Date:         Mon, 19 Aug 2002 10:52:53 -0400
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Nick Piombino <npiombino@AAAHAWK.COM>
Subject:      Self publish or perish
Mime-version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-transfer-encoding: 7bit

> Date:    Sun, 18 Aug 2002 11:58:37 EDT
> From:    Tom Beckett <TBeck131@AOL.COM>
> Subject: Re: Self-publish or perish
>
> This is an interesting thread.  Nick's take is characteristically thoughtful
> but a little too linear for my taste .Personally I don't want art to be
> science. More than half of a poem's message is its _mess_, the tangle of
> ambiguity and unresolvableness that makes it worth returning to again and
> again.
>
> Tom Beckett

I agree with you, Tom. I don't want art to be science either. I don't think
it is possible or desirable. What I was trying to get at is the issue of
distribution. One of the ideals of science is to distribute data as
generously and and as rapidly as possible. When we look at our writing work
as collectible objects, I feel this "slows down" the acceleration of
exchange. It causes us to look at poems as unique constructs, or to overly
focus on them as unique objects. I agree that the mysteriousness of poems,
"the tangle of ambiguity and unresolvableness" is one of the key factors in
making them "worth returning to again and again." This viewpoint is a strong
factor in the pleasure of poetry and you put it very well. My question had
to do with this very mysteriousness and what relationship there might be
between the private and enigmatic character of individual creation (the
unknowable formulas that makes certain poetry so collectible) and how this
outlook effects the reception of poetry and the way poetry is exchanged. I
knew that I was risking eliciting all the thorny issues that make the
separation of art and science so important, a separation I also strongly
agree with. There is a tendency in science (and many other areas of
exploration) to push for uniformity of thinking- something that poetry
offers a respite from in some ways. The tendency to overly focus on the
mysterious "secret ingredients" in poetry, however, the "new improved
formulas" that make our products "irresistable and exciting" ("So crunchy
and delicious I'll be you can't eat just one!") offers us a sure-fire escape
from the conformist rituals of science only to throw us more deeply into the
seductive arms of our advertisement ridden consumer culture. Once we cuddle
up with consumer culture as poets, however, we have all the problems that go
with marketing, distribution and sales with none of the (occasional)
advantages. If given a choice I would opt for an attitude towards the
objects of poetry that might be in some ways more akin to certain idealistic
aspects of the exchange of information that is utilized in the sciences over
the hopelessly dead end values implicit in consumer culture.

Nick PIombino

Date:         Mon, 19 Aug 2002 11:52:09 -0400
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Nick Piombino <npiombino@AAAHAWK.COM>
Subject:      The physics of rapture
Mime-version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-transfer-encoding: 7bit

My thanks to Joe Brennan for forwarding this response from CP. What I found
interesting about the Tipler book was its eccentricity. I hope CP does not
think that because I mentioned Tipler's ideas that I agree with them or even
understand them or found very much of value in them for poets or anybody
else. Actually, I'm quite sure that very few poets, if any, would find, as
CP puts it "any number of lame images and metaphors to use in their
relentless quest to discredit their art." I also don't agree with CP at all
that poets have a relentless quest to discredit their art. Not the ones I
know or know about, anyway. There are certainly some uninteresting poems out
there, but I don't see that as a quest to discredit the field of poetry.  I
certainly thought many of the religious references that Tipler employs and
the book's claustrophobic enclosure within the ideas and images of
Christianity painful to read. What I did find interesting was the phenomenon
of a respected scientist flying in the face of more or less everything his
colleagues hold dear, specifically in "scientifically" trying to "prove" the
existence of immortality. Tipler points out that "resurrection has been
inconsistent with the accepted physics of the day for two thousand years."
There was a wild, desperate, career, self and assumption immolating aspect
to this book that I found fascinating, especially coming from a scientist.
It is very strange and fascinating what people will do to escape from the
fear of death and to offer other people an escape from such fear. I have to
admit to finding many ideas fascinating that I don't agree with, or
sometimes don't even completely understand.

The speed of light not being always constant doesn't surprise me very much
when not very much else about reality is always constant. It is exciting to
hear about this assertion on the part of the Australian scientists.

It would be interesting to learn more about CP's Tale of the Tribe,
Millenary's Cantos and Eschatology of Reason.

Nick Piombino

> Somebody should point out to Nick Piombino that Tipler's
> thesis is dependent upon the universe expanding to the Omega
> point and then
> collapsing in upon itself. Current data, however, suggests
> that the universe will not collapse back in upon itself but
> rather go on
> expanding forever, a concept which carries its own
> mathematical and epistemological difficulties. This renders
> Tipler's book a bigger christian teleological cowpie than it
> already was if that's possible.
> Though Tipler is considered a 'serious' scientist who is at
> his best delivering big research bucks, few take the book
> seriously though I'm sure poets can find any number of lame
> images and metaphors to use in their relentless quest to
> discredit
> their art.
>
> Of course, the larger question concerns the immutability of
> the physico/mathematical laws which are utterly universal
> and
> immortal one day and completely anthema the next. We just
> had a good example of this with current research out of
> Australia
> which indicates that Einstein's theory of special relativity
> is wrong because the speed of light apparently is not a
> constant.
> Rather than throw out the Second Law of Thermodynamics our
> demiurges have begun jettisoning brother Einstein in a
> series of
> papers and presentations sure to net more research money and
> possibly the Dynamite Prize. And most of us hadn't even come
>
> to grips with Newton's asterisks. CP
>

> Centos and

Subject:      Re: Self publish or perish

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding:  7bit

Nick,

I know how difficult it can be to get work around.  I'm 49 years old and
still haven't managed to publish a full-length book of my own writing. So it
goes.

But I'm just not comfortable with science as a model for distribution.  Art
and data are not synonymous terms. Writing--if not the writer-- often
benefits from lag time, from a slowing down of the acceleration of exchange.
At the level of the text, "experimental" writing literally enacts this
slowing down by disrupting more expedient conduits of exchange.  As you well
know. As it is above, so it is below.  No matter how a bundle of innovative
poetry makes its way in the world ,it has to make its case one reader at a
time and it does that by problematizing the relationship between the writer
and the reader.  This dynamic is at the heart of our distribution problem.
And talk about a practice resistant to consumer culture!

Tom Beckett



> I agree with you, Tom. I don't want art to be science either. I don't think
> it is possible or desirable. What I was trying to get at is the issue of
> distribution. One of the ideals of science is to distribute data as
> generously and and as rapidly as possible. When we look at our writing work
> as collectible objects, I feel this "slows down" the acceleration of
> exchange. It causes us to look at poems as unique constructs, or to overly
> focus on them as unique objects. I agree that the mysteriousness of poems,
> "the tangle of ambiguity and unresolvableness" is one of the key factors in
> making them "worth returning to again and again." This viewpoint is a
> strong
> factor in the pleasure of poetry and you put it very well. My question had
> to do with this very mysteriousness and what relationship there might be
> between the private and enigmatic character of individual creation (the
> unknowable formulas that makes certain poetry so collectible) and how this
> outlook effects the reception of poetry and the way poetry is exchanged. I
> knew that I was risking eliciting all the thorny issues that make the
> separation of art and science so important, a separation I also strongly
> agree with. There is a tendency in science (and many other areas of
> exploration) to push for uniformity of thinking- something that poetry
> offers a respite from in some ways. The tendency to overly focus on the
> mysterious "secret ingredients" in poetry, however, the "new improved
> formulas" that make our products "irresistable and exciting" ("So crunchy
> and delicious I'll be you can't eat just one!") offers us a sure-fire
> escape
> from the conformist rituals of science only to throw us more deeply into
> the
> seductive arms of our advertisement ridden consumer culture. Once we cuddle
> up with consumer culture as poets, however, we have all the problems that
> go
> with marketing, distribution and sales with none of the (occasional)
> advantages. If given a choice I would opt for an attitude towards the
> objects of poetry that might be in some ways more akin to certain
> idealistic
> aspects of the exchange of information that is utilized in the sciences
> over
> the hopelessly dead end values implicit in consumer culture.
>
>

Date:         Mon, 19 Aug 2002 14:54:46 -0400
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Vernon Frazer <vfrazer@ATTBI.COM>
Subject:      Re: Self-Publish or Perish
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

The self-publishing tradition includes Gertrude Stein, James Joyce, Walt
Whitman, Mark Twain and Emily Dickinson, for starters. Considering the
caliber of the writers who self-published their work before anybody "got
it," I really wonder why publishers and agents place such a stigma on it.
Economic control appears to be the primary reason. They can't be "saving us"
from  "bad work," since I see enough of it in the bookstores.

Distribution of any kind is a problem. Self-publishing writers or
self-producing musicians (e.g., Sun Ra, Don Pullen, Wadada Leo Smith and
many others) try to work on all fronts, until they find an opening. Giving
away much of the work is part of the promotion  It is also part of the
confused economics the current system generates because the avant-garde has
so few members that a paying fan soon becomes a friend who gets free copies.
I give away a lot of copies in the hope that one reader will talk to another
and persuade them to buy a copy.

IMHO, it's better to self-publish and give your work a chance to find its
place in the world than to let it rot in your desk drawer. If I stopped
trying and did the latter, my wife would never be able to tolerate my level
of frustration. Aside from literary ambition, I guess you'd say I
self-publish so that other key areas of my life will remain fulfilling, in
addition to the work itself.

I would have to say that both models are necessary, since self-publishing
writers don't have a single working model they can consistently rely on.

Vernon



> Yes, I think self-publishing is a tradition of its own, and a guerilla
> effort, as Vernon points out.  Which is the point.  For instance, perhaps
> we wouldn't have Reznikoff if he hadn't self published?

>
> So Alan brings up important questions of distribution, exclusivity and
> audience.  But self-publishing is not necessarily exclusive, and is one
way
> to develop audience.  In fact, most people I know who have done some
> self-publishing tend to give away their things pretty widely.  So then
they
> are not sold, in that case, and not then a part of the exclusivity of what
> has to have been or not have been bought.  Though that does not
necessarily
> exempt them from an economics of distribution, as the distribution for
> either kind of poetry publication is not very wide, anyway, obviously.  So
> both models are necessary and possible, no?
>
>
> Sherry
>

Date:         Mon, 19 Aug 2002 15:14:04 -0400
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Geoffrey Gatza <ggatza@DAEMEN.EDU>
Subject:      United States Military Academy Poetics Program
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="Windows-1252"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

United States Military Academy
at West Point=20


Poetics Program

=20

                                Study War Poetry?
=20

                                                                =93War is
Heck=94=20
                                                                Kermit
the Frog=20


Warfare & Poetry - one of the major pre-occupations of mankind.=20

The threat of major war amongst the leading industrial states may have
receded. However, a brief look at current affairs reminds us daily of
the continuing risks of war around the world=20

                        in the Middle East, the former Soviet Union,
Africa,                         South and East Asia and, of course, in
southern Europe.=20
        =09
                        And from War comes Poetry.=20

War Poems challenge all aspects of the societies in which they occur=20

and the study of war poems, therefore, deserves careful attention=20
to gain a greater understanding of the complex questions raised:

        - Why do war poems occur?=20

        - How might war poems be prevented, avoided or resolved?=20

        - How has the character of warfare and war poems changed over
time?=20

        - Can wars be 'just'? If only for the poetry?

        - How will new challenges such as peacekeeping and the
information             revolution affect the use of poetry during
conflict?=20

        - How have developments in modern poetics affected the military
professional?=20

=20

Can =93lessons from the past=94 facilitate our understanding of =
contemporary
conflicts and assessment of future poems created during periods of war?=20

While United States Military Academy at West Point suggests a long
history of rules and laws of composition, the Poetics Program stresses
poiesis -- the actual making or doing: poetry as process. Every doing
carries the potential of something new, emergent, something not already
predicated by poetics. Practice overtakes theory, practice changes
theory.=20

And not just writing practice, but performance practice, the performance
of war.

To make war is to produce meaning and not reproduce (eradicate) a
pre-existing meaning. To destroy is to not remain subjected to a meaning
that supposedly precedes rationality. War or poetry is never about
something, it is something. Writing is not the living repetition of
life, or death where the case may be made.=20

The author is that which gives the disquieting language of war and
poetry its unities and disunities, its knot of cadence and chaos, its
insertion into the hot zone.=20

All warfare is conducted haphazardly. Now some people might say the
situation (of poetry and war) is not very encouraging but one must reply
that it is not meant to encourage those who say that!

War Poems are a challenging multi-disciplinary genera. Our educators
have chosen to draw on military, diplomatic, international, strategic
poems as well as on self described anti-war poems. Our specialist
interests extend across many regions of the poetry spectrum, ranging
from all genres of war poetry from Europe and Africa to North America
and Asia-Pacific. These interests also extend across time with
colleagues focusing on topics ranging from the dynamics of ancient and
medieval epic poetry to contemporary problems such as the conflicts in
the War Against Terror.

War Poems are inherently a controversial subject and we seek to provide
a forum for study in which individuals are encouraged to think hard
about these poems before reaching their own conclusions in the vastness
of all possible dimension.


=20

Compulsory Core Courses


The Causes of War Poems


This course is an introduction to thinking about the causes of war
poems. It aims to make students aware of the philosophical background to
debates about causation. To familiarize students with a variety of
approaches to the causation and compositions of war poems, and to
examine the merits and weaknesses of historical sociology as an overall
framework.


The Conduct of War Poetry

This course is designed to explore the dynamics of warfare at the
strategic and operational levels up to the age of Napoleon, and to
highlight changes and continuities in the way war poems has been
composed.=20


The Experience of War

The aims of this course are to explore the various experiences of war -
individual, group and community, direct and indirect, battlefield and
home front, military and civilian, male and female, and empirical and
cultural through the effect of poems. The course also aims to both
encourage reflection on the meaning and value of experience and also to
promote an understanding of experience in relation to other aspects of
war.


Contemporary Security Issues

The course will cover some of the major debates within the field
(generated from the disputes between realists poets and liberal minded
poets) as they are played out through contemporary security issues. It
will also examine the types of security issues which have come to
prominence in the Post-September 11th era. There is a particular focus
on intra-state conflict and the issue of intervention and
collaborations.


The Art of War Studies

Supplementing the other BA1 Core Courses in War Studies, the aims of
this course are to provide students with an introduction to the main
skills that are necessary for the BA Literature Studies program.


War in Modern History


The aim of this course is to equip students with intellectual skills in
comprehending major aspects of military and strategic affairs in the
world from the Crimean War to the Vietnam War.=20

=20

=20

War Poems and Society


This course aims to provide you with an understanding of the key issues
in philosophical and sociological approaches to the study of war poem
and the military establishment, such as, 'just' war poem and the ethics
of nuclear deterrence. Thesis work will dwell on =93Is the war a
justification for Good Poetry?=94


Option Courses


The following is a list of option courses running in the 2001-2002
academic year. Please note that the option courses offered each year may
vary and we may not be able to offer all the option courses listed in a
given year. We regret that no further information on the option courses
are available at this time.

Date:         Mon, 19 Aug 2002 15:24:11 -0400
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Jordan Davis <jdavis@PANIX.COM>
Subject:      The Journal of Irreproducible Results (for bears)
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Nick suggests a model of poetic production in which the aim is not to
accumulate attention within a subculture by imitating the appropriate
(i.e. high-attention accumulator) forebear, but rather to contribute to
the general body of knowledge by experimenting with the assumptions and
methods of forebears without respect to their place in the league
standings (which to abandon the frame of science in order to indulge in an
metaphor from the market could be looked at as value investing). Murat
counters that experimenting with the assumptions and methods of forebears
is a recipe for academic (i.e. mechanical and cliched) writing. But Murat,
what was Ted Berrigan doing in The Sonnets when he took Frank O'Hara's use
of times of day literally? The bear whose name has not been mentioned in
this discussion is Hal Bloom, whose misprision encompasses both Nick's and
Murat's version of influence.

Nick, I understand your wish not to be flown remote control by the
classics, but couldn't a writer come by an interest in the so-called
greats honestly, i.e. by genuine attraction to their language, with
friction in their understanding?

And Murat, I understand your rejection out-of-hand of the concept of
progress in the arts, but isn't that also an old-fogey rejection of new
work?

To answer my own questions: Ted Berrigan was misunderstanding Frank
O'Hara, and therefore making his work new. Writers respond to others' work
differently every time, and it's probably only a productive mistake to set
up any art as an absolute standard. And yes, that is an old-fogey
rejection of new work.

Jordan

From:         Joe Brennan <JBCM2@AOL.COM>
Subject:      Re: Fwd: The physics of rapture

Subj:   Re: Fwd: The physics of rapture
Date:   08/19/2002 3:03:15 PM Eastern Daylight Time
From:   <A HREF="mailto:alphavil@ix.netcom.com">alphavil@ix.netcom.com</A>
To: <A HREF="mailto:JBCM2@aol.com">JBCM2@aol.com</A>
Sent from the Internet (Details)



Well. I was saying that some poets use the dominant paradigm of the sciences
and attendant technologies as reservoirs of images and metaphors to tart up
and, I think at least in their minds, make new, what are tired cultural,
pseudo-intellectual and emotional bromides. Paul Lake, a devotee of the
Nursing Home School of Poetry, a few months back offered up a little giblet
very much in this vein. A dispassionate look at Jorie Graham's poetry reveals
the same kind of willy-nilly borrowing for emotional or aesthetic effect.
Science because of its supposed universality and objectivity is often used by
poets to disguise sentimentality like one would disguise rot in meat. Nick
P., himself, has been known to build a faux intellectual/poetic construct on
the back of cosmological and physical concepts.

It must be observed that people in the hard sciences and mathematics are in
general a very conservative, even reactionary, lot, so any perceived
perception of a break by Tipler as regards his fellow scientists would be
exaggerated. Certainly, not while he retains the kind of clout that brings in
research money. His books are published by big trade houses and university
presses whose editor's know that they risk little in letting a Tipler vent in
any vein he desires. Further, Barrow and Tipler's book, Anthropic
Cosmological Principle, a book every bit as teleological as P. of Im., is
much admired by the scientific community, especially the American community,
which even to this day -- and given current ecological conditions -- remains
resolutely ungrounded in European Transcendental philosophy, i.e., how the
limitations of our perceptions qua knowledge of the 'object' or the 'other '
impact on how we can know that object. Tipler's books demonstrate just how
misplaced our enthusiasm and faith in the sciences are. Books like Tipler's,
Barrow's, Murray's, Herrnstein's, Kelly's, Casti's, Shockley's, Drexler's,
and on and on (for there are hundreds of them), put on display the most
dangerous absurdities and eccentricities that drive the sciences and that
impact on us all through technology. What seems to have become obvious only
recently is the retrograde nature of the scientific method e.g. seeking
environmental answers through the same methodologies that fucked up the
environment in the first place. The way the scientific method interfaces with
its subject is temporal, partial and tautological. Its 'successes' are
limited, perceptually and technologically, and contain a downside that
broaches no compromise. Books like the ones mentioned above are, especially
for the laymen, windows into what the recent environmental developments
reveal -- the brutish failure of the scientific method. The failure of the
sciences is a systemic and epistemological failure, a failure of a method too
little criticized. This failure has never been more obvious than in the last
40 years. Its not a matter of 'good' science vs. 'bad' science, but the
inherent limitations of the scientific method now that those limitations are
magnified against the planetary paradigm. I invite interest in my work,
Deconstructing the Demiurge: Tale of the Tribe is available unabridged
(though recent changes have been made) at FlashPoint Magazine Number 5. 19
pages of the Eschatology of Reason should appear soon in the new issue of
David Hickman's Trope. A little of the Millenary's Centos appears in
Anastasios Kozaitis' Poet of the Day series and an early issue of Trope,
though under other titles. Carlo Parcelli



They hang the man and flog the woman
That steal the goose from off the common,
But let the greater villain loose
That steals the common from the goose.

Date:         Mon, 19 Aug 2002 22:23:19 -0400
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Bob Grumman <bobgrumman@NUT-N-BUT.NET>
Subject:      Re: Self-publish or perish

From Murat:

> What is troublesome to me in what you are saying is not essentially the
> connection between science and poetry, but the implicit idea of progress.
I
> find the concept of progress in art inconceivable; not only between
> historical periods but also among poets of the same period or even, in my
> opinion, among poems of the same poet.

I'm afraid I disagree, Murat.  I think all fields progress in two ways: (1)
covering greater expanses of knowledge and (2) expressing that coverage more
compressedly.  Poetry today is vastly more advanced than it was in Virgil's
time because, at its best, it covers a much larger world, and is more dense,
because of devices new since Virgil's time which reduce the number of words
needed to say something (as in modern visual poetry)--and because of all the
poetry that has preceded our poetry and which allows us to say more with
less through allusions.

A simple comparison would be to music.  It HAS to be more advanced today
than it was two thousand years ago because of all the new instruments, and
computers we now have, and because of the variety of harmonics that have
been devised, etc., etc., in the past two thousand years.  And consider all
the things that can be done in illumagery (as I call visual art) that could
not be done two thousand years ago.

I don't think we are necessarily superior to our predecessors, but our art
is superior to theirs (except that theirs now has had time to grow through
its use in later art, and commentaries, and its carrying more and more of
its fading era with it).
The Pyramids aren't just piles of blocks, they are Ancient Egypt.

> In what way is a Coleridge poem
> inferior or superior to a Frank O'Hara poem or a Shakespearean sonnet or a
> poem by Whitman or Pope, etc.? One may prefer one over the other; but this
is
> a matter of the reader's interests and tastes and also the cultural,
> philosophical assumptions of the age in which the reader lives. Each of
these
> poets creates "completion" in his or her own way. Can an O'hara moment
> "improved" upon, can a Whitman poem expanded upon?

Sure, the same way my poem, "glub nuts/ for/ diddle diddle," can be,
although it would take a lot more work.  Or are you really saying that all
poems are equal?


>
> >then the obvious next step would be to move towards a much
> >more
> >rapid distribution of confirmable discoveries. The vexing issue is, are
> >poems composed mainly of information (signals) or are they objects that
> >contain mysterious substances that cannot be isolated?
>
> Then poems are mainly composed of "information?" That's what you seem to
be
> saying or implying. After all "discovery" as something communicable is
> "information." Am I misunderstanding you? I don't think that's what poetry
> mainly does. In your previous post you referred to the "aura" of
fragments.
> How do you reconcile these two ideas?
>
> >that such discoveries could be disseminated and
> >employed in future poetry. I think of such Dada ideas as cutting up a
> >newspaper, shaking around the words and then letting them fall to the
table,
> >as the ground for some important contemporary and less recent work in the
> >field of poetry and the plastic arts, for example
>
> Unless the second artist re-imagines the cut-up process (and makes it
his/her
> own), the "technique" itself functions as a cliche, the opposite of
> "progress."

Hunh?  If poetry can go backward, surely it can go forward.

> You also imply that a scientific approach to poetry will abolish the cult
of
> personality or authority? Is that what happens in science? No heroes? No
> authorities?

> All in all, an interesting post.
>
> Murat

Yes, one that could generate several books.

--Bob G.

From:         Alan Sondheim <sondheim@PANIX.COM>
Subject:      speech of the assassin
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

speech of the assassin


we begin to arm ourselves
this is not a joke
prepare for war to come
prepare for bullet in the heart

i am a refugee hiding out in america
everything i think stems from war
already a century old, energy and suicides
trapped and hiding in america, where are guns,
the riots hiding in america, where is energy,
the flower's iron petals, the bodies hanging on the edge
can't think beyond, mechanism without electronics,
third-world newsreels, network implosions
bodies dissipated into bodies, no hope for america
smashed, afraid of everything
culture, knowledge, worlds of identities,
thefts and fabrications of identities, our murder-rape
let me tell you, comprehension is useless, only violence
remaining, gatherings of storms, the furies
and the horror, gunships gathered above,
drills beneath the ground, exposing rage,
smashing rage, decades of inactivity, violence against
innocent, we are all innocent, we will carry guns
i am hiding in america, have been hiding in america, i abjure
citizenship, watch voting-theft, rights-theft, land and water
theft, body theft, bone-and-marrow theft,,
smashed remnants, ornamented colonialisms flowered
with american bombs, they will fear me, fear the attack
from below, the vertical gun, the fury of anti-gravitation,
bomb and shrapnel, there will be capitols at the mercy of moles,
bombers against bombers, ruined limbs in piles, dead presidents,
blind animals, forests cut like flesh, annihilation
until we disappear, hiding out in america, we do our part, we
disappear together, we forget our names, we write from nothing,
we write from nothing

let us lead our enemies into temptation.
let them die with the fury of their hideous violence.

there will be a day we disappear.
we take up arms, we disappear.
we disappear, we take up arms.
brothers and sisters, we take up arms.

i am a refugee hiding out in america
everything think stems from war
already century old, energy and suicides
trapped america, where are guns,
riots is energy,
flower's iron petals, bodies hanging on edge
can't beyond that, mechanism without electronics,
third-world newsreels network implosions
dissipated only into bodies, hope for smashed,
we're all afraid of but culture, knowledge
worlds identities, thefts fabrications identities
let me tell you, comprehension useless, thing
remaining violence, gatherings storms, fury
horror, sound gunships gathering above,
great drillings beneath ground, rage that will expose us
smashing decades inactivity, violence against
innocent, oh we innocent
have been out, abjure
citizenship, watched theft voting, rights,
smashed remnants european-asian neocolonialisms ornamented
with american bombs, you must fear me, attack
below, vertical gun, anti-gravitation,
bomb shrapnel, there be capitols at mercy moles,
bombers bombers, ruined limbs piles,
blinded animals, charred forests, everywhere annihilation
until gone, do my part,
let's disappear together, forget our names, write
nothing, nothing


===

Arielle--

The original post is on the list serve, it was sent by Gerry Schwartz,
the original no longer exists on the website.

There is a photo of Jim at:
http://wowcool.com/deptex/
which leads to other info.

I'm not sure if you knew, but some of this reputation might stem from
the backdrop, a real active group of poets & artists at that moment,
which is how I got into this whole gig. A poet in niskayuna with
multiple books on Black Sparrow Press, a guy named Hank who used to be
in a famous hardcore band & went on to create his own press to publish
himself (tho he did contribute a book by the former co-editor, with my
friend Rich Blevins, of Zelot/Tansy, Bill Shields. Human Shrapnel, was
a book which needed to be done to combat the crappy Vietnam Academic (in
all senses of the word) poets such as Bruce Weigl) who was around
regularly to see a relative (uncle) who owned a bookstore in
Schenectady. There was also an extremely important magazine called Fact
Sheet five, who fed us updates on all the newest work & (after a while
begged people to take) free issues once he was done with them

We are both speaking of the same person which means I graduated a few
years previous from the same school.This is curious, I had no idea!

here is a post I did on their message board
---------------
Jim let me know things could be done; that is what I thank him for. All
I needed was a 32 ounce of coffee, maybe two
or three. I remember making these real small tape loops for a reel to
reel & playing drums for BCN on a machine in the
back room of the half-moon at a show where we all were allowed to play.
Jason, Otto, Ed, Jim, Joe Carandi, I forget
who else, the acoustics were enormously disturbing & led to a full on
call to the police for noise. I remember a guy
from that event took what he learned & went & formed the Fun Factory
(not the current pop band, but noise folks) in
Buffalo.

As a friend of Ed's, I looped in & out of contact with Jim when I lived
in Albany. My memories are vague, nearly
absent in periods of the late 80's & early 90's but I thot he was
working with Sam McPheeters / Born Against one time
I ran into him but never found out if anything came of that. The
occasional talks we had, usually late & long, if they
happened, were best. We were planning to rehash an idea Jim executed
years ago with Pavement Saw Press which I
started in Albany (it has turned into the second largest independent
literary publisher in Ohio). Jim's version was a
"action figure," a skinhead who I'll keep nameless, inside a meat
container with a price on him which was at Dave Erl's
for years (& I don't think was ever for sale). The version we have been
working on is a meat issue of our journal,
wrapped in a container, with a per ounce literary value.

As I moved to Philly & then started to tour with my writing I still ran
into Jim a few times. The last time I bought him a coffee at LuLu's & we
talked about oversentimentality & the press's newly installed wall of
shame (pasted up horrific submissions of pure poetic poop).
------------------

After talking with Jim's brother last night, it became apparent that,
altho undocumented, there were plenty of folks his ideas were "lent" to.



Be well

David Baratier, Editor

Pavement Saw Press
PO Box 6291
Columbus OH 43206
USA

http://pavementsaw.org

I'm sorry, but can someone repost the original
obituary, or backchannel it to me?  I think I missed
it, and only after reading David Baratier's posting do
I realize that I think I might have known Jim--I think
I went to high school with him, or at least with his
friends.

The band he was in, the Brown Cuts Neighbors, were
formed one day in gym class when a bunch of us were
sitting around trying to avoid running the track at
Niskayuna High School in Schenectady, NY (this was the
late 80s).  Jason Martin and some other guys (Rob
Goodale, I think?) were talking about starting a band,
even though they didn't really play any instruments.
We thought it was a joke.  Then they came out with a
little tape--"Broken Down Like a Bean"--and gave out
copies with handmade covers around school...I think I
still have mine.  The songs were totally insane and
wonderful: one of my favorites was called "Running
Naked on Peyote" and it still gets stuck in my head to
this day.

I moved away from the Capital District of upstate NY
after high school, and so it was always amazing to me
to go back to Albany and see BCN written up as a
serious avant-noise collective in the local papers.
To me they were always just a bunch of the craziest
guys in my high school.  I went to a show they did
once on Niska-Day, the annual town pride festival, in
which they played alongside other, far more
conventional bands.  BCN were nuts, of course, playing
conceptual hardcore until some school administrator
pulled the plug.  It was a great event.

I'm sorry to hear about Jim.

Arielle

From:         Jordan Davis <jdavis@PANIX.COM>
Subject:      Aware
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

I wasn't aware yesterday of how snippy I sounded. Or chirpy. Gimlet
chickadee-dee-dee. Today I want to vote for Nick's move to call into
question all unexamined models for consuming, producing, and distributing
this hybrid poetico-critical text-paste. Some givens:

if poetry didn't exist we'd invent it -- or rather we'd go on using words
in non-standard ways giving pleasure and insight (or inhibiting pleasure
and insight! for whatever honestly-come-by reason)

Poetry exists

and is and has been written by poets

who (because poetry transmits affect apparently by magic) come to be seen
as magic people

by people who come later and want to use words in non-standard ways but
for whatever honestly-come-by reason have been inhibited, scolded, held up
to unreasonable standards

so they appeal to the authority of the ancient magic people

some of whom are still alive

----

What gets lost (what was never found) is an explicit common understanding
of the goal of using language in non-standard ways. A doubt I have about
Nick's experimental model is that it doesn't explicitly account for
affection, self-interest, or deviousness -- in short for psychology -- for
gaming around the context of these methods of communication so liable to
give the consumer (wrong word!) the feeling they're being put on.

(On the other hand, I could take what Nick applies to texts and their
creators, this model of tinkering with how one responds oneself to a
received method, and apply it to texts and their audiences, and understand
it as tinkering with the response one gets from others.)

In any event, I'm grateful to Nick for raising the subject of unexamined
assumptions -- and I would hope any and all will modify my list of givens
for this strange but conventional human activity of communicating
differently.

Jordan

<DIV></DIV>&gt;Nick suggests a model of poetic production in which the aim is not to
<DIV></DIV>&gt;accumulate attention within a subculture by imitating the appropriate
<DIV></DIV>&gt;(i.e. high-attention accumulator) forebear, but rather to contribute to
<DIV></DIV>&gt;the general body of knowledge by experimenting with the assumptions and
<DIV></DIV>&gt;methods of forebears without respect to their place in the league
<DIV></DIV>&gt;standings (which to abandon the frame of science in order to indulge in an
<DIV></DIV>&gt;metaphor from the market could be looked at as value investing). Murat
<DIV></DIV>&gt;counters that experimenting with the assumptions and methods of forebears
<DIV></DIV>&gt;is a recipe for academic (i.e. mechanical and cliched) writing. But Murat,
<DIV></DIV>&gt;what was Ted Berrigan doing in The Sonnets when he took Frank O'Hara's use
<DIV></DIV>&gt;of times of day literally? The bear whose name has not been mentioned in
<DIV></DIV>&gt;this discussion is Hal Bloom, whose misprision encompasses both Nick's and
<DIV></DIV>&gt;Murat's version of influence.
<DIV></DIV>&gt;
<DIV></DIV>&gt;Nick, I understand your wish not to be flown remote control by the
<DIV></DIV>&gt;classics, but couldn't a writer come by an interest in the so-called
<DIV></DIV>&gt;greats honestly, i.e. by genuine attraction to their language, with
<DIV></DIV>&gt;friction in their understanding?
<DIV></DIV>&gt;
<DIV></DIV>&gt;And Murat, I understand your rejection out-of-hand of the concept of
<DIV></DIV>&gt;progress in the arts, but isn't that also an old-fogey rejection of new
<DIV></DIV>&gt;work?
<DIV></DIV>&gt;
<DIV></DIV>&gt;To answer my own questions: Ted Berrigan was misunderstanding Frank
<DIV></DIV>&gt;O'Hara, and therefore making his work new. Writers respond to others' work
<DIV></DIV>&gt;differently every time, and it's probably only a productive mistake to set
<DIV></DIV>&gt;up any art as an absolute standard. And yes, that is an old-fogey
<DIV></DIV>&gt;rejection of new work.

<html><div style='background-color:'><DIV>
<P>Steve Jonas' psychosexual connections to money&nbsp;and magic, mostly via Pound&nbsp;in the former term, and both Spicer and Wieners&nbsp;in the latter would seem to cut a figure at some remove from the more grandly "street"&nbsp;likes of Amiri Baraka.&nbsp; Jonas isn't thought "black" because he didn't approach "black topics" in any but the most oblique ways.&nbsp; Being gay, also, sets up categorical distinctions within "black arts"&nbsp;that&nbsp;become increasingly complex.&nbsp; His pansexual concern for equity in all senses of commerce place him at the very beginnings of lawful creation, rather than in a generalized social mileu.&nbsp; His work is as particular in aspect as Hammurabi's code - and as essential.&nbsp; To categorize him by the patina of his skin suggests parity with an Egyptian sophistication out of Beirut in the 30s, or better, Muslim Spain of the 12th century, where Qabbalistic study equally&nbsp;was as rife as the red of a tomato.&nbsp; But in terms 
 of Boston, doesn't Jonas really belong w/ Wieners, Gerrit Lansing, Spicer, Blaser,&nbsp;Harold Dull and possibly even someone like George Stanley?&nbsp; I mean, why even bother&nbsp;continuing the racial division? -&nbsp;it seems an empty categorical lump despite historical association.</P>

From:         Ian Randall Wilson <IanRWilson05@AOL.COM>
Subject:      Self-Publish or Perish
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding:  7bit

If you're interested in the traditional printing model of an actual artifact
that can be held in the hand and then stored on a shelf, Print On Demand
offers a way for anyone to self-publish a hardcover book with jacket or
softcover book that looks no different than the materials coming from any
large commercial press.  For a grand or so, IUniverse, XLibris or
1stBooks.com will happily take your money and get your book out -- there.
Once it's in their system, the book will be available from Amazon, bn.com,
any independent bookstore and even the chain stores will special order it.
(It's helpful to make the book returnable and available for the standard
trade discount but even if you do neither, Amazon will still list it.)

So the problem is no longer access to production or even access to
distribution.  The problem is visibility.  There's a huge amount of noise and
clutter in our culture.  Rising into view, how do you do it?  Movie studios
are putting $20-50 million behind their films saturating every available
avenue of promotion, and doing it every day.  The same goes for record
companies.  TV shows.  Large books publishers do so at a smaller scale.  How
does anyone know your little books is available?

Visibility, on the most gross scale, becomes a question of money.  If you're
willing to put some behind the book -- reviewer copies, targetted mailings,
display ads and the like -- you might get some recognition.  (1stBooks has
been running full page ads in the NY Times Book Review for groups of books.
I don't know off hand what the full page rate is but it can't be cheap.  It
might be worth it -- apparently is worth it -- to some of these
self-published authors to spend another 6, 7 hundred or a thousand dollars to
be one of the 10 books in the ad.)

From:         Tisa Bryant <tisab@EARTHLINK.NET>
Subject:      Re: Stephen Jonas
In-Reply-To:  <F5RO0BnRKa8Th6kx86t0001db87@hotmail.com>
Mime-version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-transfer-encoding: 7bit

No, I wouldn't argue that at all.  I'd include him.
And whether Jonas spins in his grave or grins from the Great Beyond, a
conference on him would be awesome, gloriously important, and a long time
coming.  He deserves the attention.

I claim Jonas as part of my own mixed-up literary and blood lineage without
"removing" him from where Stephen Ellis suggests he "really belongs," which
is, unless I've misread the results of his queerly veiled Egypto-paper
bag-test treatise, with white poets/readers, all on site in Boston, my
insanely racist hometown.   I just feel Jonas, his queerness, "otherness,"
his street running hustle, his lovely work with sound, all in Boston, in
spite of the FOUL things he's written about Blackness and Black people,
while all up in the rhythm of what he disrespected.  What do Weiners et. al.
have to do with that?   If with them is where Jonas belongs...where there is
affinity, there is also complicity.

I've been consumed with thoughts of Leo Felton  in relation to Jonas, and
separate from him, the fact of skin privilege, "milieu," the idea or
illusion of having a choice in the matter, the horrid jealousy such a choice
is regarded with by those without it, how horribly guarded the fact of a
choice and subsequent decision, by those who have it, etc.

It's all so very complex.

Tisa

***
I like to think good writing is fetishized and compassionate terrorism.

Eurydice

Here's the address to make an already-published book available in Palm
format.  They are sold -- right now none are free:

At the current time, Palm Digital Media does not maintain the editorial
staff to undertake an original publishing program. We do require that
all materials that we publish have been subjected to a rigorous
editorial review through some other form of publication. If your book
meets this requirement, you can send a copy to:

SUBMISSIONS
Palm Digital Media Four Clock Tower Place, Suite 420
Maynard, MA 01754

Also, please include a floppy or zip disk with electronic files for your
book. Preferred formats are MS-Word, .rtf or HTML. Cover art should be
submitted as a PhotoShop file. If you require that your book be
returned, please include a SASE. Palm Digital Media does not accept any
responsibility for materials submitted and will respond with an
indication of our interest in your manuscript within 90 days.

Note that there doesn't seem to be a requirement to convert it to palm
reader format, which is easy enough and free.

From:         Patrick Herron <patrick@PROXIMATE.ORG>
Subject:      Goodbye Patty, Farewell
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Goodbye Patty, Farewell


Willy, an employee of McDonald's
Jimmy, an employee of Wendy's
Leia, an employee of Burger King
Vladimir, an employee of Taco Bell



It is NIGHT.  Willy, Jimmy, Leia, and Vladimir all stand huddled in an empty
paved urban parking lot.  They are all wearing their respective employer's
uniforms.  They warm their hands from a couch fire burning before them.



Willy: [to Jimmy]  I will lend to it you for awhile.  For you to love it
while it lives and mourn for him when it's dead. Maybe for twelve or
fourteen years, or maybe two or three. But will you,' till I call it back,
take care of it for me?

Jimmy: [announcing, as if either preaching or hard of hearing] ITS SANTA HAT
AND STOCKING ARE STOWED WITH CARE. MORE SO RIGHT NOW IT'S HIT ME.  IT'S NO
LONGER THERE.

Leia:  [to Willy] They will give it anything and everything you want. That
is a lot more than I can do. I hope it remembers me because I will always
remember it.

Jimmy: [again shouting] WHERE I EXPECT IT AND THINK IT WILL BE....  [He
sits.]  GOD, HOW THIS CHRISTMAS IS SO SAD AND HEARTBREAKING FOR ME.

Vladimir:  [to Leia, nudging her] He'll bring his charms to gladden it and
it'll always have his memories as solace for its grief.  I cannot promise he
will stay, since all from Earth return.  But there are lessons taught below
I want it to learn.

Willy:  [to Leia, shaking] I've looked the whole world over, in search of
teachers fit, And from the folk that crowd's life's land, I have chosen it.
Now will you give it all your love, Nor think the labor vain, Nor hate me
when I come to take it back again.

Jimmy: [still shouting] IT WAS MY GIFT ELEVEN CHRISTMAS DAYS SHOULD BE, BUT
THREE WEEKS TO THIS DAY IT SUDDENLY LEFT ME.

Leia:  [to Willy] Once in a lifetime a true friend comes along. Thank you my
beloved for being that friend.  I will love you forever.

Jimmy: [scream, go ahead]  AND SO THE PRESENTS I MIGHT HAVE WANTED ARE NO
WHERE TO BE, FOR THE ONLY THING TRULY WANTED WOULD BE IT STILL BESIDE ME.

Willy:  [crying] I fancied that I heard them say "Thy Will be Done," For all
the joys it will bring, the risk of grief we'll run.  We'll shelter it with
tenderness we'll love it while we may And for the happiness we've known
forever grateful stay But should it call it back much sooner than we've
planned, We'll brave the bitter grief that comes, and try to understand.
If, by our love, we've managed, your wishes to achieve In memory of it we
loved, to help us while we grieve, When our faithful bundle departs this
world of strife, We'll have yet another and love it all its life.

Vladimir:  [whispering to Leia]  When it's gone nothing will be the same. My
heart will be two.  Part with it and part with me.

Jimmy: [we know, yell]  GIVE ME IT AS A GIFT WHAT SEEMED NOT LONG AGO, AND
BROUGHT BACK TO IT MY GIFT THAT I SO MISS SO.

Willy:  [still crying]  When it leaves I'll try not to cry. It was a loving,
loyal friend.  I'm sure the angels will open to it with open arms. They will
make it free of suffering.

Leia:  [looking upward] It was so pretty and so full of joy. We miss it and
its love for life.  We miss it so terribly. If we could turn the clock back,
it would be here by our sides. We will always love & miss it. Sleep tight.
May it rest in heaven.

Jimmy: [now singing]  REST EASY AND PLAY FREE, FOR SOON I'LL BE WITH IT AND
SEE; THAT ALL IS WELL AS WE MEET IN THE RAINBOWS AND STAY SIDE BY SIDE INTO
ETERNITY FOR THAT WOULD TRULY BE HEAVEN TO ME.

...leading into orchestra playing heart-wrenching outerstellar country death
blues melody...

Chorus: [20 laptops with different synthesized voices singing each number
aloud, "two hundred point zero zero," etc.]
Bacon Cheeseburger, 200.00, 13.00, 115.00, 25.00, 400.0, 12.00, 10.00, 3.00,
0.00.
Chocolate Shake, 220.00, 7.00, 60.00, 25.00, 140.0, 32.00, 8.00, 27.00.
Chicken Rings, 310.00, 21.00, 190.00, 70.00, 620.0, 14.00, 16.00, 0.00,
0.00.
Breakfast Sandwich, 340.00, 25.00, 220.00, 130.00, 900.0, 17.00, 14.00,
0.00, 2.00.
Onion Chips, 180.00, 9.00, 80.00, 0.00, 580.0, 25.00, 3.00, 3.00.

Jimmy: [intoning]  FATTY PATTY
MAKE ME HAPPY.
CLEAN THE APE
OFF YOUR PLATE.


THE END



Patrick Herron
patrick@proximate.org

my assassin, my flayed president, my young young man


the men. dangerous the young dangerous men. young flight bows. of flight
arrows of and arrows bows. and wielded face-down. machetes wielded knives,
and face-down. knives, in dirt. dirt, the dirt. the all stopped. violence
all power in must power be must killed be permanently and stopped.
permanently no else. one no is one better is than better anyone than else.
anyone an turn. ugly an turn. ugly our alive. president our was president
never was elected never flayed was alive. flayed turn figures. inside-out
power like inside-out skin-covered like figures. power human the species
human deserves species isolation. deserves women. young bullets of
invisibilities. and repeatedly destruction. we repeatedly have we begged
have for begged permanent for destruction. permanent call we on call every
on to power come to aid. our crippled, cripple. cripple. we uglier an
assassination annihilation. covers assassination globe the with globe
annihilation. permanent destroy, said. she destroy, said. she there no
problematic no nature, of none nature, culture, of sexual, none
morphogenesis, morphine. morphine. morphogenesis, i assassin. am i a am
camera. a your am bullet. your you bullet. are you my are assassin. my
assassination. my man: young

This information is still accurate.
I give a redaction:

For those interested in contributing anything less than $500.00, please do
not send checks, as a check-cashing fee of $30.00 is charged.  The best
thing to do is send cash directly to Corman at:

Cid Corman
Fukuoji-cho 80
Utano, Utano-ku
Kyoto, 616,
Japan.

account.  Address:

Cid Corman c/o Kyoto Shinyo Kinko Bank
Omuro Branch, Omuro Ukyo-ku
Kyoto 616-8208
Japan
account# 095-0010328
bank tel. # 81-75-462-9670

donations, please add a note that says that this money is for Shizumi's eye
operation.

I want to clarify something: Cid and Shizumi no longer own their own
business.  Shizumi's family maintains the business, but her brother and
sister are also getting too old to make a go of it.  That's why the
situaltion is growing even more tenuous with each passing year.  Jesse Glass

Subject:      post a poem, eh?
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

A BROTHER ON THE BALTIC

How has this warm
tilting like a planet
commanded
your peeking into
a subplot,
are you saving
strength for a variance

the motor of a mayfly

settled into noticing
the clutter and lilies
by a sedative

Valentine, listen
to the song I'm singing you

These funny sounds are questions

Cancel your nap plans,
we're going through clothes
left on top of the garbage

birth control meaning
the consolidation of wealth

I mean I hear you
as the pressure that compiles an alternate me

the sorrow in all that relates

At 3:08 PM +0000 8/20/02, Stephen Ellis wrote:
>Steve Jonas' psychosexual connections to money and magic, mostly via
>Pound in the former term, and both Spicer and Wieners in the latter
>would seem to cut a figure at some remove from the more grandly
>"street" likes of Amiri Baraka.  Jonas isn't thought "black" because
>he didn't approach "black topics" in any but the most oblique ways.


isn't "thought black" by whom?  i don't think i've ever been part of
a discussion of jonas or read anyhthing by or about him that didn't
make clear his affiliations with black vernacular culture.

>Being gay, also, sets up categorical distinctions within "black
>arts" that become increasingly complex.  His pansexual concern for
>equity in all senses of commerce place him at the very beginnings of
>lawful creation, rather than in a generalized social mileu.  His
>work is as particular in aspect as Hammurabi's code - and as
>essential.  To categorize him by the patina of his skin suggests
>parity with an Egyptian sophistication out of Beirut in the 30s, or
>better, Muslim Spain of the 12th century, where Qabbalistic study
>equally was as rife as the red of a tomato.  But in terms of Boston,
>doesn't Jonas really belong w/ Wieners, Gerrit Lansing, Spicer,
>Blaser, Harold Dull and possibly even someone like George Stanley?
>I mean, why even bother continuing the racial division? - it seems
>an empty categorical lump despite historical association.


it must be possible to think about a poet in his/her entirety --not
occluding an ethnoracial aspect in favor of a coterie aspect --it's
the whole picture that makes the work/life interesting, compelling,
etc.  it's not a racial "division" to include someone's racial
politics in a discussion.

Subject:      Self publish or perish
Mime-version: 1.0

> if poetry didn't exist we'd invent it -- or rather we'd go on using words
> in non-standard ways giving pleasure and insight (or inhibiting pleasure
> and insight! for whatever honestly-come-by reason)
>
> Poetry exists
>
> and is and has been written by poets
>
> who (because poetry transmits affect apparently by magic) come to be seen
> as magic people
>
> by people who come later and want to use words in non-standard ways but
> for whatever honestly-come-by reason have been inhibited, scolded, held up
> to unreasonable standards
>
> so they appeal to the authority of the ancient magic people
>
> some of whom are still alive
>
> ----
>
> What gets lost (what was never found) is an explicit common understanding
> of the goal of using language in non-standard ways.
(Jordan Davis)

I happened to come across a reprint of the original edition of a book by one
our most esteemed peers, Walt Whitman, who seemed to have much to say on the
topic of poetics-

"Of all nations the United States with veins full of poetical stuff most
need poets and doubtless have the greatest and use them the greatest. Their
President shall not be their common referee so much as their poets shall. Of
all mankind the great poet is the equable man."

"The poet sees for a certainty how one not a great artist may be just as
sacred and perfect as the greatest artist...The power to destroy or remould
is freely used by him but never the power of attack. What is past is
past....He is not one of the chorus....he does not stop for any
regulations...he is the president of regulation....The poet shall not spend
his time in unneeded work...The messages of great poets to each man and
woman are, Come to us on equal terms. Only then can you understand us, We
are no better than you. What we enclose you enclose, What we enjoy you may
enjoy. Did you suppose there could be only one Supreme? We affirm there can
be unnumbered Supremes...The American bards shall be marked for generosity
and affection and for encouraging competitors...They shall be
Kosmos...without monopoly or secrecy...glad to pass any thing to any
one...hungry for equals night and day.... Exact science and its practical
movements are no checks on the greatest poet but always his encouragement
and support.... The anatomist chemist astronomer geologist phrenologist
spiritualist mathematician historian and lexicographer are not poets, but
they are the lawgivers of poets and their construction underlies the
structure of every perfect poem....In the beauty of poems are the tuft and
final applause of science....It is also not consistent with the reality of
the soul to admit that there is anything in the known universe more divine
than men and women....The attitude of great poets is to cheer up slaves and
horrify despots....The prescient poet projects himself centuries ahead and
judges performer or performance after the changes of time. Does it live
through them? Does it hold on untired? Will the same style and the direction
of genius to similar points be satisfactory now? Has no new discovery in
science or arrival at superior planes of thought and judgement and behavior
fixed him or his so that either can be looked down upon?....A great poem is
for ages and ages in common and for all degrees and complexions and all
departments and sects and for a woman as much as a man and a man as much as
a woman...Has anyone fancied he could sit at last under some due authority
and rest satisfied with explanations and realize and be content and full? To
no such terminus does the greatest poet bring....the elder encourages the
younger and shows him how.. They two shall launch off fearlessly together
till the new world fits an orbit for itself and looks unabashed on the
lesser orbits of the stars and sweeps through the ceaseless rings and shall
never be quiet again...the will soon be no more priests....the gangs of
kosmos and prophets en masse shall take their place. A new order shall arise
and they shall be the priests of man, and every man shall be his own
priest..."

(from Whitman's original introduction to -Leaves of Grass-)

And from the text itself:

"Stop this day and night with me and you shall possess the origin of all
poems,
You shall possess the good of the earth and sun....there are millions of
suns left,
You shall no longer take things at second or third hand....nor look through
the eyes of the dead....nor feed on the spectres in books,
You shall not look through my eyes either, nor take things from me,
You shall listen to all sides and filter them from yourself.

I have heard what the talkers were talking....the talk of the beginning and
the end,
But I do not talk of the beginning or the end.

There was never any more inception than there is now,
Nor any more youth or age than there is now;
Nor any more heaven or hell than there is now.

Urge and urge and urge,
Always the procreant urge of the world."

(selected from Walt Whitman's -Leaves of Grass- the first (1855) edition
Edited by Malcolm Cowley (NY Viking Press, 1959)


Nick Piombino

Subject:      Movies blog

I'm late joining in to the non-musical cateorgies, but Maria's post made me
think maybe not too late? (Maria, please tell us more about Sussan Deyhim!)
This one's about the movies. Books maybe will come later ...

"All About Lily Chou-Chou," a great, disturbing recent Japanese movie about
teens & "the social." Almost makes you want to avoid human beings at all
costs. But it's actually not a misanthropic film; just unflinching, and
focused on an age (teen-) when desire and peer pressure (raw socialization?)
are almost completely unmitigated by any developed sense of
ethics/metaphysics/or anything else for that matter (although you can see
them slowly, vaguely crystalizing for some of the characters). Very
stylized, visually like a contemporary Clockwork Orange, but much prettier,
with lusher greens. Me, Nada & Anna Malmude saw this together at the Quad
(world's coldest movie theater?), and me & Anna (Nada was spared high
school) basically said "Oh, yeah, that was it, all right!" It brought back a
very unpleasant flood of memories from high school, one fucked up
event/person after another. Here's the official site, which has the same
"look" as the movie:
http://www.lily-chou-chou.com/

"Devdas," 3-1/2 hours, the most expensive and lavish Hindi/Bollywood
production in history. Nada and I saw this at the Eagle Theater in Queens,
which is HUGE, and which was completely packed--weeks into the run. Probably
you have to love epic movies, musicals, historical costume drama, and
romance flicks (or Bollywood flicks) to appreciate this movie, but maybe
not. Nada and I thought it was one of the greatest movies we'd ever seen,
but we tend to like things like Bye-bye Birdie, Caligula, The Ten
Commandments, and Kismet. (Has anyone seen Kismet recently?) I got the
Devdas soundtrack afterwards, but I think the music is not so outragously
great as I thought while watching the movie--it's the movie itself, the
dance scenes, the costumes, scenery, etc. Here's a review, which will give
you the plot (since I didn't):
http://www.indiafm.com/previews/02/devdas/index.shtml

That's all I've seen in theaters recently. Would love recommendations!

Gary,

Your list encourages me to chip in a few names:

A.I. (Artificial Intelligence), a movie you'll love or you'll hate. It is the
most disturbing single movie I saw since last year (I was going to say
"2001"), both manipulative but also profound, a horrifying fairy tale/science
fiction. I don't think anybody understands better than Spielberg the Faustian
bargain modern technology (in his case cloning, the increasing ambiguity
between copy and original) presents to us and lures us with.

Masculin-Feminine (Goddard); I saw it again on tape a few weeks ago. Superb.
There is quite a long scene shot as an interview in which the "interviewer"
(a man) is asking a woman (in the form of questions) to give up pursuing a
man who doesn't love her and turn to the interviewer, who loves her; she
doesn't budge a bit. Both heartbreaking and very analytical. Directos today
are still catching up with Goddard (The Limey, a great movie inspired by
Goddard).

Earth (by an Indian director whose name I forgot); part of a trllogy, of
which I saw only this one. It is about the split of the British Empire into
India and Pakistan in 1948 -the brutal religious violence among friends it
causes. Very difficult to get this guy's work, but from what I saw worth it.

Do you remember the documentary on the gang-rape Hong Kong porno star, shot
in the first person? I think we had a discussion about this movie a few years
ago, both of us admiring it greatly.

Maybe more to come, since I have insomnia and spend the time often watching
old foreign movies.

Murat

Best film I've seen this year (with the Apu trilogy running a close 2nd)

Atarnajuat / The Fast Runner

Evil in the form of an unknown shaman divides a small community of =
nomadic Inuit. Twenty years pass. Two brothers emerge to challenge the =
evil order: Amaqjuaq, the Strong One, and Atarnajuat, The Fast Runner. =
Atarnajuat wins the hand of the lovely Atuat away from Oki, who vows to =
get even. A first-time feature film from the North-West Territories and =
from Zacharias Kunuk, this film was on the Official Selection for =
Cannes, Un Certain Regard 2001.


K e n n i n g
[a newsletter of contemporary poetry, poetics, and nonfiction writing]

From:         matvei yankelevich <myankelevich@YAHOO.COM>
Subject:      foltz & yankelevich. @ the read. tuesday.
Comments: cc: Buttonwood Tree <poetry@buttonwood.org>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

it is tuesday. that's yesterday. but it's not yesterday. it's a week from yesterday. on a tuesday. like yesterday. but not yesterday. in a week. that's when. a week from yesterday. it's at THE READ in Williamsburg. Bedford / N. 9th. that's next tuesday. at 730 pm. Aug. 27. the 27th of August.

that's when the reading is. bring flashlights. it gets dark earlier now than it used to. that's because of the sun. but we haven't changed. not us. we stay the same. that's for sure.

we read together exactly a year ago.
we're MATVEI and we're CRAIG.
that's  YANKELEVICH & FOLTZ .

that's when our first books came out on LOUDMOUTH COLLECTIVE. craig's BBQ Killers and matvei's Writing in the Margins. that reading was at SIBERIA. remember?

this time only one of us has a new book from LOUDMOUTH COLLECTIVE. the 'coming up for air' book by craig foltz and shelton walsmith should see it's first public release that night.

but matvei will bring the new 6x6 #6 (with special wallpaper covers) and also a few extra copies of  a new poem-book, a collaboration with Anna Moschovakis, printed at UGLY DUCKLING PRESSE for the upcoming Loudmouth anthology box.

but that's next tuesday. not yesterday. the reading is in a series. craig foltz is responsible. for the series. and for this flagrant appropriation. a stylistic approppriation. of his style. for this message. from his own email. message. style.

look beyond style. bring a flashlight. and you may see the sun.

Kent--

In all of my previous years of reading manuscripts, not even a knee was
intentionally slapped, which is why I was tickled with the chance of
publishing _Add Musk Here_ by the Illinois writer, John Bradley. Since
Ohioans are humorous in person,  personal correspondance, and in their
own writing, we, as a neglected but literate people who are often picked
on for our flagrant wearing of wifebeaters, are rarely able to find any
individuals from out of state who are funny enough to meet our everyday
standards. From our preliminary research, performed with substantial
funding from our unfunny titles, we have found that in Illinois, the
converse relation is true. In fact, our inconclusive results have found
that large man made constructions, such as your time-zone line, create
this condition. And even tho our journal is known for its humor, full or
chapbook length submissions are usually stodgy and pretentious. I do not
understand why.

I am glad to hear that we have  "done two or three good" books out the
over 40 titles we have published in the last ten years. To have your
recommendation means so much to us and we expect an upward sales turn as
a direct result of your endorsement.


Be well

David Baratier, Editor

Pavement Saw Press
PO Box 6291
Columbus OH 43206
USA

http://pavementsaw.org




------------

Say David, I am really glad you are publishing John Bradley's book--
he's my good friend, but I'd still think he was the best American
prose poet working today even if he wasn't my good friend. And I
know he is very funny in his poetry, though in person he's not very
funny, really, which is one of the reasons we probably get along so
well-- three or four Saturdays out of the year, he and I sit there in
Sullivan's Bar in DeKalb, Illinois, earnestly exchanging grim
aphorisms about the state of poetry in America today. By the time
we bid adieu, we know we are better and more important human
beings than all the farmers in the bar.

But anyway, to get to my point, I'm curious about your mention at
Poetics that his is the "funniest book yet" that Pavement Saw has
published. I've seen lots of the books you do, and you've done two
or three good ones, but with the exception of some of Mark
duCharme's hard and witty work, what have you ever published that
is "funny"? Nearly everything I've seen from you folks over there in
Ohio land is absolutely humorless.

Therefore, I am happy you are finally publishing a poet deserving of
the honorific "funny." Hopefully, this will mark an upward turn for
Pavement Saw!

I'm sending this also to Poetryetc, since I want people to know
about John Bradley's funny book. And ubuweb, since those bionic
androids also seem bereft of any sense of humor.

best,

Kent Johnson

--------

Be well

David Baratier, Editor

Pavement Saw Press
PO Box 6291
Columbus OH 43206
USA

http://pavementsaw.org

From:         Tisa Bryant <tisab@EARTHLINK.NET>
Subject:      Re: Stephen Jonas
In-Reply-To:  <a05100308b9894d1e6a8c@[128.101.248.213]>
Mime-version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset="ISO-8859-1"

Many thanks, Maria.

I must say I don't understand Stephen Ellis' "grandly street" bit about
Baraka, either.
What of the Black Mountain and New York School -influenced early poems of
LeRoi Jones, who was as concerned with popular culture (like Frank O'Hara),
the poetic tradition, and linguistic revolution--as his white peers?  The
Jones becoming Baraka who assimilated Marx, Brecht, Heidegger, and Hegel?
The Baraka whose (in this case, in my opinion, unfortunately nationalist)
"street" credibility was hard-earned and included leaving his wife and kids=
?
How is he to be separated from Jonas and his "earnings"?

What's the problem with Jonas' work being in dialogue with that of avowedly
African descended writers?   Taint?  Or it's because he was queer that he
has nothing to do with other "others"?  Baldwin mirrors him in many ways, a=
s
does Samuel Delany, and again, even biracial skinhead would-be terrorist Le=
o
Felton, in terms of the "social milieu" you brought up, but I don't think
we're understanding the implications, problematics, contradictions and
rewards of milieu, skin privilege, ancestry and mythology, and the pressure
of all this on the creative process, in the same way.

Jonas and "racial division" seems to be once again an attempt to divorce
someone who is Black from the ontology of the Blackness, whether s/he
recognized it or not.  In fact Jonas's work does show the influence of Blac=
k
vernacular over and over again.

I was introduced to Jonas by Black poets, repeatedly, starting with my 7
years in the Dark Room Collective (Boston/Cambridge), who were introduced t=
o
him by Black poets, and so on.  So Stephen, your "many" who disregard Jonas
on some "Black content" tip are clearly very different from mine.  Mine are
the very same "many"  who were turned on by Harryette Mullen's work way
before the identifying mark of MUSE & DRUDGE made her a hot commodity on th=
e
color wheel, you know, back when she was supposedly "too white."

To push it, it's not an issue of "skin" color--since I believe Jonas was
very fair-skinned and could pass for white--but of ancestry.  Again, it's
there in Jonas' work. Like I said to Jim, he probably would have turned ove=
r
in his grave, just as Elizabeth Bishop might, given how resistant she was
against appearing in feminist or women's anthologies--let alone lesbian
anthologies. =20

A friend of mine seems to recall that John Ashbery also was against this
once, though he has finally come around.  75 years loving men
should finally convince a person that the label is not toxic, it's others'
reactions to it that are.

We asked each other:  Are we to say that Pushkin, Alexandre Dumas pere et
fils, Machado de Assis, William Stanley Brathwaite, and Frank Yerby, to nam=
e
a few, were NOT Black because they treated other themes in their work?  Wha=
t
about Carl Phillips and Claudia Rankine?  Will Alexander?
Are Mary Renault and Marguerite Yourcenar not lesbians because they only
wrote about homosexual men?

What I think is really interesting that so many people could so quickly
chime in and earn cool points with their one or five suggestions to help
flesh out Kathy Lou short list, but so few could have this conversation.
How is this work being read, taught, discussed?  Independent of the living
bodies, intricate root systems, timeless intellect and ever-present spirit
that went into it?

This madness is exactly how the complexity of our existence and our writing
gets compressed into nothingness, or, at best, ad-seg anthologies.
=20
Stephen, I agree that these racial categories are empty and problematic, bu=
t
as Adrian Piper said, they're all we have, and we have to work with and
through them until we can get rid of them altogether, making questions of
where people "belong" disappear.  Time and time again we're shown that the
time is not now because we're really not doing that work, just countless
work-arounds, the main one being silence (or here in the nethernay,
backchanneling). =20


Tisa

***
I like to think good writing is fetishized and compassionate terrorism.
                  =20
Eurydice
