>chime in and earn cool points with their one or five suggestions to help
>flesh out Kathy Lou short list, but so few could have this conversation.
>How is this work being read, taught, discussed?  Independent of the living
>bodies, intricate root systems, timeless intellect and ever-present spirit
>that went into it?

Cool points? That seems sort of silly to me, Tisa. Someone asks for
suggestions, and people offer the suggestions. The complexities themselves
are enormous and delicious. Rather than look at Jonas, we can look at a
whole weave of history. When I start to discuss this issues, I usually go
to Jay Wright.

In a 1983 Callaloo interview he said, "My reading of history impels me to
think that music, speech and calculation (the measuring of time and event)
have been the complex of relationships in which human spirit, action,
social and political relationships have been most gloriously exemplified. I
realize that asserting this makes literary phenomena seem primary. You
would expect a poet to insist upon literature's central position in human
affairs. We hardly apologize for this insistence any longer. But I should
stop here to say that I include in the speech community all those
practitioners of verbal art who are not normally included: the griot, the
old Testament prophet, the ritual chanter, the fabulist, the legist, the
chronicler, the preacher, even the mathematician, among others. Quite a
list, you say. What's left out? Why, nothing. Not even poetry. Among the
various speech communities, poetry finds its voice, and its unique
functions, which, nevertheless, are like those of other disciplines--the
discovery, explication, interpretation, exploration and transformation of
experience. "

I think this succinctly addresses all the questions that you raise in your
post.

Jay goes on to say, "Poetry is a concentrated, polysemous, literary act
which undertakes the discovery, explication, interpretation, exploration
and transformation of experience. It differs from some other forms of
speech in that it handles its 'facts' with more disdain, if I might put it
that way, insisting upon spiritual resonance. It differs from some other
forms of speech (such as that used by the preacher, the ritual chanter, and
the fabulist) in that it handles its spiritual domain with slightly more
critical detachment than they do. The paradox of the extreme manipulative
consciousness of the two domainsspiritual and materialindeed, their
association to produce what is at least a third and unique domainis what
distinguishes poetry from other forms of speech."
It's unfortunate that Jay won't really do many more interviews nor are
there many to read other than this one and the essay he wrote for Callaloo
in 1986, "Desire's Design, Vision's Resonance: Black Poetry's Ritual and
Historical Voice." Wright believed that "multicultural" is the way of human
development. But what of it? Some people try and pigeon hole others; some
people try to free others. Same old, same old. Should we expect anything
different on good old Buff Po?

>This madness is exactly how the complexity of our existence and our writing
>gets compressed into nothingness, or, at best, ad-seg anthologies.

The flip side to this whole madness deals with commodification. Getting
certain things into certain curricula. For instance, Toni Morrison was
first introduced into Afro-Am curricula before she was taught in "ENGLISH".
It's unfortunate shell game, but it's one that is played. And, it's played
on both side. And, everyone is played. The unfortunate situation is that
those who have certain resources make more money off the game while others
who think they're making out get simultaneously made and taken. This brings
us right back to the compressed nothingness, but it's not nothing.
Someone's making $$. --Ak

>Stephen, I agree that these racial categories are empty and problematic, but
>as Adrian Piper said, they're all we have, and we have to work with and
>through them until we can get rid of them altogether, making questions of
>where people "belong" disappear.  Time and time again we're shown that the
>time is not now because we're really not doing that work, just countless
>work-arounds, the main one being silence (or here in the nethernay,
>backchanneling).
>
>
>Tisa

From:         Jim Andrews <jim@VISPO.COM>
Subject:      Enigma n^2
In-Reply-To:  <E17hjCa-000FE0-00@mail.islandhosting.com>
MIME-version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT

"meaning is what an explanation of meaning explains"
Ludwig Wittgenstein

Enigma n^2 is an audio/visual work of sound/code poetry and interactive/generative music at
http://vispo.com/animisms/enigman2 . Turn the volume up loud. Click around in it or let it be
strange on its own.

It's a new thing related to an interactive visual poem I did in 98 called Enigma n at
http://vispo.com/animisms/enigman/meaning.html .

The basic "material" of both of them is the word "meaning" and poem-sized coding. Enigma n^2
requires Shockwave and speakers. Enigma n requires a version 4+ browser. Enigma n is a
philosophical poetry toy for poets and philosophers from the age of 4 up. Enigma n^2 is a little
vismu machine with its guts hanging out on the 'page'. Both of them attempt to discover some of
the poetical possibilities that programming opens up.

ja
http://vispo.com
http://webartery.com

From:         MWP <mpalmer@JPS.NET>
Subject:      The Meaninglessness of Meaninglessness
In-Reply-To:  <NFBBJIJOOLLMOMMACKAFEELLDHAA.jim@vispo.com>
Mime-version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-transfer-encoding: 7bit

DEATH TO ALL RANDOM NUMBER GENERATORS, FOREIGN & DOMESTIC!!!

Not to implicate anybody in particular, but I find that texts and other
forms of art generated by random algorithms all tend to have a superficial
complexity that fails to offer any further depths upon reappraisal. It is
like discovering faces in a passing cloud, as it mainly depends on one's
level of receptivity to the task of hallucinatorily processing some big
miasmic blob of information that one more or less believes on faith should
be parse-able into meaningful units of some kind.

I know about cut-ups and Cage and stochastics and all that, but I remain
unconvinced that randomness has much to teach us beyond the nature of our
own phantasmagoricamania. Would anybody care to come to its defense in some
interesting new way?

m
=========================================================================
Date:         Thu, 22 Aug 2002 22:30:33 +1200
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         "richard.tylr" <richard.tylr@XTRA.CO.NZ>
Subject:      Re: The Meaninglessness of Meaninglessness
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

I agree to a point but as you probably know when "randomness " is referred
to it means "psuedo randomness": I was interested in using a collaging
method for a work I attempted and I discovered that somehow,whatever I did,
a "pattern"  or "a "rythm of meaningfulness"" emerged (because my mind was
in fact "choosing"despite...): then I considered experimenting with total
randomness (this is still what is called the pseudo random (nothing is
totally random that human's can generate - or at least if such a sysytems is
possible it is truly totally meaningless. But with the text or "poem" I
generated form various texts it was interesting to see what emerged but then
I came to a kind of lacuna: like yourself I found it all a bit futile ..
then I became interested in the way the mind works in the making or creative
process and I think that it must utilise something equivalent to a random
number generator, and the idea of working form the unknown to the known,
that is via process unending....but I_ can_ see one interest in so called
"randomness" especially vis a vis Cage and that is the way infact it in many
ways _enhances _ reality: of course the approach from art to reality and so
on is/has always been problematic. This is different from
"meaninglessness". Pound's Cantos are relatively structured but in the
process of their writing new things were introduced: Zukofsky's "A" I think
was pretty closely structured as so I believe was Ulysses ( but I read
somewhere that Joyce "sprinkled" a whole ot of words from various langauges
into the complex that became Finnegan's Wake (which yet was a highly
pre-planned even preordained and complex work which I've never read!..).
I've read some computer generated poems by Finch and they are interesting
and good that he did them, tried a new thing, but ultimately rather
meaningless: what I find and know is that the trace of the human is
essential in any work: and a poem or text without some raison d'etre,
without emotion, however strange it may seem the "emotion" or reason may
underpin, or be the source of the energy in the work: there will be very few
truly random works. Ashbery's poetry's often seems - I emphasise the
"seems" - "random" but I think he writes in a way that his mind works
"intuitively" but the ideas generated are kind of "gated through the grid of
his intelligence and memory: whereas the grid of some of the language poets
is partly the structure they impose (as  well they also have this "grid" of
the intellct and memory I think) and either the  inherent meaning (sometimes
fragmented etc) or in fact the structure points to WHAT is being said...some
of this applies of courseto "modernist" poetry:maybe all poetry of all
kinds.
     I think Alan Sondheim's work could be an example of the reverse: highly
structured and with a definite modus operandi but as (we mostly see it) it
appears  'random'.....for me a lot of poetry of course works both on the
level of a kind of musical and  - dare I say it - inefable and strange near
meaningless meaning (which is really its meaningfulness!) as it does
approach the condition of music: it needs to succesfully (almost) resist
meaningful interpretation: even some of Auden's poetry which by synbolism or
metaphor means A can mean B to another reader as he frequently uses words in
such original ways: another poet eg Geoffrey Hill has been "explicated" by
Harold Bloom and one admires his attempt and there's a critic (forget his
name  - Hart I think)) whosse book on Hill is excellent but one wonders if
its worth being quite so alert to these complex of meanings: the plot
thickens with (sorry forget the poet who wrote "Changing Light at
Sandhover") ..... I read an analysis of his poem bsaed on the Cupid and
Psyche legend and I'm afraid it was beyond me still even with analysis: but
a very beautiful poem whatever it means and its meaning is in the poetry of
its poetry: the magic: it always is in there in all good or great
poetry...but I can apreciate the beauty of these poets and derive 'meaning'
wihout being able to parse or analyse to deeply what they are "saying" (of
course one always attempts that)....I know an editor who calls all poetry
that is not I suppose "normative" - including eg Bernstein's poetry
"semiotic": but very little poetry is semiotic entirely although semiotic
concepts may influence a poet/writer and in a sense there is always
semiosis.
  But if somthing was either entirely predictable (entropy zero - and zero
information content , as in eg telecommuciations theory) or totally random
(entropy approching infinity I suppose - maximum information content)  But
the trouble is that the  totally random system - with its maximum of
potential 'news' is useless to us: we would need to be God to "understand
it" we're into Borges territory....this is bit of information theory I
remmember and may be completely wrong on it.  Reality, whatever that is,
kicks in: or practicality.
  We can theorise all we like about randomness but somehow we have to be
communicating (however complexly or seemingly disjunctively) some
'meaningfulness: some human kick, some ethic, some life, some love.  Richard
Taylor

> miasmic blob of information that one more or less believes on faith should
> be parse-able into meaningful units of some kind.
>
> I know about cut-ups and Cage and stochastics and all that, but I remain
> unconvinced that randomness has much to teach us beyond the nature of our
> own phantasmagoricamania. Would anybody care to come to its defense in
some
> interesting new way?
>
> m

Date:         Thu, 22 Aug 2002 04:22:57 -0700
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         lewis lacook <llacook@YAHOO.COM>
Subject:      Re: The Meaninglessness of Meaninglessness
In-Reply-To:  <B989F9A4.4ABF%mpalmer@jps.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

There are two common misconceptions in your post here:
1) RANDOMNESS: The computer cannot generate a random number. There's ALWAYS a pattern, whenever Math.random( )--the JavaScript function--is evoked. These numbers are pseudo-random: they look random, but are actually patterned in some way by the machine. I say "some way" because it's not clear to me yet just what pattern the machine uses...but I was assured in Programming 101 that randomness in algorithms is a fallacy.
2) MEANINGLESSNESS: No such thing. There is absolutely no way for human beings to escape meaning. We're little meaning-generating algorithms. What appears at first to be meaningless is simply meaning we're not receptive to yet.

To delve deeper into your objections (which are valid, I believe, despite the misconceptions):
"I find that texts and other
forms of art generated by random algorithms all tend to have a superficial
complexity that fails to offer any further depths upon reappraisal."
If the motion in poetry has steadily been from the depth to the surface, what's wrong with surface complexity? And how differentiate between the surface and the depth in language in the first place?
I think it all depends on what you seek from the poem. If the poem serves to further an ego (the author's or the reader's), then text generation algorithms are not for you. In fact, it's just this egolessness that you may be finding empty in poetry produced by machines.
" I know about cut-ups and Cage and stochastics and all that, but I remain
unconvinced that randomness has much to teach us beyond the nature of our
own phantasmagoricamania"
---or about the thisness of the poem, perhaps? If one sees the poem as a phenonmenon, similar to a sunset or a tree, and doesn't seek reification of ego-concerns in the work, then these texts can prove to be bursting with meaning...in fact, your "surface complexity" is probably nothing more than the anarchy of meaning produced in such works.
Of course, there remains the question of critical standards....
bliss
Lewis LaCook

Date:         Thu, 22 Aug 2002 10:50:00 -0400
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Nick Piombino <npiombino@AAAHAWK.COM>
Subject:      Self-publish or perish
Mime-version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-transfer-encoding: 7bit

> What is troublesome to me in what you are saying is not essentially the
> connection between science and poetry, but the implicit idea of progress. I
> find the concept of progress in art inconceivable; not only between
> historical periods but also among poets of the same period or even, in my
> opinion, among poems of the same poet. In what way is a Coleridge poem
> inferior or superior to a Frank O'hara poem or a Shakespearean sonnet or a
> poem by Whitman or Pope, etc.? One may prefer one over the other; but this is
> a matter of the reader's interests and tastes and also the cultural,
> philosophical assumptions of the age in which the reader lives. Each of these
> poets creates "completion" in his or her own way. Can an O'hara moment
> "improved" upon, can a Whitman poem expanded
(Murat)

I didn't realize that it was Murat's post that inspired my quotations of
Whitman until I reread his post this morning. I guess my unconscious point
was not that a Whitman poem can be expanded upon, but that we could and
should actually try to live up to some of the ideals that he proposed. Of
course I was struck in particular (I had never read this introduction to his
own work by Whitman before) by his suggestion that poets themselves should
be their own "common referee." This is precisely what I have been
envisioning as "progress" (hate that word; I prefer "development" as it is
more local as to to time periods; regression is also an unavoidable aspect
of development) for poetics. Our discussion of self-publishing is crucial to
this issue. One more note on progress in poetry. In one of my essays of
perhaps 20 years ago I wrote something like: "There is no linear development
in poetry, only a process of eroding and building."

I'm troubled to find out that Tom Beckett, who has contributed so much to
contemporary poetics (his collections in his magazine "The Difficulties" of
articles on Charles Bernstein, Susan Howe, Ron Silliman, David Bromige and
others were essential moments, to my way of thinking, in contemporary
poetics,) has never had a major collection published. If this were the only
important issue to be brought out by this thread on self-publishing I feel
the thread would have been of great value. Hopefully, getting this fact out
about Tom's work is a step towards changing this situation.

> Then poems are mainly composed of "information?" That's what you seem to be
> saying or implying. After all "discovery" as something communicable is
> "information." Am I misunderstanding you? I don't think that's what poetry
> mainly does. In your previous post you referred to the "aura" of fragments.
> How do you reconcile these two ideas?
(Murat)

What I was trying to get at here was an attempt to show that the way we
understand and interpret what poems are as objects will determine how we
distribute them. I liked what Tom Beckett said about the "tangle" of poetry
that brings us back to a poem again and again.  I was trying to point out
that we can understand the communicative value of poetry without classifying
the poem object only as a collectible consumer item. By classifying poem
objects this way, we limit their distribution by grouping them with art
rarities. This is of great value to people who make art for money. We will
never make much money out of our poems, lets face it. There are only just so
many of us interested in contemporary poetry. If we utilized not the values
of scientists or even their methods, but looked at our products as
discoveries which urgently need to be shared with other investigative
explorers in the field of poetry, then we might not have the situation where
someone like Tom Beckett has not been adequately heard. This situation is
holding us back as a field and it is holding many of us back, I believe, as
individual poets. The "aura" of fragments idea relates to the notion of
found objects. The widespread use of found material in poetry is indicative,
I have a hunch, of a powerful undercurrent among poets towards cooperative
sharing and a fundamentally more democratic approach. The found item, as
Chris Cheek has pointed out,is an item transformed from the worthless to the
useful; it is universally available, part of an environment we share and are
hopefully learning to value and to refrain from damaging and destroying. The
notion of a found object, as a transitional object,  functions as an
intermediate area within which and by which we can connect with each other
without encroaching on each other or intruding on each other.

> Unless the second artist re-imagines the cut-up process (and makes it his/her
> own), the "technique" itself functions as a cliche, the opposite of
> "progress."
>
> You also imply that a scientific approach to poetry will abolish the cult of
> personality or authority? Is that what happens in science? No heroes? No
> authorities?
(Murat)

I don't think I want to advocate a scientific approach to poetry. But I do
think that the Harold Bloom "Anxiety of Influence" idea, that each hero poet
of each successive period has to "conquer" the oedipal hero of the previous
period points to a severe shortcoming in the way we poets understand our
positions and identities. The hierarchical aspect (that clearly Whitman
takes issue with, as may be seen in his introduction to -Leaves of
Grass-parts of which I posted yesterday) is seriously detrimental to the
self-esteem of poets. I believe that most contemporary poets suffer from
(largely unnecessary) detrimental experiences in self-esteem, anywhere from
minor to severe, a situation that can only be changed by moving forward as a
field, developing as a field, away from hierarchical models based on such
things as practices of identification and hero worship, and towards a more
equable approach, mutually supportive approach, as envisioned by Whitman
(obviously not because Whitman recommended it, but because it makes sense).
Isn't one of the main points of -Leaves of Grass- that poets have something
to be very  proud of, but that this pride should be a shared experience
based on equality?

The cut-up technique is an excellent example of technical advances in the
field of poetry. I agree that to benefit the field as a whole, it has to be
employed in an original way. But to benefit a particular poem it does not.
There is no point in having a standard in this field that every poem has to
be an original contribution to the field. But it is important for the field
to separate technical advances from the activity of hero worship. We could
talk about "The Burroughs" cup-up technique as a technical advance for
poetry. This gives a sense of tribute, and history, without hero worship,
hopefully. I think we could dispose of a lot of social and psychological
difficulties encouraged by our field if we could learn to understand that we
are working together as a field, just as in any other discipline, science or
anything, and try to jettison some of the outdated baggage that keeps
connecting us to the aristocracies and priestly hierarchies of bygone ages.
Of course every field, including science, suffers from competitive attitudes
and propriety attitudes that are destructive.



As so often before, Murat, you have galvanized my thinking; thanks for your
attention and response.

Nick

From:         =?iso-8859-1?q?Barbara=20Thimm?= <barbarathimm@YAHOO.CO.UK>
Subject:      Re: The Meaninglessness of Meaninglessness
In-Reply-To:  <B989F9A4.4ABF%mpalmer@jps.net>

 > Not to implicate anybody in particular, but I find
> that texts and other
> forms of art generated by random algorithms all tend
> to have a superficial
> complexity that fails to offer any further depths
> upon reappraisal.

Hi M.....  a few remarks from someone not familiar
with much theory:

-when you write "forms of art generated by" you are
referring to the *process* by which a work of art is
(allegedly) generated. If you can agree that a work of
art exists only in its perception, i.e. between the
audience/reader/listener and the work of art, the way
it has been generated shouldn't matter much because
'meaning' ultimately emerges in perception.

- However, I recall some instances where the *process*
is intrinsic for its perception, where the process  is
part of the art work: in works by Beuys, for
example..... or other conceptual artists.... where we
have to know about the process (or even watch it) to
gain  further insight regarding the work of art.

- with poetry part of the issue seems to be that words
seem to have acquired 'an objective meaning of their
own' (we have to rely on this some some extent to be
able to communicate) .... as opposed to, e.g., colors
which don't (but then  think of traffic lights ...).
Why do we expect a poem to mean anyhting in a
straightforward sense .... but don't expect it from a
painting?
(I'm dimly aware of Saussure etc.... but am only
slowly coming to relate his findings to my own
practice of poetry)

- sometimes, as for instance with Finch's
computer-generated poems (which are often generated by
repeatedly using a translation program on a text), I
find I'm intrigued by the process: how interesting to
see what translation programs do ... and there are
specks of meaning in the end result. Of course, a
translation program is not random. How can the result
be? is it meaningless?
in this case, the process is intriguing and
interesting. Perhaps also because the author has given
away some authority ... thus granting it to us, the
readers? or to the machine?

Hope this is of some interest ....
B

Date:         Thu, 22 Aug 2002 10:58:27 -0400
Reply-To:     baratier@megsinet.net
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         David Baratier <baratier@MEGSINET.NET>
Organization: Pavement Saw Press
Subject:      Saturday: AN AMERICAN AVANT GARDE: SECOND WAVE SYMPOSIUM
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii; x-mac-type="54455854";
              x-mac-creator="4D4F5353"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Saturday July 27

These write-ups have been spaced out at odd intervals, I started writing
them when we were behind by four tubs of mail and things are about the
same after weeks of work and going to Cleveland, Dayton and Cincinnati
(sincity was the worst featured reading I can ever remember) in the
interim. I've had the disfortune to place myself in an awkward position
where the largest evaluation is saved for last. In the Main Library at
The Ohio State University, specifically room 122, we met in the morning.
Our tribe was the first to arrive and after telling some worthy
librarian jokes to librarians, they thot us harmless enough to enter and
while I set up titles to sell, plenty of pastries and cups coffee were
brought in to the conference room. Without exception, a fine pastry is a
mark of a worthy conference & the chocolate glazed donuts were
especially avant guard.

The first person I saw was mIEKAL aND who was reading material straight
from various web projects he has done. Starting with mezocrostics for
Dick Higgins, after a few minutes, when I realized that a reading from
web pages I was familiar with would be his entire performance, I went
upstairs to hear the competition, which sounded interesting, a paper on
Burroughs, at the library with the largest collection of his work. This
presentation was horrible, there was one primary source, which was
Kostelanetz, and I couldn't decide if he was used because the presenter
was hoping to impress him, or because having five books by the same
author was an easy way to research. I was embarrassed that our wonderful
collection was so under- & mis- represented for the weekend by this
drollery. Especially considering the distance I had traveled between the
two reading spaces, located excruciatingly far from each other, if one
were interested in trying to flit about as I do.

I was unable to tolerate remaining in that same room long enough to hear
a part of William J. Austin's talk, I ran downstairs to hear Ficus
Strangulensis, who had a visual poetry presentation using the overhead
projector. Ficus often moved too fast with his showings, things cranked
by with brief explanation & often before they could be fully
appreciated; but what a show! A brilliant moment in the middle was when
he was doing these poem transformations through handwriting which I had
seen many of, where one word at the top of the page, such as 'poem' is
changed into another, say 'hand' at the bottom of the page, visually
through a gradual downward asemic method. Ficus' threw a wrench in, by
breaking the rule of slight visual letter changes & placing an object in
the center. I could see doing this myself in a fit of laziness, "damn,
this 'a' just doesn't look anything like a 'z.' Screw it, lets draw a
circle in the center."  While this needs to be seen for full
appreciation I hope this description is clear enough for now. I was able
to ask some questions regarding where he got his type from, how,  and
what method he used to catalog such a large amount (by folder & type
size) & other things & I think people were tired of me asking questions
(tho when he was talking about the meaning of whiteness on the page, I
got in a good joke between slides, as the blank screen projected, "oh,
is that what you mean." Unlike other conferences, say when all the
grammarians meet at the MLA or the "creative writers" at AWP, the jokes
were not necessary to keep me interested.

At 10:00 AM Igor Satanovsky did not appear, so Carlos Luis read. This
displacement pissed a bunch of people off since they missed Carlos as a
direct result. I found Luis' use of the computer interesting, even wild
in this time period, he creates visual poems on the computer, but only
as an method of production. Once the 'poem' is finished he prints one
copy then permanently deletes it off the hard drive. I was glad to catch
his work also, it sounded wonderful, tho I didn't understand it since I
do not speak spanish or cuban. Having been raised by a tribe of poets
who could make boxes of macaroni sound good, I felt right at home at the
reading. I had another, albeit different,  pastry which was not nearly
at the forefront of muffinry as the aforesaid donut.

Igor read & while his short readings (see Friday & Sunday reports) were
excellent, this one was tedious because the thought placed behind using
the bullhorn on Friday shifted from fitting the work to being
arbitrarily used as the tool of the man. I was disappointed. The lack of
connection was grating, and as the yelling continued, I slipped out and
went to see Irving Weiss read his translation of Malcolm de Chazal's
Sens-Plastique. I am sure glad I did. Unfamiliar with the original, all
was consistently attention grabbing with moments that were amazing & a
full three minute period where I was lilted & lifted out of the room.
One of the highest points of the conference, the area was a description
of the face in other terms, I wish I had my notebook with me. Irving, if
you could fill me in on when the translation is coming out, & the
publisher, I would greatly appreciate it.

I went downstairs to see Scott Helmes' presentation and stopped by the
book area before the show started. I bought a handmade edition of a Jim
Leftwich book and a gorgeous four color "folio" by Kathy (KS) Ernst
called Plaisir D'Amour. The night before, in trade from mieKAL, I
acquired Sequencing, a card deck that kept me up an extra hour that
night with its visual, electronic circuit looking vizpoems. Also, I was
eyeing a silkscreened vispoem by Marilyn Rosenberg which was wonderful,
probably three foot by four, but, while a steal at $99, was beyond my
financial means. Over the day the most popular sellers seemed to be a
vispo anthology edited by Scott Helmes (co-edited by Grumman?) , which
disappeared before I could get a copy (or record the title), Plaisir
D'Amour by Ernst, Falling in Love Falling in Love with you Syntax by
Sheila Murphy.

Helmes presentation was a two screened slide show with him discussing
various point about the works on the screen. Unlike the other vispo
folks at the show, with the exception of Ernst, Helmes mostly does works
which are serial in nature. Having been first exposed to his work thru a
Zelot/Tansy chapbook from the late 80's, it was nice to see so much
together at once and at a followable pacing due to the two screen
set-up. The fragments of letters pieces I've always liked, where a
template is used to create a new visual reminiscent of a word, that
seems to contain a message, but never quite acquiesces to the page
enough to be understood. These visual remnants of meaning are appealing
to me. He showed a large and intense swatch of his work and afterward I
could form a single question.

With a chant of "follow me, I'm misleading!"  many walked behind us
hoping for lunch, confused from four hours of readings & lectures only
to find themselves five minutes later, on high street, abandoned.

--------------------more, later


Be well

David Baratier, Editor

Pavement Saw Press
PO Box 6291
Columbus OH 43206
USA

http://pavementsaw.org

From:         Tisa Bryant <tisab@EARTHLINK.NET>
Subject:      Re: Stephen Jonas
In-Reply-To:  <5.1.0.14.2.20020821210444.00b2b6c8@mail.verizon.net>

Thanks, Anastasios.

Cool points: I'll admit that comment was coming out of frustration with the
more game-show aspect of this process of research, in spite of the beauty of
community evidenced here at such times.  Surely a quick and effective way to
harvest, to cull, and learn, and I often contribute if I can, but then never
initiate request, as something not silly nags.   Some natural tension
between progress and process, perhaps, struggle necessarily yielding to
ease, legendary/lifelong back break vs. the illusion of fingersnap.   Maybe
I'm just getting old, or my politics need a shift.  My apologies to the
list; I'll figure this out on my own time.  Life is work.  Work is work.

I appreciate your offering Jay Wright's words and work as a touchstone for
understanding.  That was a lengthy quote; you must keep him close at hand.
These times demand we be quick.  I've just moved; my set of Callaloo is with
everything else, in boxes.

In these discussions, I can't say that I start with any one person's work,
save for the line that indoctrinated me into literary life, Clarence Major's
"Total Life Is What We Want."  To look at the weave of history, well, is
there any other way?   We're fortunate so many have done so much.  Ntozake,
Henry Louis Gates, Wahneema Lubiano, Zora Neale Hurston, Gayl Jones with her
treatise on the Third World Novel experiment, more and on and on around the
world.

Wright's thinking does indeed address much of what I've questioned, much of
what I've long believed, addresses the bulk of my own non-traditional
("grandly street") literary education, and more and more still, for years of
learning to come.

I admire the way Wright makes simple the third domain, poetry, as coming
from the domains of the spiritual and material, so then including all artful
speech and speakers, without supplanting written traditions for oral, as
some other folks do, but calling, like Cecil Taylor or Ed Roberson, to Eshu,
to blend and guide voices over and through.   We must be able to call on
something, someone, surely, for confirmation and synthesis, before we can
move on.

My mentioning Harryette Mullen was a way of addressing the both sides of the
full madness: Toni Morrison not being taught in English curriculums for
years; Harryette Mullen being fully ignored in Afro-Am departments until
recently.  Or any number of other examples, or all of Wanda Coleman's
response to being shut out of Black lit functions for critiquing Maya
Angelou, where she chronicles the struggle for a living Black literature,
the payoff, the payback, the playbook.

To pigeon hole, to free...

Thanks again.

***
I like to think good writing is fetishized and compassionate terrorism.

Eurydice

> From: anastasios.kozaitis@VERIZON.NET
> Reply-To: UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
> Date: Wed, 21 Aug 2002 21:20:44 -0400
> To: POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU
> Subject: Re: Stephen Jonas
>
>> What I think is really interesting that so many people could so quickly
>> chime in and earn cool points with their one or five suggestions to help
>> flesh out Kathy Lou short list, but so few could have this conversation.
>> How is this work being read, taught, discussed?  Independent of the living
>> bodies, intricate root systems, timeless intellect and ever-present spirit
>> that went into it?
>
> Cool points? That seems sort of silly to me, Tisa. Someone asks for
> suggestions, and people offer the suggestions. The complexities themselves
> are enormous and delicious. Rather than look at Jonas, we can look at a
> whole weave of history. When I start to discuss this issues, I usually go
> to Jay Wright.
>
> In a 1983 Callaloo interview he said, "My reading of history impels me to
> think that music, speech and calculation (the measuring of time and event)
> have been the complex of relationships in which human spirit, action,
> social and political relationships have been most gloriously exemplified. I
> realize that asserting this makes literary phenomena seem primary. You
> would expect a poet to insist upon literature's central position in human
> affairs. We hardly apologize for this insistence any longer. But I should
> stop here to say that I include in the speech community all those
> practitioners of verbal art who are not normally included: the griot, the
> old Testament prophet, the ritual chanter, the fabulist, the legist, the
> chronicler, the preacher, even the mathematician, among others. Quite a
> list, you say. What's left out? Why, nothing. Not even poetry. Among the
> various speech communities, poetry finds its voice, and its unique
> functions, which, nevertheless, are like those of other disciplines--the
> discovery, explication, interpretation, exploration and transformation of
> experience. "
>
> I think this succinctly addresses all the questions that you raise in your
> post.
>
> Jay goes on to say, "Poetry is a concentrated, polysemous, literary act
> which undertakes the discovery, explication, interpretation, exploration
> and transformation of experience. It differs from some other forms of
> speech in that it handles its 'facts' with more disdain, if I might put it
> that way, insisting upon spiritual resonance. It differs from some other
> forms of speech (such as that used by the preacher, the ritual chanter, and
> the fabulist) in that it handles its spiritual domain with slightly more
> critical detachment than they do. The paradox of the extreme manipulative
> consciousness of the two domainsspiritual and materialindeed, their
> association to produce what is at least a third and unique domainis what
> distinguishes poetry from other forms of speech."
> It's unfortunate that Jay won't really do many more interviews nor are
> there many to read other than this one and the essay he wrote for Callaloo
> in 1986, "Desire's Design, Vision's Resonance: Black Poetry's Ritual and
> Historical Voice." Wright believed that "multicultural" is the way of human
> development. But what of it? Some people try and pigeon hole others; some
> people try to free others. Same old, same old. Should we expect anything
> different on good old Buff Po?
>
>> This madness is exactly how the complexity of our existence and our writing
>> gets compressed into nothingness, or, at best, ad-seg anthologies.
>
> The flip side to this whole madness deals with commodification. Getting
> certain things into certain curricula. For instance, Toni Morrison was
> first introduced into Afro-Am curricula before she was taught in "ENGLISH".
> It's unfortunate shell game, but it's one that is played. And, it's played
> on both side. And, everyone is played. The unfortunate situation is that
> those who have certain resources make more money off the game while others
> who think they're making out get simultaneously made and taken. This brings
> us right back to the compressed nothingness, but it's not nothing.
> Someone's making $$. --Ak
>
>> Stephen, I agree that these racial categories are empty and problematic, but
>> as Adrian Piper said, they're all we have, and we have to work with and
>> through them until we can get rid of them altogether, making questions of
>> where people "belong" disappear.  Time and time again we're shown that the
>> time is not now because we're really not doing that work, just countless
>> work-arounds, the main one being silence (or here in the nethernay,
>> backchanneling).
>>
>>
>> Tisa

At 11:41 AM -0400 8/22/02, Tisa Bryant wrote:
>Thanks, Anastasios.
>
>Cool points: I'll admit that comment was coming out of frustration with the
>more game-show aspect of this process of research, in spite of the beauty of
>community evidenced here at such times.  Surely a quick and effective way to
>harvest, to cull, and learn, and I often contribute if I can, but then never
>initiate request, as something not silly nags.   Some natural tension
>between progress and process, perhaps, struggle necessarily yielding to
>ease, legendary/lifelong back break vs. the illusion of fingersnap.   Maybe
>I'm just getting old, or my politics need a shift.  My apologies to the
>list; I'll figure this out on my own time.  Life is work.  Work is work.
>
>I appreciate your offering Jay Wright's words and work as a touchstone for
>understanding.  That was a lengthy quote; you must keep him close at hand.
>These times demand we be quick.  I've just moved; my set of Callaloo is with
>everything else, in boxes.
>
>In these discussions, I can't say that I start with any one person's work,
>save for the line that indoctrinated me into literary life, Clarence Major's
>"Total Life Is What We Want."  To look at the weave of history, well, is
>there any other way?   We're fortunate so many have done so much.  Ntozake,
>Henry Louis Gates, Wahneema Lubiano, Zora Neale Hurston, Gayl Jones with her
>treatise on the Third World Novel experiment, more and on and on around the
>world.
>
>Wright's thinking does indeed address much of what I've questioned, much of
>what I've long believed, addresses the bulk of my own non-traditional
>("grandly street") literary education, and more and more still, for years of
>learning to come.
>
>I admire the way Wright makes simple the third domain, poetry, as coming
>from the domains of the spiritual and material, so then including all artful
>speech and speakers, without supplanting written traditions for oral, as
>some other folks do, but calling, like Cecil Taylor or Ed Roberson, to Eshu,
>to blend and guide voices over and through.   We must be able to call on
>something, someone, surely, for confirmation and synthesis, before we can
>move on.
>
>My mentioning Harryette Mullen was a way of addressing the both sides of the
>full madness: Toni Morrison not being taught in English curriculums for
>years; Harryette Mullen being fully ignored in Afro-Am departments until
>recently.  Or any number of other examples, or all of Wanda Coleman's
>response to being shut out of Black lit functions for critiquing Maya
>Angelou, where she chronicles the struggle for a living Black literature,
>the payoff, the payback, the playbook.
>
>To pigeon hole, to free...
>
>Thanks again.
>
>***
>I like to think good writing is fetishized and compassionate terrorism.
>
>Eurydice

>>  From: anastasios.kozaitis@VERIZON.NET
>>  Reply-To: UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
>>  Date: Wed, 21 Aug 2002 21:20:44 -0400
>>  To: POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU
>>  Subject: Re: Stephen Jonas
>>
>>>  What I think is really interesting that so many people could so quickly
>>>  chime in and earn cool points with their one or five suggestions to help
>>>  flesh out Kathy Lou short list, but so few could have this conversation.
>>>  How is this work being read, taught, discussed?  Independent of the living
>>>  bodies, intricate root systems, timeless intellect and ever-present spirit
>>>  that went into it?
>>
>>  Cool points? That seems sort of silly to me, Tisa. Someone asks for
>>  suggestions, and people offer the suggestions. The complexities themselves
>>  are enormous and delicious. Rather than look at Jonas, we can look at a
>>  whole weave of history. When I start to discuss this issues, I usually go
>>  to Jay Wright.
>>
>>  In a 1983 Callaloo interview he said, "My reading of history impels me to
>  > think that music, speech and calculation (the measuring of time and event)
>>  have been the complex of relationships in which human spirit, action,
>>  social and political relationships have been most gloriously exemplified. I
>>  realize that asserting this makes literary phenomena seem primary. You
>>  would expect a poet to insist upon literature's central position in human
>>  affairs. We hardly apologize for this insistence any longer. But I should
>>  stop here to say that I include in the speech community all those
>>  practitioners of verbal art who are not normally included: the griot, the
>>  old Testament prophet, the ritual chanter, the fabulist, the legist, the
>>  chronicler, the preacher, even the mathematician, among others. Quite a
>>  list, you say. What's left out? Why, nothing. Not even poetry. Among the
>>  various speech communities, poetry finds its voice, and its unique
>>  functions, which, nevertheless, are like those of other disciplines--the
>>  discovery, explication, interpretation, exploration and transformation of
>>  experience. "
>>
>>  I think this succinctly addresses all the questions that you raise in your
>>  post.
>>
>>  Jay goes on to say, "Poetry is a concentrated, polysemous, literary act
>>  which undertakes the discovery, explication, interpretation, exploration
>>  and transformation of experience. It differs from some other forms of
>>  speech in that it handles its 'facts' with more disdain, if I might put it
>>  that way, insisting upon spiritual resonance. It differs from some other
>>  forms of speech (such as that used by the preacher, the ritual chanter, and
>>  the fabulist) in that it handles its spiritual domain with slightly more
>>  critical detachment than they do. The paradox of the extreme manipulative
>>  consciousness of the two domainsspiritual and materialindeed, their
>>  association to produce what is at least a third and unique domainis what
>>  distinguishes poetry from other forms of speech."
>>  It's unfortunate that Jay won't really do many more interviews nor are
>>  there many to read other than this one and the essay he wrote for Callaloo
>>  in 1986, "Desire's Design, Vision's Resonance: Black Poetry's Ritual and
>>  Historical Voice." Wright believed that "multicultural" is the way of human
>>  development. But what of it? Some people try and pigeon hole others; some
>>  people try to free others. Same old, same old. Should we expect anything
>>  different on good old Buff Po?
>>
>>>  This madness is exactly how the complexity of our existence and our writing
>>>  gets compressed into nothingness, or, at best, ad-seg anthologies.
>>
>>  The flip side to this whole madness deals with commodification. Getting
>>  certain things into certain curricula. For instance, Toni Morrison was
>>  first introduced into Afro-Am curricula before she was taught in "ENGLISH".
>>  It's unfortunate shell game, but it's one that is played. And, it's played
>>  on both side. And, everyone is played. The unfortunate situation is that
>>  those who have certain resources make more money off the game while others
>>  who think they're making out get simultaneously made and taken. This brings
>>  us right back to the compressed nothingness, but it's not nothing.
>>  Someone's making $$. --Ak
>>
>>>  Stephen, I agree that these racial categories are empty and
>>>problematic, but
>>>  as Adrian Piper said, they're all we have, and we have to work with and
>>>  through them until we can get rid of them altogether, making questions of
>>>  where people "belong" disappear.  Time and time again we're shown that the
>>>  time is not now because we're really not doing that work, just countless
>>>  work-arounds, the main one being silence (or here in the nethernay,
>>>  backchanneling).

<html><div style='background-color:'><DIV>
<P>Tisa, I like it that you forward ancestry over appearances.&nbsp; How do you propose to work through the toxicity of label; given that name recognition is increasingly commodity fetish?&nbsp; Are categories really "the only thing we have to work with" in this?&nbsp; Anyway,</P></DIV>
<P>I made the mistake of presuming in Jonas' stead that he might prefer not to be discussed as a practitioner within a group he had certain difficulties identifying with.&nbsp; The work he left behind are obviously rife with associations other than those persons he while alive claimed as&nbsp;influence.&nbsp; Sure, his work is full of The Tradition, and his presence as subject in a conference on same would propably strengthen - and open out&nbsp;- that tradition considerably.</P>
<DIV></DIV>
<P>In the end, all combination is taint, individual to individual - even in likeness, it's between&nbsp;"you" and "not you".&nbsp; But if one's attempting to consolidate a category, these are the first differences to be deflected.&nbsp; Hopefully, a deflection that's temporary, tho since goal in that arena of&nbsp;"setting aside difference"&nbsp;would be to nail conditional similiarities down to&nbsp;category, generic likenesses tend to overshadow individual eccentricities to an unusually high degree.&nbsp; Hopefully</P>
<DIV></DIV>
<P>the work you mention - Jonas' too - is being read and taught without applying it toward canonical staus -&nbsp;whatever that may be - but given the habit of history, there seems real reason to doubt.&nbsp; More like walkarounds than workarounds - but what would the real work be?&nbsp; In the public world, poets (and poetry), like show dogs, have a tendency to seem perhaps a little too fey in style&nbsp;to really "show" <EM>anything</EM>.&nbsp; I suppose</P>
<DIV></DIV>
<P>I'm not addressing the substance of your post, depressing as issues of separation, categorization and/or canonization seem; the ideals of lawful identification and use of anything seem nothing if not slightly ridiculous.&nbsp; One does, tho, have to start somewhere, behaving as if one were something other than underfoot of&nbsp;your standard American provincial mute.<BR><BR></P>
<DIV></DIV>
<DIV></DIV>

>like discovering faces in a passing cloud, as it mainly depends on one's

>miasmic blob of information that one more or less believes on faith should

Reply-To:     parrishka@sympatico.ca
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         parrishka <parrishka@SYMPATICO.CA>
Subject:      Re: The Meaninglessness of Meaninglessness
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1; x-mac-type="54455854";
              x-mac-creator="4D4F5353"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

>

this isn't particularly new, but i can think of no better apology for the use
of randomness, or chance based procedures (and i'm just going to conflate them
here, willy nilly, with no care for precision or real or pseudo-randomness,
cause what we're really talking about is the deliberate disavowal of authorial
control over the production of the text, by any means, yes? pretty sure it
comes down to control in the end. and it's august, and i just don't feel like
being rigorous.) than joan retallack's SECNÀHC GNIKÀT : TAKING CHANCES.
The full text can be found here:
http://epc.buffalo.edu/authors/retallack/taking-chances.html

some choice snippets follow:



I, along with everyone else, work at the intersection of chance and intention.
The selective use of chance procedures merely foregrounds what is at work in
all that we do and experience, whether or not we wish to turn our attention to
it. The results of "chance operations," as Cage liked to call them, are just
that, nothing more, nothing less than a turning of attention toward the
silences that lie beyond the habits, desires, fears of our intentionally
directed eyes and ears. What results from the use of chance procedures may
shock or delight. The light in delight is that of the sheer given. Nature's
processes operating independently of our opinions about them. The stars before
we herd them into constellations. Ah, but don't worry, one needn't forego the
pleasures of constellations to invite chance into the conversation.

The selective foregrounding of chance makes it possible to bring to light and
sound things that are otherwise potently absent or ominous. Perhaps because
we've tended to be uncomfortable with things outside what we take to be the
realm of control, we miss/ignore/deny the circumstantial evidence that chance
is all around us. Hence the silences--feminine, phobic, phallic--wherein lie
unmined energies of chance. Is it primarily fear (biological conservatism) that
has so firmly tied our attention to simple periodicities and regularities, that
has led us hear harmony only in simple color-coordinated chords? Probably,
improbably enough. (It is after all the characteristically chaotic rhythms of
the normal brain that neurophysiologists credit with all our abilities for
complex innovative thought and action.) But it's our ability to operate outside
regularities, that takes us toward the discoveries and enactments of
imagination, the play and invention that we like to identify as the
characteristically human contribution to the fractal intricacies of our
universe. Every now and then an artist gives us the breath-filled resonances of
more complex chords.

</choice snippet>


and i was just looking over some of my students' own writings on their own
poetic processes, and i found a couple of interesting statements. 17 year olds
are pretty focussed on meaning and intentionality, as a rule, but some of them
really groove on random procedures in composition. like this fellow here:

".. Other than that, the words chosen were completely random. I liked that idea
because my life often seems random and chaotic, and every now and then some
sense of order and meaning presents itself. I felt that forming some meaning
and order to almost compltely random word selections would possibly help me
gather insight into life itself. Or, if you entertain a more mathematical
mindset, there is no such thing as complete randomness, only infinitely complex
systems, or algorithms. Since poetry to me either seeks meaning or randomness,
I felt that a fairly random selection of words was legitimate."


katherine parrish

Date:         Thu, 22 Aug 2002 17:37:31 -0700
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         MWP <mpalmer@JPS.NET>
Subject:      Re: The Meaninglessness of Meaninglessness
Comments: To: parrishka@sympatico.ca
In-Reply-To:  <3D65644A.3FA0C3F1@sympatico.ca>
Mime-version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-transfer-encoding: 7bit

Thanks to everybody who took the blow of my opening salvo! I will
collectivize my responses to the various comments and present them here en
masse.

First let me beg to leave the issue of Meaning vs. Meaninglessness aside, as
I don't know if I can get into it without embarking on a marathon debate.

I am quite familiar with how random generators work and what limitations
they have with regard to the modeling of true random events. The fact is,
though, that randomness doesn't have to be entirely "pure" for a process to
be perceived as sufficiently random for one's purposes. (Just look at Las
Vegas!) As long as the statistical spectrum of a random algorithmic process
shows it to be random within its intended context, then for all intents and
purposes, de facto, if not de jure, it is.

"Depth" is the way a good work of art gets richer upon repeated readings or
viewings. That is, by delving more deeply into its structure we come to
grasp the internal connections more acutely and more integratedly. In a
poem, for instance, this might involve seeing how the musicality of the
words interact with their meanings. Such a thing cannot happen in a work of
random-generated pseudo-complexity because it has no depths or integrations
to embrace. It is all surface and no substance.

I fully agree that randomness is a fine and dandy tool for diverting an
artist from well-worn grooves. As long as randomness doesn't get taken for
what it is not, I have no problem with using it as a shock-cutting
self-discombobulator.  But, unfortunately, in part due to the widespread
rise of computer-assisted art, random number processes and their
counterparts have become practically pro forma among self-proclaimedly
"experimental" artists and composers, and even poets, if only because these
processes are so easy to program. You simply apply RND() or FRACTALIZE() to
some dull database sequence and it instantly takes on a new complexity! Wow!
My point is that this approach is the easy way out, and also a dangerous one
because it promises delights it cannot deliver upon except at the most
superficial of levels.

I am not arguing against the general use of random processes in art, but
against their facile misuse. Cage clearly understands this distinction,
which is why his work evades my critique. In a sense I would argue that
grasping the prevalence of randomness in the universe is one of the great
advances of the modern era, and today's art definitely needs to reflect
this. But I would also add the proviso that it should do so in a way that
doesn't sacrifice what art has always been about, even at its most
self-abnegating, which is to give people a rich, multifaceted experience
that deepens upon repeated exposures.

As far as life and everything else is concerned, I am perfectly at peace
philosophically with the role randomness plays in genetic evolution and
other natural forces. Just don't expect me to wait around for a work of art
that only comes into existence after a few million years of arbitrary
growth!

I actually believe that all works of art -- all -- have an integral
component of randomness that helps bring them into being. My dispute here is
only with those artists who use randomness as a crutch to make their work
seem more textured than it really is. To me this is the lesson that lies at
the heart of Mallarme's admonition that one shouldn't be misled into
believing that a mere toss of the dice -- i.e., the embrace of randomness as
such -- is enough to abolish the true quality of chance that arises as the
fundamental residue of the manifold risks artists take in the making of
their work and that people take in the shaping of their lives amidst the
ruin and entropy that is nature's law. By using randomness as a crude tool
for inflating the "complexity" of a work of art one is effectively
cheapening the real effects of randomness upon our basic ontological being,
which is that it can have deadly serious consequences. (But also great
opportunities for beauty!)

Which leads me finally to say what there is to learn in art beyond the
nature of our own solipsistic hallucinatory phantom-states of mind. We learn
what it means to be other, to explore virtual otherscapes that the mind dare
not enter on its own even in reverie. Randomness creates the illusion we
have moved someplace interesting and shocking and new, when in fact it is a
false narcissistic spinning-wheel utopia.

m

This thread reminds me of that famous passage in Leonardo Da Vinci's
notebooks where he speaks of his fascination with a spit stained wall, and of
the images  and beauty he saw there.  Inspiration, meaning, can be found
anywhere.  Having the eyes to recognize the images, the beauty, the patterns
is a whole nother thang.

Tom Beckett

From:         michael ceraolo <ceraolom@YAHOO.COM>
Subject:      poem about joining the listserve
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

A Tale of Two Cities: Twenty-First Century Edition



It was the best of lists;
it was the worst of lists

Two cities
that shared a similar style,
shared a similar climate,
shared a similar culture,
had somehow diverged dramatically

One’s list was mainly a list,
the other’s list was merely one of its many functions

One encouraged the posting of poems,
the other actively discouraged such posting

(except once during a morbid death watch

when poets posted poems about a beloved local poet)

One encouraged discussions about poetics and other topics,
the other did not

(though members were occasionally treated

to ‘mistaken’ mailings meant to be private,

including pathetic pleadings for a job)

Oh well,
to paraphrase Yogi Berra,
if the people don’t want to discuss poetry,
you can’t stop ‘em



Michael Ceraolo

ceraolom@yahoo.com

Date:         Fri, 23 Aug 2002 15:46:55 -0700

From:         jesse glass <ahadada@GOL.COM>
Subject:      Intrigued
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

MWP--someone I should know I guess--intrigues me with the authoritative way
in which he collectivizes his responses.  I really must agree with what he
says--especially given the postings of Alan Sondheim's happy bits to this
list.  Yes, that's exactly what is missing in most computer-generated work:
depth.

However, I would like MWP to give some examples to back up his assertions in
relation to John Cage and his ability to use random processes in a
"non-facile" manner.  Cage virtually gave up traditional composing in the
late 1950s and used random processes in his work for the remainder of his
life.  As a Cage fan, I find some of Cage's radomly-generated works
immensely interesting, and some appear to me to lack that depth that draws
me back to read it or listen to it over and over.  My question I guess is
this: how does one use a random process, or processes over 40 odd years as
an artist and remain "non-facile" in its use?  I do not believe that John
Cage would escape your critique--especially if one is familiar with his
complete body of work.

If by randomness we include fractal forms, then it appears that many artists
have used forms of randomnity as "crutches" in their work.  Of course,
there's Leonardo's famous anecdote about the stained wall, which probably
led to his invention of the sfumato technique--the smoke, or veiling of
intricate detail that graces the backgrounds of most of his paintings-- and
in Japan there's the wonderful scroll of 100 Obake (monsters or ghosts) said
to have been inspired by the fungus on a temple wall.  In addition the
technique of frottage gave Max Ernst the complexity he needed to make some
of his most interesting art, etc. etc.

I find fractal forms "deep" in the sense that when I fly above a coastline
in a jet and I peer down I see more and more connections.  I can say the
same about the complexity (fractal forms) in Durer, in Holbein, in some of
Cage's smoke paintings and in the raku that my Japanese friend fires in the
mountains of Kumamoto.

But what makes the use of random processes by some artists facile, and some
not, because it all seems to be one and the same process available to all
the arts.

Or is the difference to be found not in the arts per se, but in the use of
the computer as a generator of "art"?

Of course, it's this very lack of depth that causes a text, or a visual or
aural work to become boring, and boredom, I believe, is the great sin of
most 20th century (and now 21st c.) art.

Another aspect of this whole issue of computer poetry and art depends on a
certain mass forgetting that seems to be washing through the collective
heads of the young.  These people are encouraged to see the great writers of
the past as museum pieces and hardly relevant to today's new consciousness
in the arts.

There's a Zen saying that goes, When people are hungry and thirsty they will
eat and drink anything.  I believe this is how random, computer-generated
"depthless" texts can come to be called "poetry."

Excuse these final ramblings,

Jesse

From:         "richard.tylr" <richard.tylr@XTRA.CO.NZ>
Subject:      Re: Intrigued  Thoughts from Aotearoa

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"

Jesse etal. I'm in some agreement with MWP but I think we need to know how
exactly we arrive at things that have depth: certain kinds of poets are
more deliberate about what they do: they seem to plan thier entire work.
Others like Pollock seem to rely on spotaneity and certain unconscious
"powers" (although its just that the mid is working at a "deeper" level  and
the 'meaning created is emotional and expressive and so on rather than
conceptual as we know (eg conceptual art or more "deliberate" art) and then
there's eg an artist such as Rebecca Horne who although she plans, she
_says_ at  least,  that she doesnt know why she has two guns that shoot each
other (I saw that exhibit when i visited NY in 1993), and there's also the
question of prosess. Also, as someone said, meaning is everywhere: it is
inherent in the very placing of words: it's virtually impossible to escape
"meaning" ...total randomnes would be wonderfully meaningfully meaningless:
but as MWP knows and others we are normally talking about the psuedo random:
now in telecommunications we used "pseudo random noise generators" for
testing signal to noise ratios and cross over between 4 khz channels: these
are basically diodes or amplifiers that are overdriven and out comes noise:
as has been pointed out that is random enough and so are computer generated
random functions I would imagine so the issue is to what extent is it
meaning full: here we also get into the problem of meaning and the how and
what of meaning...and I think that question has confronted artists and poets
forever: the nature of reality: to what extent we are a part of that
reality, the "distance" the poet/artist adopts, the use of "magic" and so
on. What I know of Derrida is that he very aware of the problematic nature
of 'meaning' but that doesnt excommunicate the fundamental human
"meaningfulness" we all know. The question is also what is depth. Its not
totally a function of the intellection in a work: but there is almost no
writing or art of any value or kind that is meaningless or without depth
(without intelectiona and emotion etc). One way is for the author to be
foreward then bow out then return and then for a multiplex of dialogues to
inter-act ( even Thackeray in "Vanity Fair" or Brecht later and so on): I
"worked on" (or am playing with still in a rather desultory way) a thing I
called "the Infinite Poem" which began by utilising  near random collage etc
but  I found that I couldnt avoid meaning or even a kind of vestigial
narrative or trace of a narrative i found in a work that began utilising the
random selections of different texts and juxtaposing them but then I decided
that I would let this "poem" become a process (as I had read  about Beuys
and some conceptual art by then, and about such as Louise Bourgeois - who is
not a conceptual artist per se but who work from the idea of certain trauma
in her childhood and her life's devolpment and so on))and
Boltanksi and others) and as time past became also interested in Cage and
even Charles Ives: who'se father detuned pianos before Cage and I also liked
seeing examples of the many drafts of a work: I prefer seeing all those to
seeing a completed work, and initially (and still somewhat) I was attracted
to the idea of (deliberate or not) imperfectness - sloppiness even.  That
anything could come into the "work"  which became a paradigm or analogue or
whatever of life itself....but in my intial work there were things that I a
had "generated" in between the the "found" texts: the next step is/maybe
will be to allow anything and everyone into the "project" and for it to
become "self-generating" (so that "contributors are selected by ballot
rather than on "merit" and I bow out so to speak or not) ...but pardoxically
I still reserve the right to write semi-normative and "perfect" poems (if I
can ever be bothered or get passionate enough to want to ...) which may or
may ot be "subsumed" into the text or whatever it is.

Alan Sondheim's work is a large and quite structured and philosophic/poetic
project and whatever one thinks of it his poems he sends are part of that
and not random as they seem (they often seem chaotic as they come on the
list)...but there's something here (I dont mean specifically in Alan's work)
( I mean in this question of the random as the mind I think utilises some
form of random as well as "structured" scanning into its own memory) that
reflects the way the mind actually works increating eg a "logical
thought"(and in dreams we get a kind of dream illogic logic)...what is the
process that leads to the thought's thought and if we call that state say E,
the what '[multiplied by (r acting on E creates E? where r is whatever
initiates the proces leading to the formulation of E or parts of E)]  So a
thought "completed" (as we perceive it  this term is dubious) might be
represented
by a formula such as:

     completed thought = a multiplied by E or     c. t.  becomes a function
of  some function of a.E where a is the thought's thought's thought and so
on....

This is where philosophy, psychology, neurology, mathematics and other
disciplines converge on or have relevance to poetics or "poetry" or art
whatever poetry is.

But regardless of philosophy: poetry or art, if it is to be of signal value,
must have the fundamental human emotional, psychological, and ontological
concerns: however complex or random or disjunct we become. And of course
things can be rich,strange, and beautiful even if created (apparently) by
random processes: so you all have permission to be as playful or random or
deep or shallow or kitschy or planned or absorbtive or antiabsorbptive or
mysterous or confessional or simple or obscure or "good" or "bad" or tinkly
or motile or as strangley and pulsingly visual frightening calming exciting
boring devastating repetitive formal unformal insane or wonderful woody
word-centred slef-indulgent narcissistic self-sacrificing bland jittery
amazed truculent devious or childlike as  you like!

None of which adresses the question of why approximately 24000 people are
dying from the direct and indirect effects of poverty every day.(UN report
cited by John Pilger). but poetry may do nothing or not but it doesnt kill
people - asfar as I know.)

Regards, Richard Taylor  (Aotearoa)

Im always fascinated by people's blanket condemnation of process.  It seems to
me what you say could be applied to literally any writing convention, cut-ups,
automatic writing, haiku, sonnets, concrete poetry, xerox art.  In many ways
they operate as a preset, & a certain percentage of creators will mark new
territory & extend the form & most will only enact a static & predictable
versioning of the preset.

mIEKAL



MWP wrote:

>
> I am not arguing against the general use of random processes in art, but
> against their facile misuse.

form is emptiness...emptiness is form...

--- jesse glass <ahadada@GOL.COM> wrote:
> MWP--someone I should know I guess--intrigues me
> with the authoritative way
> in which he collectivizes his responses.  I really
> must agree with what he
> says--especially given the postings of Alan
> Sondheim's happy bits to this
> list.  Yes, that's exactly what is missing in most
> computer-generated work:
> depth.
>
> However, I would like MWP to give some examples to
> back up his assertions in
> relation to John Cage and his ability to use random
> processes in a
> "non-facile" manner.  Cage virtually gave up
> traditional composing in the
> late 1950s and used random processes in his work for
> the remainder of his
> life.  As a Cage fan, I find some of Cage's
> radomly-generated works
> immensely interesting, and some appear to me to lack
> that depth that draws
> me back to read it or listen to it over and over.
> My question I guess is
> this: how does one use a random process, or
> processes over 40 odd years as
> an artist and remain "non-facile" in its use?  I do
> not believe that John
> Cage would escape your critique--especially if one
> is familiar with his
> complete body of work.
>
> If by randomness we include fractal forms, then it
> appears that many artists
> have used forms of randomnity as "crutches" in their
> work.  Of course,
> there's Leonardo's famous anecdote about the stained
> wall, which probably
> led to his invention of the sfumato technique--the
> smoke, or veiling of
> intricate detail that graces the backgrounds of most
> of his paintings-- and
> in Japan there's the wonderful scroll of 100 Obake
> (monsters or ghosts) said
> to have been inspired by the fungus on a temple
> wall.  In addition the
> technique of frottage gave Max Ernst the complexity
> he needed to make some
> of his most interesting art, etc. etc.
>
> I find fractal forms "deep" in the sense that when I
> fly above a coastline
> in a jet and I peer down I see more and more
> connections.  I can say the
> same about the complexity (fractal forms) in Durer,
> in Holbein, in some of
> Cage's smoke paintings and in the raku that my
> Japanese friend fires in the
> mountains of Kumamoto.
>
> But what makes the use of random processes by some
> artists facile, and some
> not, because it all seems to be one and the same
> process available to all
> the arts.
>
> Or is the difference to be found not in the arts per
> se, but in the use of
> the computer as a generator of "art"?
>
> Of course, it's this very lack of depth that causes
> a text, or a visual or
> aural work to become boring, and boredom, I believe,
> is the great sin of
> most 20th century (and now 21st c.) art.
>
> Another aspect of this whole issue of computer
> poetry and art depends on a
> certain mass forgetting that seems to be washing
> through the collective
> heads of the young.  These people are encouraged to
> see the great writers of
> the past as museum pieces and hardly relevant to
> today's new consciousness
> in the arts.
>
> There's a Zen saying that goes, When people are
> hungry and thirsty they will
> eat and drink anything.  I believe this is how
> random, computer-generated
> "depthless" texts can come to be called "poetry."
>
> Excuse these final ramblings,
>
> Jesse

I have two poems about basketball.  I'm not sure how old you are, so
Dawkins and his Clinton-like (George, that is) may not be familiar.  Here
is a link to one on Shaq that was in canwehaveourballback?  And, below on
Dawkins.

http://www.canwehaveourballback.com/9gallagher.htm

The Legend of Lovetron

In a place
pretending to be
Kansas City:

Darryl Dawkins
knocked over
Bill Robinzine

like a bulldozer
clearing
a few small rocks.

He hoisted himself
into the air, became
a wrecking ball

then descended
into a dunk.
Shattered backboard.

Robinzine did
The Scream,
covered his face,

and shards of glass
reigned over him.
He ran.

What do
you call that
Mr. Dawkins?

“Chocolate thunder flyin’
Robinzine cryin’
teeth shakin’

glass breakin’
rump roastin’
bun toastin’

Wham bam
Glass breaka I am
Jam!”
Sweep.

>>> ceraolom@YAHOO.COM 08/23/02 11:08 AM >>>
A Tale of Two Cities: Twenty-First Century Edition



It was the best of lists;
it was the worst of lists

Two cities
that shared a similar style,
shared a similar climate,
shared a similar culture,
had somehow diverged dramatically

One's list was mainly a list,
the other's list was merely one of its many functions

One encouraged the posting of poems,
the other actively discouraged such posting

(except once during a morbid death watch

when poets posted poems about a beloved local poet)

One encouraged discussions about poetics and other topics,
the other did not

(though members were occasionally treated

to 'mistaken' mailings meant to be private,

including pathetic pleadings for a job)

Oh well,
to paraphrase Yogi Berra,
if the people don't want to discuss poetry,
you can't stop 'em



Michael Ceraolo

ceraolom@yahoo.com
