Date:         Fri, 23 Aug 2002 14:31:07 -0500
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Thomas Bell <trbell@COMCAST.NET>
Subject:      Re: Intrigued
MIME-version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT

I agree depth is missing in the work so far but the 'depth' comes from the
process and relation of artist to procedure.  I try and get to this in my
review of Loss' book here but I'm not sure how successfully I get the point
across?
Loss Pequen~o Glazier.  Digital Poetics: The Making of E-Poetries.
Tuscaloosa, The University of Alabama Press, 2002.

If you want to be an e-poet, you need this book.  If you want to know about
the development of e-poetry you should read this book.  And if you want a
poet's perspective on implements (software, systems, and code) used to make
the e-poetry that is being done on the internet today  this book will help
you think through and develop your own working philosophy or  poetics.  It
will also lead you to get on with the job at hand or, more precisely, on
your monitor.

Loss Glazier is the  Director of the Electronic Poetry Center of the State
University of New York at Buffalo http://epc.buffalo.edu/  (arguably the
premier site or home for poetry today) and so speaks with some authority.
But here he speaks as an involved poet and as the kind of teacher who gives
you sources and a working philosophy against which  you can develop your own
way of doing e-poetry.  Here are sources, tools, and some sound ideas, so go
out onto the internet and do it.

This book may present difficulties for some readers since Glazier addresses
the confluence of two contemporary cultural streams:  the potential the
internet has opened up for world experimental art and artists; and poetry as
it is increasingly practiced today.  These streams don't converge in a
simple fashion in the real world but rather interact on a number of levels.
However, Glazier has found a mechanism to center on the cutting edge of
interest in the current in both streams through use of sidebars (a mechanism
grounded in hypertext and information retrieval sources).   His sidebars
stem from "techne" which aptly enough has roots in both art and technology.
Like internet links, techne can send one back through history or out onto an
information lode.   The book is not to be read as a cover-to-cover thesis
but as a sourcebook to keep at hand should something jar and one feels a
need for exploring an information avenue: one can techne,  jump, or link
intellectually here even if not virtually via  the internet.  Not as easy as
navigating the net,  but close.

Adapting technology to art is one of the streams this book explores and it
should be emphasized that the approach is one of adapting tools to art, in
the tradition of Cayley and Rosenberg, rather than the all-too-common
approach which seeks to adapt art and poetry to the latest technology.  With
the poet in his or her appropriate place as user of an implement to create,
you are ready to begin.  Beyond a computer and an internet connection you
need some history, some internet geography and knowledge of the unique tools
available out there for you to use: codes and hypertext have proven
themselves capable of expressing more than just words on the page or in a
book.

 In this rapidly changing environment it's obvious that you will never know
all you need to know and there will always be unendable disagreements about
which code or piece of software is best, but Glazier manages to furnish a
handhold and perspective to get you started writing or e-poeting - don't
quibble over the term here, just do it.    While this is not a handbook on a
specific technology or a textbook on learning a specific computer language,
he does furnish enough basics and a glossary so that you can learn to grep
with the best.  With the basics you are adequately equipped, I feel, to use
any language or piece of technology in the process of writing poetry.  As
Ron Silliman said "Larger productions, such as poems, are like completed
machines.  Any individual sentence might be a piston.  It will not get you
down the road by itself, but you could not move the vehicle without it (from
The New Sentence as quoted by Glazier)."

This talk of vehicles might seem to hearken bark to the Futurists and their
dead-end fascination with machinery (or computers in this case) but rather
leads to the works Russian branch of Futurism and to other pieces, such as
Apollinaire's "Il Pleut" where letters come "ALIVE" as Glazier points out.
Poetry is not about machines but poetry is a machine to be used by a poet to
do wondrous things with motion for Apollinaire and Glazier, sound for Dmitry
Bulatov, computer games for Jim Andrews, holopoetry for Eduardo Kac, code
for Ted Warnell, while for me it is a process to explore the visual,
visceral, and  gestural.  This is the second stream of the book where the
emphasis is on 'art' and 'poetry' in the process or making.

This is experimental poetry as it is practiced today, in conditional space -
the as-if space where the poet uses his tools in the encounter with the
world as he or she sees it on the page, on the internet, or in the world.
While avant garde or experimental approaches to poetry have been present for
about a century (and actually go back to it's roots) it is only recently
that they have been adopted by the mainstream academy in the United States.
This 'new' poetry which, if it is new, could be called post-post modern,
language poetry, or "acadominant" as it was recently called on the POETICS
list (http://epc.buffalo.edu/poetics/welcome.html), emphasizes the poem's
materiality; may seem disjointed to those schooled in traditional poetic
forms' and may seem 'tentative' as it does question where science,
rationality, assertiveness, etc., have landed civilization.

Attention to process is a way of dealing with the technology of computing
and the internet for Glazier here just as it can be a way for us to deal
with the technology of our world.  At the same time it is a way of moving
beyond the often crushing (of self as well as others) demands of the
subjective "I" which with its excesses has led to many of the vicissitudes
of contemporary culture.  These two statements are obviously replete with
psychological and poetic arguments and counterarguments which space here
doesn't allow, but a look at procedure begun by an 'ego' might make this
point clearer.  Procedure is a poem generated electronically through code or
by a machine or monkey and there is obviously no ego "doing" it.  But this
procedure was set in motion by a human computer, machine-operator, or animal
trainer.  One could attend to the procedure or the operator, but as Glazier
and others have shown one can also attend to the process at play between the
two and it is this "play" that is what is of interest.

In this fashion Glazier's centering on process in both these streams gives a
way for the reader to go to work by directing attention to the processes of
poetry, of navigating the internet, and of computing.  This is the step
computing and constructing and navigating the internet can take toward a
second Gutenberg revolution.  The process of e-poetry introduces the reader
to both the "electronic" and the "poetry" in electronic poetry as they are
practiced today and hopefully will be in the years to come as the electronic
world is truly (after some recent false starts) poised to overwhelm the
print world.  We are back to Glazier's starting point: Federico Garcia Lorca
's In Search of Duende,  "Behind those black sounds, tenderly and
intimately, live zephyrs, ants, volcanoes, and the huge night straining its
waist against the Milky Way."

tom bell

For every action there is an equal and opposite reaction. If that's true,
then the person who love and hate Alan's work would represent the equal and
opposite reactions. Those with milder opinions would sit on the continuum
between the two extremes. Two equally intelligent people can justify
opposing opinions equally well. I believe it ultimately comes down to taste,
but that the differing evaluations can deepen our insight into what we think
the author is or isn't doing.

Vernon

> well now here's an old problem for you:  i find that sondheim's work
> does have "depth," and that encountering his work has been one of the
> most exciting and rewarding things about being on the list. so  what
> does this mean, that 2 people with some knowledge of and respect for
> poetry and poetics have such different responses to the same work?
> is one of us "wrong," or is the old saw true that "taste" is not
> worth arguing about? which gets us back to the question of the
> utility of "evaluative criticism" that was such a hot topic a couple
> of months ago.
> --
>

One of France's biggest daily newspapers, Libération, just published a solid
piece on the demise of Black Sparrow Press in its weekly Literature
supplement. For those who can read French & want to check it out, the link
is below. Libé obviously comes to BS via the Buk, but still, this is rare --
has anyone seen a piece on BS's demise in the US national Press?

Libé often does unexpected things (at least one wouldn't expect them this
side of the Atlantic). My favorite is (yellowing now in front opf me pinned
to the wall) their issue on the day Burroughs died, which sported a front
cover filled with a photo of WSB taking aim with a winchester, with the
caption reading:WILLIAM BURROUGHS DECROCHE  which could rtanslate as
BURROUGHS KICKS THE BUCKET_

From:         Alan Sondheim <sondheim@PANIX.COM>
Subject:      random
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

for what it's worth, I very rarely use random processes and everything is
reworked

I don't know Jesse Glass but in relation to my work he's absolutely blind

there's nothing right and wrong with random per se - why rehash this

most poetry is boring anywhere and most poetry is meaningless; look at its
huge audience

whatever one wants to do is fine - why worry about categories

and most of anything has no depth

i would say my own work has depth if nothing else and possibly nothing
else

however you define 'depth' - i would say something out of the deep sea;
anglerfish

alan

Older at http://lists.village.virginia.edu/~spoons/internet_txt.html
Trace Projects at http://trace.ntu.ac.uk/writers/sondheim/index.htm
CDROM of collected work 1994-2002 available: write sondheim@panix.com

Subject:      HOOPS -- POLITICS OF THE SNEAKER PIMPS -- PUBLIC ENEMY
Mime-Version: 1.0

Politics of the Sneaker Pimps

On the outs I lace up, the world I face up
To score on anybody, its war on everybody
The new guys come in blood shot between the eyes
As long as their sellin that merchandise
And one what goes in don't come back
The color may be green but its also black
And red I know many heads that spent bloodshed
Cursed in converses, dead in Pro Keds
Now every Tom, Dick, Harry or Joe Smith
Skip the spauldings, pony's, and k-swiss
High school and college coaches gettin
Kickbacks from scholarships and them slave ships
Hey Dr. J where you got those moves
Was it gettin high in the schools
Can it be the shoes?
Truth is truth, I tear the fuckin roof off the house
Expose them foes with my mouth
I see corporate hands up in foreign lands
With the man behind the man gettin paid behind the man
I hold the rocket stop the hand in my pocket
200 a pair but I'm addicted to the gear
They'll make me do things on the court to amaze ya
I heard they make em for a buck 8 in Asia
They came a long way baby since
Clyde Frazier had pumas, pullin mad consumers
Them Filas I'm feelin but I cant touch the ceiling
Them New Balance hits 120 million
The last thing I need is Adidas terminatin my contract
For wearing those old pair of wack
Reebok low tops covered up by floppy socks
Gave me a jump shot before I got jumped and shot
Duckin a word from my sponsor
Trying to end my year like Kwaanza
Been paid since the 8th grade
11th grader, pop the champagne
12th grade start the campaign
Gettin fame sign my name in the dotted frame
Nike got me pullin re's and g's
Shit, I can get shot for these
Please god give me 20 more years on these knees
To maintain without this game I gotta do keys
And I don't wanna go there because its fuckin everywhere
Factories wanna be me kids wanna see me
Behind the wheels and endorsement deals
Its the politics and the tricks behind the kicks

PUBLIC ENEMY

Super Agent...He Is What He Is

Sold / black gold
One strong buck
To the Milwaukee Bucks
For a million bucks
Just get em off the street
So he don't get bucked
Super agent to rescue
So he won't get fucked
Ya run nigger run
To the auction block
But you can't pledge alliegance
To the block
This buck right here
The right kind a stock
For sale for passin
The right kind a rock
Auctioneer stern to massa falk
Can a nigga go home
Where he used to walk
Come back but super agent
Said you can't talk
I didn't know basketball had a balk
The buck run laps
While they run craniums
Players be drainin em
Owners be claimin em
Super agents framin em
Then nicknamin em
Tra win their ass
To be packin them stadiums
In the players ear
Word for word verbatim
Super agent got em locked
Coaches be hatin em
Super agent wouldn't even
Come in my hood
If I had no skills
Was wack and no good
In my neck of the woods
The leagues concrete
And one can only dream about wood
Yeah deal the grade
Let the bills get paid
Pay respect to the projects
And the half-court rejects
Scholarship save that college
Shit
Them championships
Don't pay for the head trips Fuck the trophy
Find the loot
Then approach me
Land of milk and honey
Can I get a quickness
To the money
Or a witness four ______ years
I ain't wit this
Hell with the NCAA ____ / because
My super agents paid
With his dollars I can buy a fuckin college
Miss the rah rah campuses
And keep the school buses
Lookin who's lovin ya
Goin for the jugular
They know they can't
Contain me on the regular
Pimps, pushers
Pocketbook guzzler
Would you pardon my father
Mr. Governor
Thought he had it made
Dreamin about a trade
The thanks we get
Put the roof on this bitch
Dark side of the room
When he jumped the broom
Super agent got this player
Nine-figure wages
Back of sports pages
Off ghetto stages
Shootin sleepin pills
And runnin to the hills
Starmaker makin stars
Hockin burgers and cars
Superstar
How you get to where you are CHORUS
Chillin off the court
See the nigga got bought
Got kicked out the sport
Unseen hand made em
Kiss the ass of the man
One cursed the flag
Everybody ran
Super agent where are you now?
Have you found another brother
To be your cow
Cause you fumbled my shit
And dropped the ball
You won't even answer my call Bridge
Can I get a chance
If I don't sing or dance
Write about romance
Or wear short pants
So I rave and rant
You can't say I can't
Get my grants
Col chillin in a B Boy stance

--PUBLIC ENEMY

Date:         Fri, 23 Aug 2002 16:42:22 -0500

From:         Chicago Review <chicago-review@UCHICAGO.EDU>
Subject:      "New Writing in German"
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1" ; format="flowed"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

-CR- is pleased to announce
the publication of

-Chicago Review- 48:3/4
"NEW WRITING IN GERMAN"

This 360-page double issue brings together more than fifty
German-language writers, particularly those who have emerged
since 1989 and those not well-represented in English translation.

Select contributors include: Marcel Beyer, Ulrike Draesner,
Jenny Erpenbeck, Gerhard Falkner, Durs Gruenbein, Judith Hermann,
Thomas Kling, Terezia Mora, Raoul Schrott, Ruth Schweikert, Alissa
Walser, Lutz Seiler, and Peter Waterhouse. (A full list of contribs
is available at http://humanities.uchicago.edu/review -- follow
the "forthcoming" link.)

The 1990s were marked by a range of new directions in
German-language poetry and prose, wch the editors have surveyed
in their critical introduction. That introduction also includes a
brief account of their principles of selection:

"Our points of departure were quite simple. We wanted to include
as many interesting poets as we could find from the last fifteen years
or so, along with several older, significant, and underrecognized
'big guns.' For prose fiction, a considerably broader and denser field,
our approach has been diagnostic and investigative: to see who right
now and in the past decade may be considered heirs of the 'grand
signeurs' of postwar German literature."

This issue is available from yr local bookseller (keep yr eye peeled
for the orange cover!), from SPD, and from -CR- directly -- see below
for our specially discounted subscription rate for Poetics list members.

* * * * * *

GERMAN PRESS RESPONSES TO "NEW WRITING IN GERMAN"

Across the Pond
An American Anthology of Contemporary German Literature

How do you translate "Schlappschwanzliteratur" -- the phrase Maxim=20
Biller concocted to annoy his fellow writers -- into English? Chicago=20
Review's quite plausible suggestion is "wanker literature." The=20
journal has just put out a double issue devoted to (mostly recent)=20
contemporary German-language writing, titled "New Writing in German"=20
(Chicago Review 48:2/3, Summer 2002). In their introduction, the=20
publishers of this intelligently composed anthology take stock of=20
concepts provided by recent German criticism ("Pop literature," "the=20
new narrativity," "Das Fr=E4uleinwunder," and "multicultural=20
literature"), but fortunately they give preference to a laconically=20
alphabetical ordering of the volume's contents, which, we were glad=20
to see, are divided equally between the rubrics of poetry (from=20
Juergen Becker to Thomas Kling and Peter Waterhouse) and fiction=20
(from Marcel Beyer to Ingo Schulze and Feridun Zaimoglu).

Well-known translators, including Christopher Middleton and Rosmarie=20
Waldrop, have made sure that many of the texts find a second home in=20
America. The anthology -- which leaves out Enzensberger and Grass,=20
but for that includes Mayr=F6cker and Pastior -- is available in this=20
country as well, at the Literarisches Colloquium Berlin, Am=20
Sandwerder 5, 14109 Berlin (www.lcb.de), for a paltry 15 Euro. lmue.

(Sueddeutsche Zeitung, 6.25.2002)

* * * *

New Writing: From German in English

The literary journal Chicago Review has brought out a volume titled=20
"New Writing in German" representing poetry and prose by younger (as=20
well as older) German authors in English translation. Now for the=20
first time, interested readers have the opportunity to get to know=20
the diversity of contemporary German literature, and not just more of=20
the same. In Germany, the 300+ pages-thick volume can be obtained for=20
15 Euro through the Literarisches Colloquium Berlin, Am Sandwerder 5,=20
14109 Berlin.

212/1000 character essay


heaven earth black yellow :: is black, the cosmos are vast a desolate
wasteland sun fills moon sets in west it's dusk from 7 to 9 morning
constellations line up measure word, they spread out cold comes heat goes
autumn harvesting winter hiding, concealing intercalary timing leftover
residue becomes one tenth measurement of years so lu bamboo pitches shift
position open clouds ascend, galloping, sending rain dew forms becoming
frost gold gives birth beautiful water jade emanates Kun mountain summit
double-edged dagger furiously named huge gate-tower pearl called light
darkness treasure fruit plum apple many vegetables mustard ginger sea
salted rivers fresh fishscales hidden depths feathers circling above fire
dragon emperor teaching phoenix royal official men beginning making
writing characters then uniforms, wearing robes clothing skirts expel
throne yield country yao tang has predicted console people strike down
guilty hold boundary talk and test with scalding trying case at court
query way bequeath bow doubting sections love raise hosts leaders minister
prostrate army barbarians near far reality ration guest returning cries
white colt grazes there change covers grass weeds (vegetation) trust
attain myriad (10,000) directions (square) [...] four great five name
stands cause evil breathing public rectification fit dwell leisure ch'in
4-stringed instrument good wonderful question or problem gate as well

Date:         Fri, 23 Aug 2002 21:39:28 -0700
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Jim Andrews <jim@VISPO.COM>
Subject:      Re: The Meaninglessness of Meaninglessness
In-Reply-To:  <E17iS8A-000Brx-00@mail.islandhosting.com>
MIME-version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT

> > > Im always fascinated by people's blanket condemnation of process.  It seems to
> > > me what you say could be applied to literally any writing convention, cut-ups,
> > > automatic writing, haiku, sonnets, concrete poetry, xerox art.  In many ways
> > > they operate as a preset, & a certain percentage of creators will mark new
> > > territory & extend the form & most will only enact a static & predictable
> > > versioning of the preset.
> > >
> > > mIEKAL

Yes, it seems to me also that it's a question of what aspects of the work the artist permits
randomness to operate on, and the particular nature of the selection process within which the
random is operative. Rather than a "blanket" question of whether random process is desirable or
not.

For instance, in generative music, the process of selection is usually quite structured,
particularly if the music is rhythmic, even if there is randomness within the structured
selection process.

Some works involving random selection/generation:
http://vispo.com/animisms/enigman2
http://vispo.com/animisms/enigman/meaning.html
http://vispo.com/animisms/SeattleDrift.html
http://vispo.com/arteroids

In some of these, you will probably be able to spot the random elements without looking at the
source code. In others, you would probably have to look at the code. In these four pieces, the
random process is prominent only in the first. It's my first try at, um, generative music/sound
poetry.

It is also possible to 'weight' the randomness in certain directions, ie, load the probabilities
in certain directions while not eliminating the random altogether.

Randomness does not provide depth. It provides variability of whatever particular element is
randomized. This variability may contribute to 'depth' in certain ways, but depth and
variability are not even remotely the same thing.

ja

Date:         Sat, 24 Aug 2002 17:14:31 -0700

From:         jesse glass <ahadada@GOL.COM>

<!--StartFragment-->
I don't know Jesse Glass but in relation to my work he's absolutely blind.
I would extend that to most of what I see on the computer screen--I'm
wearing triple-strength bifocals now.  I recognize a factory when I see it,
though, and that is what I really object to.  Your work is typical, but your
process of "publication" is what bothers me most.  Factories are no fun for
the people who are forced to work at the end of the line.  On the other hand
they must be real ego trips for the owners.  You've set yourself up as a
factory Alan, and you are ramming your products down the collective throats
of this list.  You are colonizing my hard-drive, with no apologies.  When I
signed up to this list in 1998 I did not sign up to the Alan Sondheim list.
I signed on to the Poetics list.  Sondheim does not equal poetics.  You are
taking advantage of a great forum and if everyone posted their limit every
day for the next year they could not catch up with your excessive postings.
If this were an edited forum, or an e-magazine you would be forced to find
other venues, but as it is we have hot and cold running Alan, and I
absolutely think it's wrong.

Why do you post so much?  It must be ego.  Why don't you remove your name
from your postings for awhile so that we can all see just how unique your
work is.  Or, better yet, why don't you try something new.  I disagree with
Tom Bell when he calls computer work cutting edge.  As it stands right now
it does not matter how much you augment your capabilities via computer, if
you haven't got talent to begin with it doesn't matter how many rams you've
got.  You'll just produce a yawn.  But as it is, Alan did say something
correct and I congratulate him for it.  It's not often that the directors of
big corporations address those who are not expected to complain.   Jesse

For those who missed it in its first (Temple University Press, 1993)
incarnation, here is the new, Exact Change edition (first copies just
delivered to my door by UPS) of:

PPPPPP: Poems Performance Pieces Proses Plays Poetics
by Kurt Schwitters
Edited and translated by Jerome Rothenberg and Pierre Joris
$15.95
ISBN 1-978972-35-9

from the back cover:

"The Trojan war cannot have been as full of incident as one day in
Schwitters' life. When he was not writing poetry, he was pasting up
collages. When he was not pasting up, he was building his column, washing
his feet in the ssame water as his guinea pigs, warming his paste-pot in the
bed, feeding the tortoise in the rarely used bathtub, declaiming, drawing,
printing... and in the midst of all this he never forgot, wherever he went,
to pick up discarded rubbish and store it in his pockets." -- Hans Richter

here are few small excerpts to whet the appetites:


UNSTUPID

So hear glant scream pained Morea
Mamauer gleam dislarned thou I sing
Shrill glowteth glant équalte fine
Like wheel axles scream to scream
Embers paineth bodyhot dislarned shine
O hear! I dislarneth painéd pains.
        Seeyoo Sibeelee splashes the moon
        O see you, o sing along;
        Sibeelee goldens Glotea.
But Paain Dream throttles my sing.


WORKER SONG

Workingman
C-sharp D
Workingman
Foreman
Shifts power
Foreman shifts power
Shifts C-sharp D
Foreman
Powerman
Forepower C-sharp D

I call out:
Foremen arise!
Powers arise!
C-sharp D arise!
Me arise!
Foreman
Forepower
Fore C-sharp D
Me fore C-sharp D

C-sharp D E-flat
D-sharp
Me fore C-sharp D
Me forepower
Me foreman
Foreman me?
Forepower C-sharp D?
D-flat?
D-sharp?
Shifts power
Me shifts power
Working man shifts power

KURT SCHWITTERS TO THE SWISS DADAIST ARP. BLACKBERRIES (2)

belivered pra!
first I say why?
why does one use upper-case and lower-case? i use only lower-case. then I
say why? why does one punctuate i write everything without punctuation then
i ask why why does one use umlauts i won't be straight diacritical
henceforth i will write zurich fülfills seclusion  personal carryover and
then i remember the old phrase from mathematics namely that it does not
matter in which order i add respect multiply and now i write vole instead of
love because love needs voles to love voles and finally now will giveup the
or derofwordsamongthemselvesbywritingonlyonegiantwordorwhile
morewrotitsoladinorthographyisnaturallyunimportantandsenseigiveupinfavorofno
nsenseandthustheitsheklmnoppqrsutabelgikemaminopetroleumplaguekakrrkrrrksrst
opitonobilamenteyakkaanteelinguekitonpausbacrocodilemmadiemadilemma*)
                                                                                         kuwitter

*) Here the typographer went stark raving mad and threatened a general
strike, should he be forced to set any more Kugewitter (Cowweather).


DIE GAZELLE ZITTERT

Die Gazelle zittert,
Weil der Löwe Brüllt.
Die Hyäne wittert.
Doch die KUNST ERFÜLLT.


THE GAZELLE TREMBLES

The gazelle trembles,
As the lions roar.
The hyena shambles.
But ART GIVES MORE.

From:         Maria Damon <damon001@UMN.EDU>

part of the beauty of alan's work is the imaginative ways he finds of
disseminating his work; i.e. using listservs as a publishing venue,
as they are already a public forum of sorts.  also, there are many
reasons for high-volume publishing other than "ego."  Without
attributing any of these specifically to sondheim, some of them might
be: obsessive/compulsive tendencies, a belief in process, an ethic of
transparency, a working method that *requires* imminent publication
as part of its constraint system, etc etc.  please, gentlemen, avoid
ad hominem attacks that involve accusations of egotism and lack of
talent.  you both seem like intelligent and talented folks.

Subject:      if the epics happened now...

Waiting for Book Six to Begin   or   “It’s an allegory isn’t it”?


Aware of the dearth of diners, blinking in the neon ensparkled air, the
companions converged on a shop selling bagels, offering ten ducats a dozen

“I don’t sell to anachronisms” the young rapscallion salesclerk said. “Get
out of my store!”

Abashed and  ashamed our captain said “heigh ho” and we heigh hoed, all the
way down Broadway.  This was Book Six and we were dreading it.

“It’s an allegory” said little Achmed, at least once a block. “Just a bloody
allegory!” We all cheered, but subdued. “The Author didn’t know about the
PCBs,” said another, “that’s not part of the deal.” “I didn’t sign up for
this!” a third began. “Shut yer face!” someone said, loudly. This was me.
We none of us choose our fate so why bellyache?

“It’s just a matter of which river,”  said the captain.  “I admit I’m lost.”
“We’re gonna have to pay the oarsman extra if we make him wait two days.
Union rates.  Time and a half for evenings and nights.” Achmed cleared his
throat.  “Excuse me honored sir captain?  As treasurer of this...
um...endeavor I have to warn you that our funds are coming to an end. I
suggest we go straight to book seven.”

Nonsense said Fred.  Fred is not too bright.  He is a hero:  Heavy footed
Fred. With one step he can squash sheep and goats beneath his feet,
accomplishing slaughter and meat tenderizing in a single step. Fred hasn’t
read the book  so he doesn’t know about Book Six.   Someone asks him how
good he is at killing three-headed dogs. “I can kill any kind of dog,” Fred
said.  “Even a dog that’s already dead?” I asked. “No problemo.  Fred said.
Show me dog, will kill.”

Reply-To:     men2@columbia.edu
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Millie Niss <men2@COLUMBIA.EDU>
Subject:      if bin laden drove a taxi
Comments: To: Webartery List <webartery@yahoogroups.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

This is one of my "Joan" poems -- she's a narrative voice I sometimes use.
She also wrote a letter to the MTA asking where they buried the body in the
Uptown 34th street IRT station (due to odor of rotting), and she thinks that
all Arab falafel makers are in league agaist her and communicate evil
messages to her by ripping her straw wrapper or putting too much tahini on,
in extreme cases.
------------------

I Have Lost My Mind Somewhere on The West Side Highway


I have lost my mind.
Would you help me find it please?
It can’t have gone far.

Last night Bin Laden drove me to see the shrink
At least he looked like Bin Laden
He had a very long beard
and drove well

I dreaded being asked whether anything unusual had happened to me recently–
a way doctors use to find out of the world you live in
is disconnected from theirs,
which their MDs give them the right to dub real

Yes, bin laden drove me to see you
I would have to say
he was a very good driver
and got me here on time even though I was late to begin with
only you always run late so you wouldn’t know

he mumbled in a semitic language into a cell phone throughout the drive
then took out a little prayer mat and stuck it under his rather shapely rump
and got out a holy book and began to pray

I think it was in Arabic but frankly with the  meds you give me even English
looks like Arabic
making reading rather difficult
I think I’ll enroll in an Arabic class so I can read the Times Bestsellers
again

I thought maybe it was my patriotic duty
to unman this driver
by pulling on the end of his turban
and unrolling it
and then I’d get to see if he had nice hair, too

But the speeds on the West Side Highway made me wary of this course of
action
what if, turbanless, the man could no longer drive and I were to get
stranded
somewhere between the Intrepid
and the Convention Center
It wouldn’t do.

I don’t remember his medallion number or his name on the posted license but
that doesn’t matter because I’m sure it was fake.

I was afraid he’d use the car as a car bomb with me still in it, he seemed
so eager to drive on
he really was a very good driver

but no, dr. elshrinko, nothing at all unusual has happened in the month
since I saw you
I no longer spot celebrities in the street
you said that was an illusion but I know they are avoiding me
because you have robbed me of my power

I stick to down to earth things as recommended.
I have taken up philately.
I got a pen-pal in Kenya.
I volunteer at the hospital bringing ice water to the patients
but I stay strictly out of their affairs as directed by you
I have accepted that romance is not in the cards for people like me;
instead we get the love and fellowship of friendship of fellow clients in
day program
it is almost a family
yes, dr. elshrinko, I have accepted all of this

but why then, would bin laden be picking me, me in particular up to drive to
see you?
he must want to make peace, with me as his instrument
will you help me contact the media?

what?

you want to up my meds?
but I can see.  I can think.  I am myself, or at least a self
I don’t care if my experiences are a little unusual
I’m an unusual person

I don’t want to fit in anyway.
do you really want to risk locking me up when I know bin laden?

he could come and destroy the whole hospital except for me.
oh well.
the cops again.
I guess you win.

bye bye Osama!  You can come out of the corner now.  It seems clear that
elshrinko can’t see you...

Subject:      Re: Self-publish or perish

Collaborative efforts with fellow poets, but also with artists from other
disciplines, are great ways to expand one's own horizon and potentially the
field as a whole. I once had the opportunity to write movements for Ken James
who is a choreographer/dancer with Fellow Travellers Performance Group, a Bay
Area dance company.  Three years later that project continues to resonate for
me.  More recently Jessica Grim and I have attempted some co-written texts,
one of which (And Or Not) is due out in a forthcoming issue of Raddle Moon.

Collaboration can break down hierarchy, it can take one out of the habitual
range of reference.  It is also quite challenging.  I'd like to do it more
often.  And I'd like to see more of it going on. I've often wondered why
collaborative writing projects aren't attempted more often on this list.

Tom Beckett

Subject:      waiting
In-Reply-To:  <v04210142b98c52f36059@[128.135.91.150]>

it sounds like there


 I am just

 the other times there waiting

 it was the one to wait in
sometimes the other was truly there where there or not in the others waiting
waiting on each other

sitting in the the one waiting
they had gone to move or do something

a distant door closed

they had signed up to repeat every word they hadn't entered

the distance

 it was the door that shut

 they had signed up to listen to there waiting below the distance

a pause, and the room above was someone not there for hours, and a moment

 it was in that other that entered the other waiting
 one, who is and then  would come in


some would fight amongst themselves, raising their waiting

I am just

mostly though I knew they where not, not waiting

 it didn't sound like words
the distance

 a room for one waiting
 sitting in the one not known
I knew they would wait  for hours
some I knew would come in
and some would just wait

 other times there where others
 others that where in their distance
a distant door shut in the room below the distance

a pause


I knew they hadn't entered the room above me
 not in the waiting room above me

I was not there

the door would fight, raising their voices, cracking and just a pause

someone not known, someone not in the room above me would try to just wait

 I knew  sometimes they would say "thank you, I am just waiting"
"I am just waiting, I am just waiting, thank you"

I could be those low foot steps making distance
 someone else's distance
 someone  making a distance
 a moment, a word
I could be another room
sometimes waiting

 just waiting

I knew they would wait for waiting
 waiting on the wait room above me

some could not be waiting
 some I think sat in their voices in the room above me

sometimes I had signed up to be low in the room below
the room that was not there
 just waiting, just waiting, thank you

Tom

--you
&
anyone else--

are invited to cocreate at the swiki we have set up below.  from what I can tell
there have been 10-20 folks consistently working on the site since it was
invigorated at the beginning of the month.  I have done extensive collaboration
with other writers over the the years in a one to one form of exchange but this
kind of space requires even deeper observations of one's ego, identity,
aesthethics, expectations & a kind of thorough letting go that I find myself
enjoying more & more.  I also find that there is a lot of listening & reading
going on in the space, many of the additions are quite thoughtful & often
polymorphic in how they graft themselves onto a document (72 pages created so
far) in a way that defies identification with an individual recognizable
signature.


spidertangle or spy yonder tangent...
http://swiki.hfbk-hamburg.de:8888/mIEKAL



mIEKAL

Sara Teasdale


Antares was red in the sky before us,
  And behind us, the blackness of the sea.

Antares was red in the sky before us,
 And behind blackness of sea.

us, before sky the in red was Antares
sea. the of blackness the us, behind And

us, before sky the in red was Antares
i touched her breast
i'm so sorry my life is horrible
she said i've been watching you i lowered her

us, before sky the in red was Antares
sea. the of blackness the us, behind And
we'll do this together
we'll split it between us
she said i've been watching you i lowered her
she said for a long time
she said bare floor

sea. the of blackness the us, behind And

Antares Antares was was red red in in the the sky sky before before us,
us,
 And And behind behind us, blackness of of the sea.

Not everyone. Somehow,

the spokes of the day exhaled
in water like the thunder of bungee
lettering, and I painted myself
to the chair again, baby, just like

breaking in the middle like this
does no good. My dad was a truck driver and
a muscle car dipped in rust. Like candy,

my throat glorifies morning with
a whole afternoon's worth of
sandwhiches wroth with thickness.
This won't help me pass my GRE! If

Dad had saved face with this nubile
lurid cream, we would all have severed
ties with a corporate potato tattoo
splashed seductively across my forearm.
Wanna see me flex, baby? The creases

in the sky are arguable; some of us
are horrifically in love with them.

Free idea for opera, musical comedy, fiction or poem(depending on one's genre
orientation):

a protagonist who deals with stressful situations by bursting into song.
Protagonist does not sing well at all and is singing in wildly inappropriate
contexts.  The nominal "plot" would consist of a sequence of stressful
situations.

I have briefly experimented with this approach to life and especially
recommend medleys of Tom Jones songs.  Although badly sung opera is
interesting also.  Sometimes Donna ain't mobile at all.

Tom Beckett

Joe,

With that last post from you re: Sondheim, and in the context of
numerous recent and satisfied comments from others about how
the list is "unedited," how overposting may have many "healthy"
reasons, etc., I'm really surprised that you (who has published
material on the '98 expulsions) didn't remind people that the list, in
fact, is NOT "unedited," since the continuing proscription of
individuals from the list (there are now at least five, apparently, as a
well-known poet and editor of my acquaintance, who has had some
past arguments with Charles Bernstein, has been trying to join and
keeps getting rejected) is the grossest and most vulgar form of
"editing" one can carry through.

Mind you, I probably wouldn't rejoin anyway myself, but don't you
think it is a bit revolting, from an poetical-ethical point of view, that
1000 poets go happily on conversing away while the *censorship of
banishment* continues as policy behind the curtain?

Wouldn't it be interesting to be impolite and raise the issue
directly? It would be a much more interesting topic of discussion,
probably, than the silly non-issue of Alan Sondheim's volume of
postings, or poems about basketball, though a free list will always
have topics like these, too... For a long time, the matter's been
contained as a dark, little secret, a boxed-up embarrassment no
one wants to talk about. But I've always said it's an issue that will
be aired and analyzed in the future in a prominent way (relatively
speaking, of course-- our poetry sub-culture is small), and I remain
convinced that will be the case. And those who speak up now will
most certainly be respected now and later for doing so.

Sending this cc. to a bunch of other people who have posted in
August, who have either been concerned with the Poetics list issue
in the past, or who have made statements in the past about the
value of open and democratic discourse in poetry.

Kent







They hang the man and flog the woman
That steal the goose from off the common,
But let the greater villain loose
That steals the common from the goose.

Kent, et. al.,

I'm opposed to the exclusions--and would urge all affected to continue to try
and resub-- but am dubious of yr perspective that the 1000 or so poets on the
list are "happily" conversing.  This from the standpoint of one who has
dropped off the list on a number of occasions over the last few years.

We aren't a particulary cohesive group of individuals. Cyclic patterns of
rapture-to-rupture, along with whatever's in the repertoire, seem to be in
play at all levels most of the time. It's frustrating, energizing, enervating
and frictive.

There's a spectre haunting the Poetics List: the spectre of ___________?

Love,

Kent Johnson

>the continuing proscription of

What twaddle. There are umpteen poetry lists. A listowner has the right to
remove particular people if they see fit. Nowhere here, or in the rest of
this self-congratulatory screed, is there any mention of the numerous
listmembers who felt intimidated by those ended up being removed.
Intimidated to the point where they felt they didn't dare post. BTW What
kind of a snob thinks "vulgar" is an insult?

Then we get the phrase

*censorship of
> banishment*

self-inflatory twaddle.

Later on

>For a long time, the matter's been
> contained as a dark, little secret, a boxed-up embarrassment no
> one wants to talk about. But I've always said it's an issue that will
> be aired and analyzed in the future in a prominent way (relatively

This is risible,  classic obsessive-compulsive snow tactics. Repetition,

3 storey house


You see Lightnings, Thunders, Storm, and thusly here.
There appears to be some writing on the note ...

Is this whatever truth there is?
Leaving you plain and in pain
To your brain but a stain
When there is nothing to gain
Here hexed by text

I don't understand that.
Nikuko laughs at Nikuko!
Nikuko cries on Nikuko's shoulder.
Nikuko is jumping up and down, yelling and screaming at Nikuko!
Nikuko kisses Nikuko lightly on the cheek.
Nikuko spanks Nikuko's ass!
Spank! Spank! Spank! Ouch!
Nikuko exclaims, "Yowwwwwch!" as hand imprints appear on his/her ass!

You say, "This area is going down. All areas are going down."
You say, "Look on our lives. "
You say, "Napalm cauterizes the violence of inscription."
Nikuko's tongue cut out, available for massacre.
Nikuko's arms cut off, available for massacre.

Nikuko laughs at Nikuko!

oracle: success in war


   159  16:36   grep -h "great war" network/* > zz
   163  16:37   grep -h "missing in action" network/* > zz
   165  16:38   grep -h "missing" network/* > zz
   167  16:38   grep -h "killed or wounded" network/* > zz
   169  16:39   grep -h "wounded or killed" network/* > zz
   171  16:39   grep -h "wounded and killed" network/* > zz
   173  16:39   grep -h "killed and wounded" network/* > zz
   175  16:40   grep -h "mutilated" network/* > zz

survive. the woman mutilated herself by eating pieces of her fingers.
fragments of cocks, breasts, cunts, churn through past-histories as
mutilated hate crimes, digital eternities mutilated by legacy softwares
and dead prisons, mutilated translations of the usual, the holds and holes
of the body; leaning in toward the screen; the mutilated screen,
projection of emptied spaces, mutilated sites, questions of the mutilated
history of every little thing

mutilated women, men, children. even the order's got an ideology, informal
hate crimes, digital eternities mutilated by legacy softwares and dead
dull and mutilated violence against oneself, the accumulation of mutilated
signs.

destroyed and mutilated. - you are killing children. your scatter-mines,
your leaflets are destroyed and mutilated - you are killing children,
killing everything. everything is destroyed and mutilated. what damage
mutilated, returned, sliding out forever, caressed, cuddled, fucked,
mutilated, returned, sliding out of view of a mutilated conversation.

the mutilated faces were unrecognizable.

# the signs were unrecognizable. the machine sorted, resorted, arranged.
# the signs written by smiling old men.
# the signs were brought on the backs of the wounded.
# the foiled assassination. the concentration camp. the computer-roundup.
# everything in this world is evil, she said.
# the smiling old men in power pissing oil.
# the world can't hold us, they said.
# we are far from damaged life, she said. we are mutilated.
# there was no answer. believe in this: meltdown of the net.
# there was no answer. believe in this: you can see the world teeter, if
you look around and leave the commentary.

Actually, I understand why Kent would call my attempted criticsm of Alan's
over-postings a non-issue, because both have the same mode of operation:
they're both prolific in their postings, and neither of them appear to give
a good god damn about what other people think.  I think enthusiasm for a
subject is good, but it also has a down-side.  Both Kent and Alan do not
appear to have any understanding of polite limits and I really find this
absolutely "American" and absolutely rude.

Alan's factory, and his unapologetic use of it to spew forth, reminds me of
George Bush--the head of the largest over-producing, spewing factory in the
world.  Both seem to have a feeling of "entitlement" that escapes me.  We'll
let others debate the issue about Bush, but why does Alan feel that he is
entitled to empty his outbox onto this list and onto my hard-drive?  I don't
think he's earned the right to do this steadily now for four years or more.
Someone mentioned that Alan's a genius, but nothing I see on this list
indicates that to me.

Well, Alan, let's hear it.  What gives you the right to clutter up my hard
drive with your work?  Why do you feel entitled to post your "creative"
productions over and over to this discussion list?

What I see of Alan's work comes through on this list as numbers, letters,
and words that to someone trained in literature and art, and with more than
an adequate understanding of most things--including computers--appears
assuredly electronic, but less than literature if you've just spent the
morning reading Pope, Emily Dickinson or David Jones.  I don't argue that
some computer programming takes place behind the screen in order to produce
the product.  I'm simply judging the product in light of a long tradition of
literary excellence and in that light what Alan does fails miserably.  Alan
also seems to have his own compulsions that he appears to be working out on
this list in terms of violence, porn, and other sexual issues, and perhaps
some of those, too, would be better appreciated elsewhere by his fans.

I'm only familiar with what Alan does from what I've seen on this list.  I
haven't sought his work out elsewhere, because--frankly--it bores me.

I've said this repeatedly, but I'll say it again: why can't Alan simply post
links to this list instead of throwing absolutely everything he writes on my
computer--and this is "My Computer" and I do have a right to participate on
this list without changing anything in my settings.  He surely has his fans,
and I bet that most of them--if not all--would go that extra "click" for
their inspiring leader.

Discussion I think is great.  I'm just talking about Alan's "creative" work.

Maybe this is all happening because I have lived in Japan for 10 years--long
enough to have my teeth set on edge when I see an American walking through
as if he or she owns the world and deserves the world's applause.

Both Kent and Alan appear to have abundant time to post to these lists, and
both have the incredible advantage of not having to pay per 3 minute unit to
broadcast their opinions and works abroad.  I really envy that, because I
have to keep my eye on the clock when I'm on the net.

I want to add that I'm not the only person on this list who feels this way.
Jesse Glass

From:         Nancy Kuhl <nekuhl@YAHOO.COM>
Subject:      Celebrating the Bollingen Prize 1949-2002
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

Yale: A Place for Poetry, Celebrating the Bollingen
Prize 1949-2002

The Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library and the
Whitney Humanities Center at Yale University are
pleased to announce a major literary event to take
place in September. “Yale: A Place for Poetry,
Celebrating the Bollingen Prize 1949-2002,” will bring
nearly all the living winners of the prestigious
Bollingen Prize for poetry to Yale University for a
group reading and roundtable discussions. The program
will take place on Thursday, September 19 and Friday,
September 20.

Thursday, September 19, 8:00 pm
First Church of Christ in New Haven (Center Church on
the Green)
311 Temple Street, New Haven, CT 06511-6698

Readings by Bollingen winners:
John Ashbery, Robert Creeley, Louise Glück,, Anthony
Hecht, John Hollander, Stanley Kunitz
W.S. Merwin, Gary Snyder, Mark Strand, and Richard
Wilbur

Friday, September 20, 9:30 am-12:30 pm
Whitney Humanities Center
53 Wall Street, New Haven, CT

Panel 1: American Traditions in Poetry
Panelists: Glück, Creeley, Ashbery, Kunitz, Strand
Moderator: Langdon Hammer

Panel 2: The Craft of Poetry Today
Panelists: Wilbur, Hecht, Hollander, Merwin, Snyder
Moderator: J.D. McClatchy

The Bollingen Prize winners attending the events
include some of the most influential poets in the
country: John Ashbery, Robert Creeley, Louise Glück,
Anthony Hecht, John Hollander, Stanley Kunitz, W.S.
Merwin, Gary Snyder, Mark Strand, and Richard Wilbur.
This group includes winners of the Yale Younger Poets
series prize, the Pulitzer Prize, the National Book
Award, the National Book Critics Circle Award, and the
Lannan Foundation Poetry Prize, recipients of National
Endowment for the Arts grants, and Guggenheim and
MacArthur Foundation fellows—to name only a few of
their accomplishments. Rarely does such a
distinguished and honored group of writers come
together and thus this occasion promises to be among
the most important and memorable events in
contemporary American literary culture.

For more information contact Nancy Kuhl at
203.432.2966 or via e-mail at nancy.kuhl@yale.edu

From:         lewis lacook <llacook@YAHOO.COM>
Subject:      ATTACK OF THE __________
Comments: cc: "arc.hive" <_arc.hive_@lm.va.com.au>,
          cupcake kaleidoscope <CupcakeKleidoscope@yahoogroups.com>,
          Renee <curry333@hotmail.com>, rhizome <list@rhizome.org>,

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

On my planet, tell me what dowager gawks
as the suns that triple cells quadruple
across our sky a jelly with lead and fantastic
sadness in store for you. What derringers god

the tinfoil space helmet on the astronaut
that glisters and twists with everything fanatic
as the red rum seas ripen to a faster purple
and our leader in fear begins closing the docks

to insure us no viral bouquet of foreign shots
on my planet arraigns us. We know what bitter churl
can do, what dulcimer mutes, in jealous, attack;
for these light years among deathly rocks we sought

drier plateaus, raised above our worst of dreams.
Such sadness rung up when just one of us leaves.

=====

http://artists.mp3s.com/artists/385/lewis_lacook.html

Comments: cc: "arc.hive" <_arc.hive_@lm.va.com.au>,
          cupcake kaleidoscope <CupcakeKleidoscope@yahoogroups.com>,

I like the sun chips away at everything.
Explosions of crepe dogwood at warp pink
and purple wallop, as in high yellow pavements

push feet from dissonance to sober waking. She's

in right now around the television just un-smudging
her eyes from where we unraveled our streaming
on sheets. There's a sliding glass door separates us.

This is the bridge between two bodies among
the clock. My computer breathes on and off.

Our hearts

Consider this quote by (sorry) Carl Sagan,

The question is not whether you are right or wrong, sir.  You are not even

A good seventy percent of what is posted to this list is, at best, beside
the point of this list.

Question:  Has the List become decadent?  Is the list decadent?

Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         MWP <mpalmer@JPS.NET>
Subject:      Re: The Meaninglessness of Meaninglessness
In-Reply-To:  <NFBBJIJOOLLMOMMACKAFCEOGDHAA.jim@vispo.com>
Mime-version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-transfer-encoding: 7bit

The Egolessness of Egolessness

(Excuse the verbosity verging on otiosity! The ferocity verging on
pomposity! Etc. I do my best to keep things short, but I was born to ramble,
so ramble on I must.)


Lots of voices kicking in on this topic. I hope that's a good thing and
isn't turning people off. Here are my latest responses to the considered
refutations and maddeningly oracular pronunciamentos that have followed in
the wake of my last posting.

First off, I hope I don't come across as sounding too authoritative, as I
would prefer to remain problematized by my own weakly submerged (for me)
contradictions. Indeed, this is what I cherish most about the process of
thought, that the mind (if healthy) naturally resists following a single,
dogmatic path for too long and turns repeatedly to nothingness for
confirmation of its sustained existence. (Thus spake Blanchot! Sort of.)

But seriously, the last thing I want to do here is to pit pro- and
anti-randomness forces against each other in some kind of gladiator fight to
the death. As I think my words have indicated, I see art as being a soluble
solution comprised of both randomness and necessity, but at a level of depth
that cannot be indicated by any algorithm or mere toss of the dice.

"Depth" is one of those woefully fuzzy words I frankly don't like to lean
upon except when I cannot think of a replacement. For me it is simply an
indication of something that is endlessly complex. Randomness as such is not
endlessly complex. It has one level of complexity and that's it. (Can even
be quantified.) Good art has depth. A good meal has depth. Andy Warhol has
depth. Nature has depth, even though it is intensely random in certain ways.
It is also highly structured down to the finest detail, which to me makes
the balance work. (Thank - God?)

The reason I feel that certain usages of randomness are pernicious and need
to be rooted out is because the result can be so deceptive. What may seem
like the full depth of thought in a work of art may actually not be deep at
all but merely the product of a banal random generative device. Like that
old A-I psychiatrist (Eliza?) who would dispense pseudo-authoritative advice
without any true understanding of the patient's illness. Art that is built
upon a random algorithm instead of making the hard choices and connections
that a mind must make in putting together a work of adequate complexity is a
castle made of sand. It may look strong and fortified to the uninitiated -
until the first wave comes in and washes it all away. (Of course if a work
deals with such devices in some meta-critical fashion then there may be a
good justification in using them. I am not laying down any chiseled rules,
okay?)

Resorting to stupid randomness tricks to deprive oneself of the "tyranny" of
the authorial voice is clearly throwing the baby out with the bath water.
There are more effective methods that still preserve the mind's maze-work of
mixed intentions such as Rimbaud's derangement of the senses. Computers have
made things like text-scrambling widely available at the click of a mouse,
which is exactly why they must be resisted. (But NOT necessarily rejected!)
Unfortunately, the more computers become a part of our working lives the
more such tricks will be resorted to by those who seek the easy way out. But
just because the "Author" is dead doesn't mean the critic should just roll
into his grave as well!

If you inspect a typical aleatoric process like a random walk or Markov
chain you will note that it looks only one step back (or at most a few) at a
time to decide its current move. Such an approach is simply too shallow to
serve as the scaffolding for a complex work of art. By contrast, if you look
at the way the mind works, it sees everything in its completeness as well as
its partiality. It grasps the global and the local, the end and the
beginning, the fragment and the whole - and does so amazingly all at once.
There is (yet?!) no purely artificial way of achieving this degree of
gestaltification, in art or in life.[*] Bataille - a strong advocate of the
violence of the arbitrary, by the way - puts it nicely: "To live: to rebegin
that which finishes without finishing." Why would anybody wish to replace
what the admittedly mortal, limited mind does so brilliantly and (so far as
we know) uniquely with a cheap simulacrum, unless it be through laziness or
the desire to deceive?

[*] Indeed, one definition of a computer might be that it is a mind
incapable of metaphor. (Debatable point?)

Next I move on to defending the glorious un-facility of Cage. I would say
that the reason the randomness in Cage's approach to art attains depth is
because of the way he forged an alliance between world, work and life. Cage
demonstrates through every aspect of his being - his art, teachings and
interactions with people - that randomness is not merely the fluffy icing on
the cake but an integral part of one's being fully alert to the world's
contingencies and continuities. His connection with oriental cultures is not
insignificant in this regard, as they have been among those that have most
fully embraced the effects of chance in the creation of a life's work that
is in tune with transpersonal forces of preservation and change.

I now would like to carry on a bit longer about Cage, whose entire body of
work I believe I know rather well, so here I say to begin

TRANSFER INTERRUPTED!

Hm. Am I back? There's a story that somebody tells about the painter Jackson
Pollock. (I think it's Julian "too deep for his own good" Schnabel.) While
visiting him in his home, somebody tells Pollock that his work looks merely
like a bunch of random drips and drabs. At which point Pollock angrily grabs
a brush and flicks a long loogie of paint across the room that lands cleanly
on the distant doorknob. What Pollock does in his painting is like finely
aimed archery. It cannot be considered random except insofar as any painting
that is not absolutely precise in all particulars is such.

Process? You will hear no blanket condemnations from me - wet or otherwise!
Except insofar as process is embraced for its rationality and not its
hopelessness. (Check out the classic minimalists, for instance, and see how
their influence traces directly back to the pessimistic yearnings of
Beckett.)

To me one of the strongest reasons for using randomness in art is that it
puts us more acutely in touch with the pervasive randomness that affects us
in our daily lives. Whether it be:  - to come upon a man who puts his knife
in one's back (shades of Beckett!) . . . to stumble upon some shard of
driftwood on the beach that brings forth memories of one's long dead uncle
(shades of Proust!) . . . to be made aware of the flux of reality that is
usually darting about below one's sensorial radars until it breaks to the
surface of consciousness during those rare heightened moments when
everything is seen as one (shades of Darwin!) . . . How's that for a
magnanimous gesture of harmony and reconciliation!

Straight man question (to all): If form is emptiness what is structure?



m*rk p

This is my last reply to Jesse Glass.

If you don't like my work or the huge frequency of 1/2 a day, just set
your email filter. You constantly complain about my posts filling up your
hard drive - which wouldn't even be the case in 1984. You can quite
ignore them.

Genius is always in the eyes of the beholder; I don't claim one way or
another.

If you don't know how to filter, or if pushing delete is too difficult for
you, just write to me or the list and I will tell you.

Your posts are insulting. I have no idea who or what you are, but you
apparently expect me to respect you in spite of them. I don't, and I would
just as soon not have you read my work myself.

And as I've said repeatedly, I'm on numerous lists, as are most people,
where people post up to 5-10 times a day, without issue. I don't like a
lot of the posts and some of the people, so I don't read them - so what?n

Either try the delete key or set up a filter.

Finally, as someone said, this is tiresome, and I apologize to the list
myself - this should be a non-issue. If someone wants to discuss my
writing, that would be great; but talking about its appearance, when it's
so easy to eliminate, seems to me an insult to others. And Jesse, it's
been 8 years, not 4.

Alan

Subject:      Re: The Meaninglessness of Meaninglessness
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"

In a message dated 8/26/02 12:45:16 PM, mpalmer@JPS.NET writes:

>>
Resorting to stupid randomness tricks to deprive oneself of the "tyranny" of
the authorial voice is clearly throwing the baby out with the bath water.
There are more effective methods that still preserve the mind's maze-work of
mixed intentions such as Rimbaud's derangement of the senses. Computers have
made things like text-scrambling widely available at the click of a mouse,
which is exactly why they must be resisted. (But NOT necessarily rejected!)
Unfortunately, the more computers become a part of our working lives the
more such tricks will be resorted to by those who seek the easy way out. But
just because the "Author" is dead doesn't mean the critic should just roll
into his grave as well!

If you inspect a typical aleatoric process like a random walk or Markov
chain you will note that it looks only one step back (or at most a few) at a
time to decide its current move. Such an approach is simply too shallow to
serve as the scaffolding for a complex work of art. By contrast, if you look
at the way the mind works, it sees everything in its completeness as well as
its partiality. It grasps the global and the local, the end and the
beginning, the fragment and the whole - and does so amazingly all at once.
There is (yet?!) no purely artificial way of achieving this degree of
gestaltification, in art or in life.[*] Bataille - a strong advocate of the
violence of the arbitrary, by the way - puts it nicely: "To live: to rebegin
that which finishes without finishing." Why would anybody wish to replace
what the admittedly mortal, limited mind does so brilliantly and (so far as
we know) uniquely with a cheap simulacrum, unless it be through laziness or
the desire to deceive?
 >>

Please forgive the length of this posting.

I've been lurking a bit, enjoying the give and take between various members
on this topic.    What m*rk writes re:  Rimbaud and Bataille is clearly
accurate and must seem so to anyone who thinks well about literature --and
that, I assume, includes nearly everyone on this list (perhaps everyone).

The idea that the "tyranny" of the authorial voice can be answered in only
one way amounts to a broad denial of factual evidence, plain and simple.
That the authorial voice operates tyrannically is itself a problematic
stance.  Authority, we know, is rarely tyranny.  The best we can do is tamper
with authorial authority; we can hardly eliminate it since it sources
everything we experience.

We do invariably experience as individuals.  To tamper with the individual
seems more a political gesture that has, politically (not necessarily
aesthetically), thus far failed, simply because it sidesteps the guts of
life.  Rimbaud, De Sade, Rimbaud, Lautreamont, Bataille, Artaud and most
celebrated poets, writers, critics, philosophers understood this.  They had
lives, however messy.  They understood that the "tyranny" was rooted in human
experience, and that art which pretends to eliminate human experience might
be considered "there," but not so much like a tree which is about life and
death, as like a chiseled rock.  Hence the method of derangement of the
senses in some cases which does not throw the baby out with the bathwater, as
m*rk puts it.

Some--not all--have interpreted contemporary language philosophy as a call
for the elimination of the authorial voice from both politics and art.  There
is precious little of that in the actual writings by said philosophers.
Their project is meant to reveal and explain rather than eliminate.  The
disruptive methods they sometimes employ serve the explanation, the
exposition.  They are not meant to obliterate since such an act is impossible
in any event.  The best of these poets, writers, critics, philosophers
understood that the very attempt to obliterate restores in full, because
contingent upon, the power of the authorial voice.

Personally, I support every sort of artistic method in its attempt.  I'll
leave for history the question of how much value a particular method obtains,
though as Jesse Glass has intimated, no individual work of art escapes the
arena of valuation.  Everything connected with human experience is about and
promotes a value.  And only nothing is not connected from any point of view,
since point of view doesn't exist beyond human intervention.

I'd like to suggest an oldie but still a goodie:  Rene Wellek's Concepts of
Criticism.  Although Wellek's overview has been necessarily updated by
Lentricchia and others, his brief section on Paul Valery seems germane to our
discussion.  Valery despised the self and its emotional/tragic gestures which
dominated art, especially novels.  His view was that poetry should aspire to
a cold interlocking of content, form, image, meaning--a blending so perfect
that no one element stood to the front at any time to be recognized and
analyzed.  Form and content are one.  Meaning and image are one.  The critic
would find it near impossible to locate and isolate one element for
discussion.  Anyone familiar with Valery's works knows that the issue of what
they mean is problematic, to say the least.

Valery's method, his "philosophy," as Wellek points out, attempts to remove
the work of art from human history and place it in some absolute,
a-historical dimension (art for art's sake?).  He knew that to accomplish
this he would have to repress the self which thinks, feels, desires, lives
and dies.  T. S. Eliot was much influenced by Valery, though his attempts to
create an impersonal poetry met with mixed success due to the tragicomic
details of his life and personality.  He was, as many are, dissatisfied with
the chisled rock.  He needed the tree.  He was compelled by who he was.
Ashbery is another who takes a "halfwalk" down this road, though similarly
unable to travel the entire distance.  And Coolidge's The Crystal Text, while
ostensibly a meditation on one version of the chisled rock, neverthess moves
many precisely because he does not deny the meditation's agent, the self, as
it contemplates its subject/object.

Wellek points to the austere nature of Valery's ideas and methods.  Some may
call Valery a purist.  I have no objection.  But there is a conservatism
attached to purism, and historically a part of the avant-garde has not been
exempted from said purism/ austerity/conservatism, either politically, or
aesthetically, or both.

Quite frankly, I admire Valery's attempts and his poetic results.  Flaubert's
"book about nothing" has always intrigued me as an idea, even though Flaubert
knew the impossibility of achieving such a work.  My own writing, however,
issues from my preference for the messiness of life and death, the inevitable
intellectual and emotional highs and lows experienced by the individual.  I
want that crucial stuff in my art alongside whatever formal innovations are
available to me, including the interrogation of authorial power.

Poetry which is "about" the details of an individual's living and dying is
not, as some would have it, a merging of art with reportage.  That idea is
just silly.  All art, all "writing," all speaking, mediates the supposed
object under scrutiny and recreates it.  One might even argue that the object
is created in whole.  In that sense, it's all art, and Stevens said as much
even though it wasn't his idea to begin with.  The author's voice, far from
behaving tyrannically as a rule, is coextensive with human experience.  If
this were not true, this listserv would not be possible.  We would not be
talking "about" anything.

Poetry, because its methods are usually different from, say, journalism,
recreates the world in a different, perhaps more important and memorable,
fashion.  There is plenty of historical evidence to suggest the privilege of
poetry's recreations within the human sphere.  In any case, what we
experience, either in poetry or walking down the street, is a recreation.  We
never get the world as it is.  The world as it is is a nonsensical phrase
anyway.  What exists outside of human perception is hardly a world, or
informed by any idea whatsoever.  It is beyond our control.  The recreations,
conceptualizations, in which we live, however, we can control to some degree.


Of course what some refer to when they site tryannical methods is the
politicking within the poetry biz.  Who can deny that.  On the other hand,
the best stuff seems always to rise out of such political and aesthetic
conflicts, like the one between Valery and his imagined opponent.  That's
LIFE.  There is no escape from conflict, from comedy, from tragedy.  Some
would argue that a privileged and relatively peaceful nation--the U.S. for
example, can no longer make great art, that we have been reduced to surface
gestures such as randomness for it's own sake.  I don't know how true that
is, but's it's worth considering.

What I do know is that I understand my writing to be tree-like (ho!), part of
an eco-system, if you will, and not removed from it.  But others have
different ideas, and that's fine with me.  I'm listening.

Best, Bill

WilliamJamesAustin.com
KojaPress.com
Amazon.com
BarnesandNoble.com

this is good, this is healthy, this is not bitchin' about who should
