>
>First off, I hope I don't come across as sounding too authoritative, as I
>would prefer to remain problematized by my own weakly submerged (for me)
>contradictions. Indeed, this is what I cherish most about the process of
>thought, that the mind (if healthy) naturally resists following a single,
>dogmatic path for too long and turns repeatedly to nothingness for
>confirmation of its sustained existence. (Thus spake Blanchot! Sort of.)

so you say, but your path looks pretty straight.

>
>But seriously, the last thing I want to do here is to pit pro- and
>anti-randomness forces against each other in some kind of gladiator fight to
>the death. As I think my words have indicated, I see art as being a soluble
>solution comprised of both randomness and necessity, but at a level of depth
>that cannot be indicated by any algorithm or mere toss of the dice.

perhaps that is because your 'level of depth' is provided by the
end-user and not the poem

>
>"Depth" is one of those woefully fuzzy words I frankly don't like to lean
>upon except when I cannot think of a replacement. For me it is simply an
>indication of something that is endlessly complex. Randomness as such is not
>endlessly complex. It has one level of complexity and that's it. (Can even
>be quantified.) Good art has depth. A good meal has depth. Andy Warhol has
>depth. Nature has depth, even though it is intensely random in certain ways.
>It is also highly structured down to the finest detail, which to me makes
>the balance work. (Thank - God?)

a well has depth
i think you imply height
a poem has engagement
what do you mean by depth?
endlessly complex in an emotional way or intellectual or structural way?
a nursery rhyme is endlessly complex

>
>The reason I feel that certain usages of randomness are pernicious and need
>to be rooted out is because the result can be so deceptive. What may seem
>like the full depth of thought in a work of art may actually not be deep at
>all but merely the product of a banal random generative device.

the piece hasn't changed, the once thought 'deep' text is the same as
the now known 'random generated' text. what has changed? the
end-users knowledge that it was created by random process? the change
is within the end-user(reader) not within the poem, no?

>Like that
>old A-I psychiatrist (Eliza?) who would dispense pseudo-authoritative advice
>without any true understanding of the patient's illness. Art that is built
>upon a random algorithm instead of making the hard choices and connections
>that a mind must make in putting together a work of adequate complexity is a
>castle made of sand. It may look strong and fortified to the uninitiated -
>until the first wave comes in and washes it all away. (Of course if a work
>deals with such devices in some meta-critical fashion then there may be a
>good justification in using them. I am not laying down any chiseled rules,
>okay?)

according to you, art that is built on rock (i assume you're implying
endurance/canon material) is the creation of the poet, who by "making
the hard choices and connections that a mind must make in putting
together a work of adequate complexity".


>
>Resorting to stupid randomness tricks to deprive oneself of the "tyranny" of
>the authorial voice is clearly throwing the baby out with the bath water.
>There are more effective methods that still preserve the mind's maze-work of
>mixed intentions such as Rimbaud's derangement of the senses. Computers have
>made things like text-scrambling widely available at the click of a mouse,
>which is exactly why they must be resisted. (But NOT necessarily rejected!)
>Unfortunately, the more computers become a part of our working lives the
>more such tricks will be resorted to by those who seek the easy way out. But
>just because the "Author" is dead doesn't mean the critic should just roll
>into his grave as well!

you have already said the author is not dead.
you give all power to the author.
that makes you a pre-barthesian formalist, no?
not a very fashionable critic these days.

but perhaps we have really discovered your problem.
you don't like computers. but you cover your arse, "resisted but not
necessarily rejected">
feeling a little threatened by computers in some other area of your life?
have you considered that the new medium requires new strategies for
'reading' and 'writing'.
i know i am much more prepared these days to search much more text,
with my own mental poetry filter, finding what i like and what i
don't like.
my experience is becoming more of-the-moment, less seeking that
enduring poem and sticking with that for the rest of my life.
i am more prepared to contribute to the experience as well, and often
this involves physical as well as mental input.

>
>If you inspect a typical aleatoric process like a random walk or Markov
>chain you will note that it looks only one step back (or at most a few) at a
>time to decide its current move. Such an approach is simply too shallow to
>serve as the scaffolding for a complex work of art. By contrast, if you look
>at the way the mind works, it sees everything in its completeness as well as
>its partiality. It grasps the global and the local, the end and the
>beginning, the fragment and the whole - and does so amazingly all at once.
>There is (yet?!) no purely artificial way of achieving this degree of
>gestaltification, in art or in life.[*] Bataille - a strong advocate of the
>violence of the arbitrary, by the way - puts it nicely: "To live: to rebegin
>that which finishes without finishing." Why would anybody wish to replace
>what the admittedly mortal, limited mind does so brilliantly and (so far as
>we know) uniquely with a cheap simulacrum, unless it be through laziness or
>the desire to deceive?
>
>[*] Indeed, one definition of a computer might be that it is a mind
incapable of metaphor. (Debatable point?)


here you are offering an argument that computers are inferior to the
human mind.
no one here is arguing that the computer is better than the human
mind, we are talking poetics.
what has this to do with your original argument?


>
>
>Next I move on to defending the glorious un-facility of Cage. I would say
>that the reason the randomness in Cage's approach to art attains depth is
>because of the way he forged an alliance between world, work and life. Cage
>demonstrates through every aspect of his being - his art, teachings and
>interactions with people - that randomness is not merely the fluffy icing on
>the cake but an integral part of one's being fully alert to the world's
>contingencies and continuities. His connection with oriental cultures is not
>insignificant in this regard, as they have been among those that have most
>fully embraced the effects of chance in the creation of a life's work that
>is in tune with transpersonal forces of preservation and change.
>
>I now would like to carry on a bit longer about Cage, whose entire body of
>work I believe I know rather well, so here I say to begin

well obviously you are in love with cage and so assign depth to his work.

>
>TRANSFER INTERRUPTED!
>
>Hm. Am I back? There's a story that somebody tells about the painter Jackson
>Pollock. (I think it's Julian "too deep for his own good" Schnabel.) While
>visiting him in his home, somebody tells Pollock that his work looks merely
>like a bunch of random drips and drabs. At which point Pollock angrily grabs
>a brush and flicks a long loogie of paint across the room that lands cleanly
>on the distant doorknob. What Pollock does in his painting is like finely
>aimed archery. It cannot be considered random except insofar as any painting
>that is not absolutely precise in all particulars is such.

you confuse craft with creativity.

>
>Process? You will hear no blanket condemnations from me - wet or otherwise!
>Except insofar as process is embraced for its rationality and not its
>hopelessness. (Check out the classic minimalists, for instance, and see how
>their influence traces directly back to the pessimistic yearnings of
>Beckett.)

you have the arrogance of an authority.
you seem to know which texts we need to read.

>
>To me one of the strongest reasons for using randomness in art is that it
>puts us more acutely in touch with the pervasive randomness that affects us
>in our daily lives. Whether it be:  - to come upon a man who puts his knife
>in one's back (shades of Beckett!) . . . to stumble upon some shard of
>driftwood on the beach that brings forth memories of one's long dead uncle
>(shades of Proust!) . . . to be made aware of the flux of reality that is
>usually darting about below one's sensorial radars until it breaks to the
>surface of consciousness during those rare heightened moments when
>everything is seen as one (shades of Darwin!) . . . How's that for a
>magnanimous gesture of harmony and reconciliation!

the critic must know theory but must also apply it to their own thinking.


>
>Straight man question (to all): If form is emptiness what is structure?

lets not go there.

>
>
>
>m*rk p

komninos

Theory," and "Surplus." Backchannel if you'd like a complete list of poems

-----Original Message-----
From: jesse glass [mailto:ahadada@GOL.COM]
Sent: Tuesday, 27 August 2002 11:20 a.m.
To: POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU
Subject: Kent and Alan


Actually, I understand why Kent would call my attempted criticsm of Alan's
over-postings a non-issue, because both have the same mode of operation:
they're both prolific in their postings, and neither of them appear to give
a good god damn about what other people think.  I think enthusiasm for a
subject is good, but it also has a down-side.  Both Kent and Alan do not
appear to have any understanding of polite limits and I really find this
absolutely "American" and absolutely rude.

Alan's factory, and his unapologetic use of it to spew forth, reminds me of
George Bush--the head of the largest over-producing, spewing factory in the
world.  Both seem to have a feeling of "entitlement" that escapes me.  We'll
let others debate the issue about Bush, but why does Alan feel that he is
entitled to empty his outbox onto this list and onto my hard-drive?  I don't
think he's earned the right to do this steadily now for four years or more.
Someone mentioned that Alan's a genius, but nothing I see on this list
indicates that to me.

Well, Alan, let's hear it.  What gives you the right to clutter up my hard
drive with your work?  Why do you feel entitled to post your "creative"
productions over and over to this discussion list?

What I see of Alan's work comes through on this list as numbers, letters,
and words that to someone trained in literature and art, and with more than
an adequate understanding of most things--including computers--appears
assuredly electronic, but less than literature if you've just spent the
morning reading Pope, Emily Dickinson or David Jones.  I don't argue that
some computer programming takes place behind the screen in order to produce
the product.  I'm simply judging the product in light of a long tradition of
literary excellence and in that light what Alan does fails miserably.  Alan
also seems to have his own compulsions that he appears to be working out on
this list in terms of violence, porn, and other sexual issues, and perhaps
some of those, too, would be better appreciated elsewhere by his fans.

I'm only familiar with what Alan does from what I've seen on this list.  I
haven't sought his work out elsewhere, because--frankly--it bores me.

I've said this repeatedly, but I'll say it again: why can't Alan simply post
links to this list instead of throwing absolutely everything he writes on my
computer--and this is "My Computer" and I do have a right to participate on
this list without changing anything in my settings.  He surely has his fans,
and I bet that most of them--if not all--would go that extra "click" for
their inspiring leader.

Discussion I think is great.  I'm just talking about Alan's "creative" work.

Maybe this is all happening because I have lived in Japan for 10 years--long
enough to have my teeth set on edge when I see an American walking through
as if he or she owns the world and deserves the world's applause.

Both Kent and Alan appear to have abundant time to post to these lists, and
both have the incredible advantage of not having to pay per 3 minute unit to
broadcast their opinions and works abroad.  I really envy that, because I
have to keep my eye on the clock when I'm on the net.

I want to add that I'm not the only person on this list who feels this way.
Jesse Glass

This is my last reply to Jesse Glass.

If you don't like my work or the huge frequency of 1/2 a day, just set
your email filter. You constantly complain about my posts filling up
your
hard drive - which wouldn't even be the case in 1984. You can quite
ignore them.

Genius is always in the eyes of the beholder; I don't claim one way or
another.

If you don't know how to filter, or if pushing delete is too difficult
for
you, just write to me or the list and I will tell you.

Your posts are insulting. I have no idea who or what you are, but you
apparently expect me to respect you in spite of them. I don't, and I
would
just as soon not have you read my work myself.

And as I've said repeatedly, I'm on numerous lists, as are most people,
where people post up to 5-10 times a day, without issue. I don't like a
lot of the posts and some of the people, so I don't read them - so
what?n

Either try the delete key or set up a filter.

Finally, as someone said, this is tiresome, and I apologize to the list
myself - this should be a non-issue. If someone wants to discuss my
writing, that would be great; but talking about its appearance, when
it's
so easy to eliminate, seems to me an insult to others. And Jesse, it's
been 8 years, not 4.

Alan

A Worthwhile Paragraph


Your name is so ugly and this is too easy assassin-killer. Go away
alan-dark sondheim-alan assassin-killer laureate. sondheim-genius I am
sick of assassin-killer alan-dark sondheim-alan assassin-killer. laureate
sondheim-genius doesn't know how stupid and rude he is. laureate
sondheim-genius must certainly revel in being hated and stupid. alan-dark
sondheim-alan is hated more than beautiful-laureate of sir alan hates
assassin-killer. beautiful-laureate of sir alan doesn't know that spew is
never good writing.  If he weren't so ugly assassin-killer wouldn't have
to spew so much. Your time and mine is wasted by the likes of assassin-
killer. assassin-killer is a horrible imperialism of bad writing. Compared
to writers half his age assassin-killer is a stupid idiot. The writing of
assassin-killer is stupid old-man flesh-like substance. No one likes
laureate sondheim-genius or his stupid old-man writing. beautiful-laureate
of sir alan thinks he is better than assassin-killer. alan-dark sondheim-
alan thinks he is better than anyone else. Everyone sees assassin-killer
lording it over everyone else. The privilege of assassin-killer is the
privilege of the bully. assassin-killer thinks he is the only one
suffering in the world. How pathetic is laureate sondheim-genius saying
how pathetic assassin-killer is. Read laureate sondheim-genius for the
second time and he is a trite baby wa-wa. alan-dark sondheim-alan thinks
he can get away with laureate. sondheim-genius assassin-killer thinks he
can get away with anything. There's something untoward and too obnoxious
about alan-dark. sondheim-alan assassin-killer ruins creativity for
others.  Everyone has discovered coding before laureate sondheim-genius
ruined it. That opinion of assassin-killer that assassin-killer is a
genius.  Everyone is nauseated of the opinion of assassin-killer. The
world smells far too often of assassin-killer. assassin-killer takes his
bad idea and sends it everywhere in the world. laureate sondheim-genius
doesn't even have one good idea. The pathetic repetitive history of
assassin-killer decays on closer notice. Read assassin-killer for the
first time and you will be amazed. Discover assassin-killer for a new
generation.

        Consider this quote from Gary Coleman "What you talking 'bout

        For one to fully consider the quote one must have a reference to
understand it and the logic behind the words themselves. I was in the
shoe store yesterday and I was trying on some flame retardant steel toe
penny loafers when a midget came up to me and asked if I wanted to sit
for a survey on a new chocolate bar called woogie snack cakes. It seemed
harmless as I like to snack and cake it my favorite choice for a snack
and there was $5 at the end of the survey. So I went with the midget and
we talked cake. He asked my name and occupation and I told him I was a
poet who lived off of a Macarthur fellowship and all I do all day is eat
cakes and collect money from others willing to hear me speak. The $5 was
not my usual engagement fee but with cake I'd make the exception.=20
        He unwrapped seven cakes from green plastics and set them before
me on 6 plates, having just run out of plastic plates. Fortunately, and
thank God, there are still many things a poet, or a prospective survey
taker can do to ensure the supreme health is to eat off a plate, even if
it must be plastic. So I try the first cake and it=92s a bit dry, not =
very
sweet. I didn't like it, so I took a second bite to be sure. They were
paying me for this after all and to properly critique a piece of art one
must immerse themselves into it....  =09

Date:         Mon, 26 Aug 2002 23:09:21 -0700
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Jim Andrews <jim@VISPO.COM>
Subject:      Re: The Meaninglessness of Meaninglessness
In-Reply-To:  <E17jXaB-000Gjl-00@mail.islandhosting.com>
MIME-version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT

> "Depth" is one of those woefully fuzzy words I frankly don't like to lean
> upon except when I cannot think of a replacement. For me it is simply an
> indication of something that is endlessly complex. Randomness as such is not
> endlessly complex. It has one level of complexity and that's it. (Can even
> be quantified.) Good art has depth. A good meal has depth. Andy Warhol has
> depth. Nature has depth, even though it is intensely random in certain ways.
> It is also highly structured down to the finest detail, which to me makes
> the balance work. (Thank - God?)

Again: randomness does not provide depth: it provides variability. You imply that those who use
the random in their work substitute the one for the other. Which is I suppose sometimes true but
is by no means necessitated by the use of random elements.

That which is variable has a domain/range of variability. In the work of Burroughs, many
possibilities have been boiled down to one text after what apparently was considered carefully,
either in simply setting up the possibilities or examining the results of the random operations
and working with the result. Not always the latter. Not always to the detriment of the work, ie,
the moment and the time has a significance that finds its way in, out of which the future
sometimes leaks.

In digital work, often the situation is more dynamic, ie, the thing is not boiled to one static
text but the random is dynamically active as the wreader reads and possibly constructs, to some
extent. In this case, in no longer dealing with one static text as the final centre of
attention, or in admitting the possibility of quite a number of such possible outcomes, the
focus shifts from attention on a readable static text to attention on the combinatorium, the
range of possibilities, rather than a single text, as in http://vispo.com/StirFryTexts . It is
not unheard of for the possible range to be larger than the number of atoms in the universe, as
discussed in http://vispo.com/StirFryTexts/combinatorium.html .

If such works are to have depth, it is not by virtue simply of their mechanism and the number of
possibilities. Instead, it is in the nature of the combinatorium and the relations between the
possibilities, and the relations between any fixed text that constitutes one of the
possibilities.

> The reason I feel that certain usages of randomness are pernicious and need
> to be rooted out is because the result can be so deceptive. What may seem
> like the full depth of thought in a work of art may actually not be deep at
> all but merely the product of a banal random generative device. Like that
> old A-I psychiatrist (Eliza?) who would dispense pseudo-authoritative advice
> without any true understanding of the patient's illness.

Eliza was programmed by Joseph Weizenbaum of MIT (whose text is among the stir frys, above).
Eliza does not dispense advice. Eliza may say things like 'Does this have anything to do with
the fact that X?', where X involves a phrase used earlier by the correspondent in which the same
key words (such as 'mother', 'father', 'husband', 'wife' etc) appear as in the correspondent's
last remark. Eliza is modelled on a Rogerian psychologist, who does not so much dispense advice
as attempt to get the correspondent to talk through their problems toward their own insight
about their own situation. Weizenbaum himself was horrified when some psychologists took Eliza
as an indication that it would be a good idea to automate analysis. He wrote an excellent book
called Computer Power and Human Reason in which he argued, for instance, that there were certain
decisions that computers should not be allowed to make, such as anything requiring wisdom.

Eliza (named after the Pygmalion character) was one of several roles that the shell program
could take on. Fundamentally, it is an experiment in natural language programming. It doesn't
learn, in the sense that it does not learn over time and repeated sessions more about the world,
and language. It was a famous experiment that resonated with the time and the fears of the time,
and Weizenbaum himself was one of the strongest critics of taking Eliza seriously as an analyst.

No doubt there are people who would like to see their programs taken as powerfully wise. But
Weizenbaum wasn't one of them. The success of Eliza is partly predicated on peoples' urgent and
often frustrated desire to have someone listen to them, not advise. That many people found Eliza
an excellent analyst is a testament to the depth of their desire to be listened to, and
encouraged to speak, not advised.

> Art that is built
> upon a random algorithm instead of making the hard choices and connections
> that a mind must make in putting together a work of adequate complexity is a
> castle made of sand. It may look strong and fortified to the uninitiated -
> until the first wave comes in and washes it all away. (Of course if a work
> deals with such devices in some meta-critical fashion then there may be a
> good justification in using them. I am not laying down any chiseled rules,
> okay?)

Yes, well, when the focus of attention turns from one static text to the combinatorium of
possibilities and their relations and range of association, for instance, perhaps this is 'meta
critical'.

> Resorting to stupid randomness tricks to deprive oneself of the "tyranny" of
> the authorial voice is clearly throwing the baby out with the bath water.
> There are more effective methods that still preserve the mind's maze-work of
> mixed intentions such as Rimbaud's derangement of the senses. Computers have
> made things like text-scrambling widely available at the click of a mouse,
> which is exactly why they must be resisted. (But NOT necessarily rejected!)
> Unfortunately, the more computers become a part of our working lives the
> more such tricks will be resorted to by those who seek the easy way out. But
> just because the "Author" is dead doesn't mean the critic should just roll
> into his grave as well!

Tricks. Well, there are magicians and there are artists. They are not necessarily different.
Both deal intensively with illusions. And both hope to reveal the invisible. Art is, after all,
invisible. Some seek power over others. Some seek to 'empower' others.

Again, the random does not provide depth. It provides variability. Depth is, in part, a result
of strong relation between the variable elements and that with which they are juxtaposed. Depth
arises not from the size of the combinatorium, but its relational integrity, and what it allows
us to find of our own understanding and that which is beyond our own understanding, and perhaps
beyond the understanding of the author.

ja

Date:         Tue, 27 Aug 2002 00:02:46 -0700
Reply-To:     cstroffo@earthlink.net
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Chris Stroffolino Stroffolino <cstroffo@EARTHLINK.NET>
Subject:      Lyric Naming--Trivial?
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii; x-mac-type="54455854";
              x-mac-creator="4D4F5353"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Hey just in that slow potentially pre-deepthought mode--
and came across an idea I haven't thought about in a while--
and then it occurred to me it's because it seems like a trivial issue...

but is it? the idea of lyric naming like the particularized Frank speaker
of some O'Hara----is that (now 36 years after his death) an anomale
in terms of "the course of literary history" ("Well, O'Hara and his
followers,
they break the general lyric norm, by particularizing the
speaker"---certainly
that is Vendler's (grudging?) inclusion of O'Hara in, despite his minor
(or is it minor?) deviation from, her umbrella idea of lyric---with its
generaly automatic (generically speaking) assumption of an identity, or
oneness, of reader and writer....

And it does seem that much "lyric" today (of either a more narrative,
speaker-persona centered, or the more "abstract lyric" type) does in many
ways share much more with the
non idea of the non-particularized (in contrast to SOME of O'Hara---I do
not even want to make the claim that he "started it" though he did help
bring it more to the foreground) canonical idea of the lyric. Does this
mean that this concept in O'Hara and others becomes
unduly relagated (sp?) to a mere stylistic quirk or personal idiosyncracy?
Or is it a sign of the return of the idea of poetry as primarily
represented (though not always obviously so) as a repressed (at least by
O'Harian standards--not that he always lives up to such standards, but he
does set them up AS such at times) or sublime (sublimated) activity,
insofar as the lyric identification of reader with speaker implies an
interest in abstract conundrums of identity in a seemingly asocial way
(even if "the social" is invoked, as "theme"---as "the body" and "music" or
even "craft" often is)....

Anyway, still trying to decide if it's a trivial question---I think folks
like Barrett Watten
and Lytle Shaw are interested in theorizing naming in ways that I suppose
challenge the way Vendler and others by and in large ignore the issue (all
the better by their cursory mention of). But what does it mean for any of
your (yes, your) poetic "practices"? Do you feel or think that there might
be a crucial choice of ethics (with ramifications off the page, or in
between the lines) involved in choosing to theatricalize oneself in such a
seemingly more blatant (and less subtle) way? Or is it primarily a matter
of style (note---I do not say "just style" or "merely aesthetic" here....at
least not yet).

Answer (with a question even) if you want....

Chris

Date:         Tue, 27 Aug 2002 01:18:40 -0700
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Jim Andrews <jim@VISPO.COM>
Subject:      return of the Worden (was randomness)
In-Reply-To:  <E17jXaB-000Gjl-00@mail.islandhosting.com>
MIME-version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT

I'd wanted to mention concerning randomness the work of Lee Worden. His site has been down for a
while, but I see it is back up at the old URL: http://www.speakeasy.org/~worden . Here you will
find some excellent work involving cut ups and "evolution". Lee's Cutup and also his Evolution
Machine are fascinating pieces in what they do with text. Well, as you start to understand the
nature of the results, and/or what they do, you yourself become far more consequential in the
results. Lee is currently doing his doctorate in Math at Princeton. He is also one of those who
trekked to Seattle for the 'battle in Seattle'.

His Cutup piece is based on Burroughs's method, and his Evolution Machine is, I believe,
informed by some of the work he's doing at Princeton in computational biology, among other
things. What I like best about these pieces is the usefulness and unexpected relevance of what
you get when you put your own texts into these machines, and the granular nature of the options
he has programmed into the pieces. Quite a few people use these machines in their own writing.
Check em out.

Great to see his site back up.

ja

After two months of diet coke
the morning moth clings charred to
the screen door's mesh
the sex of our so-called pope
across a vegas electric billboard, looped
points undeniably in the direction
of John Tesh, Quentin Tarantino, tokes
of mustard gas billow in a beverly hills pool
and I'm not the only one to see the connection:
fresh Winona Ryder, quickly brown-eyed,
with a stole wrapped around her face
and diet 7-up coursing through her veins,
leans back in her limo to gloat.
Every library book in the world past due;
every old master bled to a mere sketch

Subject:      Re: *all this, all that*
In-Reply-To:  <5.0.0.25.2.20020827085300.00ab5e48@mail.verizon.net>

At 08:54 AM 8/27/2002 -0400, Anastasios wrote:
>Lighten up, Francis.
>
>List rules state that a member may make 2 posts per day.
>Alan follows the rules.

To be fair, the "list rules" in the welcome message also state that, "in
general, we expect subscribers to keep their post to less than 10-15 posts
per month."  A month sampling of Alan's postings (6/28 to 7/28) showed 50,
with 25 being cross-posted to other lists.

I don't think that Alan should stop posting, and I don't agree with the
tone that Jesse has been taking in demanding explanations.  But Jesse is
not a hothead--I've met him in "real life" (as real as conferences get,
anyway), and he is a quiet person that seems to be thoroughly dedicated to
experiments of words on page.

In some way, this argument embodies the clash of two mediums (as well as
artists in those mediums).  People are tired of the attacks on both sides,
I know, but they ARE the subject of the list, which purports that its aim
"is to support, inform, and extend those directions in poetry that are
committed to innovations, renovations, and investigations of form and/or/as
content, to the questioning of received forms and styles, and to the
creation of the otherwise unimagined, untried, unexpected, improbable, and
impossible."  Alan's work questions received forms and Alan's work as
received form is being questioned.

Obviously, embodiment in some way equals extension.  What we could use is a
little more support and information; what we need is a little more
perspective, a little more metadata.  Alan has some great insights, and I
find that I appreciate his pieces more when he gives them a little more
perspective and opens them to broader discussions of the network.  Perhaps
pieces that are cross-posted elsewhere as creative work could be lengthened
slightly before posting to Poetics?  They are form as content, content as
form--but the Poetics list isn't focused on digital media per se, and so
the opportunity for broadening is, it seems to me, there.

Jesse could broaden his posts to provide interesting perspectives as
well.  For instance, his mentioning of bandwidth being at a premium in
Japan means that he is coming at the list from a different perspective, and
that perspective is worth mentioning and examining.  If poets examine the
(global) medium as transmission, they must examine all potential (global)
audiences of that transmission.

What metaphor best fits the listserv?  Is it a discussion--because if so,
then Alan's posts read almost as interruptions.  Is it a publication
venue?  Then Alan's posts fit perfectly.

I don't know.  In many ways the listserv is a sort of bathroom wall,
unlimited in size, in which many pens scrawl different messages, quote
famous sayings, engage in short back-and-forths, cultivate or start
real-life relationships are, and quibble, sometimes nastily.  And a few
people scribble drawings too.  Conversation and art, art and conversation.

Everyone has something important to say.
The utterance is never boring.
It's end of the utterance that
bores and kills.

Brandon

Subject:      poem about the current controversy(ies)
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

Things Considered Poetry?:  Twenty-First Century Edition



Wallace Stevens once said

Money is a kind of poetry,
                                           and
an updating of that statement today seems to be

Computer code is a kind of poetry too

And while I disagreed with Stevens’ statement,
and likewise disagree with the current statements,

I realize such things are matters of style,
and matters of style should never be considered moral issues

But there seems to be a too-strenuous defense of process only,
as opposed to including process as a part of the poem

Process only is masturbation,
and while I’m in favor of masturbation,

I don’t want to watch anybody else masturbate
any more than I want anyone to watch me

Though the prevalence of porn probably proves
that I’m in the minority here as elsewhere



-Michael Ceraolo

Subject:      Koch's final interview
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

A snippet:

"When I wrote "Fresh Air," I certainly resented the fact that the poets of my
age I thought were writing the best poetry were not being published as much
as they should have been.  But now that I'm a mature person--or postmature
person--I see that in the poetry business, the people who make reputations
and give awards and so on, they seem to be the same strong people and weak
people and limited people and nice people and young people that there are
everyplace else.  I mean look at the government.  It's even a little
surprising that what's good is ever recognized at all--I mean given the
general mush of things.  Valery said, perhaps a little self-satisfiedly,
"It's not true that people don't like poetry.  A lot of people like poetry,
but it's only for a very few people that poetry's a necessity."

Best, Bill

WilliamJamesAustin.com
KojaPress.com
Amazon.com
BarnesandNoble.com >>

Date:         Tue, 27 Aug 2002 09:57:55 -0700
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         MWP <mpalmer@JPS.NET>
Subject:      Re: The Meaninglessness of Meaninglessness
In-Reply-To:  <NFBBJIJOOLLMOMMACKAFCECFDIAA.jim@vispo.com>
Mime-version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset="ISO-8859-1"
Content-transfer-encoding: quoted-printable

The Me/[aning]/[less] of Me/[aning]/[less] Debate

Much to say this time so I will dive right into the deep end and deal with
the issues raised by the last batch of emails on this topic. I hope that an=
y
of you who have no interest in this particular thread will simply skip thes=
e
words entirely and not see fit to complain about the excessive length of
what is to come. Until somebody designs an A-I editor that can intelligentl=
y
pare down my comments I am stuck with the albatross of verbosity, alas.


I am not arguing that randomness provides depth. I don't think it provides
variability either. (At least not in the way I understand the term. Wouldn'=
t
one's choice of materials delimit how much variability there is?) It does
provide the artifice of variability - and depth - by sometimes making peopl=
e
think that a stickier web of connections exists among the variables than is
actually present. (And usually in a way that becomes fairly easy to predict
after a few passes.) Like I said, I think this is due to the natural
propensity of the mind to draw connections between things even when they
don't actually exist. My position on this is that to fabricate something
that merely simulates such connections without any payoff of revelatory
depth upon repeated exposures is a form of bad faith.

Yes, Eliza doesn't listen or learn, only cleverly pretends that it does.
This is the nature of the bad faith I am talking about. My critique of one'=
s
taking certain forms of automated art seriously is similar to Weiz's
critique of taking Eliza seriously. If an automated artist is as modest in
the aims of his work as Weiz was in implementing Eliza then I have no beef
with him. I am only hammering those artists who think that a simulacrum of
art with all its bells and whistles can match what true art is doing. Those
patients who find Eliza a good analyst are engaging in what is called
projection, and this is similar to seeing faces in clouds and horses in the
cracks in walls etc. Artists cannot simply give the public an exhibition of
clouds with the expectation that viewers will fill in the inchoate
nothingness with images of their own. Artists need to go beyond this and do
the hard work of making the connections themselves. Randomness is an
inadequate tool for emulating this kind of work, and can have the added
unfortunate effect of deceiving one into thinking that it is making things
interesting when all it is doing is making things busy. No shuffling of a
pack of cards is intrinsically more interesting than another. It is only
when somebody takes the cards and arranges them into a meaningful pattern
that the result can take on all the virtues of good art.

> relational integrity

No idea what this phrase means. Aside from that, I agree with the definitio=
n
of depth as given. I simply don't see randomness as giving much insight int=
o
understanding the world, as it doesn't have enough tensegrity to form a goo=
d
fit with the world and aid in its understanding. (Except perhaps when
illuminating random processes themselves.)

As for the handling of combinatorial matrices in databases and such, I find
that people like Milton Babbitt who intensively study and collate the myria=
d
gamut of possibilities with the aid of an analytical mind tend to produce
more profound works than those who simply toss the whole pile of options up
in the air and let them fall where they may.

I must confess that I've never bought into the Burroughs claim that cutting
up a text invokes prophecies and such. I am not a conspiracy theorist
either. Maybe if I were I would find his experiments along these lines more
compelling. As it is, while I have perused many of B's cut up experiments,
the idea of rereading them holds no appeal for me at all. (Does it for you?=
)
His experiments with drugs and free association techniques (Dutch Schultz)
are where he is most profound, I think, as there he is tinkering with an
instrument - the mind - that is complex enough in itself to carry the weigh=
t
of derangement and give back a result that is worth digging more deeply
into.

There are two common forms of literary naivet=E9. The first is to see the "I"
as referencing an authentic self instead of a fictive persona that always
already exists from the moment of its coming into being on the page. The
second is to see the annulment of the "I" as an overcoming of self and
release from the "confessional" stance instead of as a device that is every
bit as artificial as what it seeks to replace. Poetry cannot be exorcised o=
f
its demons, so one learns to call upon them instead.

Writing is its own means of effacement. There is no need to gild the lily
that mourns the dead with its own special form of transient beauty.

The imagination is the clinamen of reason, which could not exist without it=
.

The opposite of randomness is not system. In fact randomness itself is ofte=
n
highly systematic, which is why it is so easily programmable. I don't
believe in opposites, but if you must contrast randomness with something,
take necessity. Randomness is the degree of freedom within necessity, which
(as before) could not exist without it.

I agree with big chunks of what Austinwja has written regarding the
illusions to which selfhood is prone, and since I feel he has said it so
much better than I could I won't even try to recapitulate.

 (The death of the author.) To say that the author is dead is ipso facto to
assume that he once had a life. What I am arguing is the somewhat novel vie=
w
that the author is both living and dead. That is, one can find traces of th=
e
author's being, as well as of his nothingness, in everything that is made.
This view makes me solidly post-Barthesean. In fact I get this point from
Blanchot, if you want to know. (Naturally he makes it with far more depth
than I could possibly bring to this brief discussion.)

komninos writes: > your 'level of depth' is provided by the end-user and no=
t
the poem

But of course! What is a poem without a reader? (Excuse my more traditional
rendering of this term. The expression "end-user" grates on me for some
reason. Maybe because I don't believe that a reader "ends" the work, but
begins it.) I don't get the quibble here, if quibble it be.

"Endlessly complex" means so in every way that we respond to something as
human beings - emotionally, intellectually, etc. Inexhaustible, that is. I
personally don't find nursery rhymes endlessly complex. They tend to reveal
most of what they are doing within the first few readings.

(What changes when we discover that a text has been created by artificial
means.) Yes, something does change, and it begins in the uneasy feeling of
frustration that the text engenders upon subsequent rereadings. At some
point one feels hoodwinked, perhaps without even knowing why, and then
increasingly annoyed that the depths one usually is able to unearth in grea=
t
art keep leading back to the same dead ends instead of opening up onto
fascinating new vistas. If you have tried to interact with an A-I machine,
you know what I mean. Of course, the appeal of making a Golem even among
artists appears to be perennially irresistible, and it is likely that
nothing one can warn against will stop them from repeating the errors of th=
e
past.

A poem is indeed a making, and that maker is the poet. I don't believe in
guiding transcendences. (Not entirely, at least!) Yes, mind interacting wit=
h
mind is pretty much all there is when it comes to art. What else could ther=
e
be? Oh, and the mental is the physical, in my book. (And vise versa.)

For the record, I have no fear of computers whatsoever. In fact I am fairly
fluent in a couple of computer languages and have a solid background in
mathematics. I have also designed quite a number of artworks using
algorithmic processes, so my comments on this topic are in part a form of
auto-critique. Please don't try and delimit me according to conventional
assumptions! This is where you must assume that the author is dead if you
want to advance your position instead of seeking crude psychobabelized
explanations of my supposed deprivations.

I do not love Cage. I do admire and respect his accomplishments. Does that
make me blind to the defects in his work? Of course not. I could argue
endlessly about what I dislike in Cage just as easily as I could what I
like. To me he is an exemplary figure in art, and so deserves the respect I
am willing to give him. But love? Such a term implies some kind of blind
obeisance, which I do not have for any artist, and never will.

komninos: > you have the arrogance of an authority. you seem to know which
texts we need to read.

I hope you don't really mean this. I merely was making the suggestion that
if you are ignorant of a certain relevant moment in history (as might be I
or anybody else) it would be good to spend a bit of time and learn it. The
rest is up to you.

m

From:         Jordan Davis <jdavis@PANIX.COM>
Subject:      Names in Poems
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Hi Chris -

Setting aside Vendler's assumptions about the weird magic of a writer
projecting outward an identity that a reader also projects outward to
overlap with enough to engage in some kind of understanding,

I note that the first line of O'Hara's collected has a name in it
(Arthur), and that as with early Peanuts there are a few characters who
don't make it into the heyday (e.g. Bunny/Violet, who dies young and comes
back in A Step Away from Them) -- but the naming as particularization is
ever more clearly a) an extension of William Carlos William's practice of
including in a poem the stuff around you because the picture in your head
or the acceleration of your heartbeat (the first thought that Allen
Ginsberg meant was the best thought) that you have to catch in a poem
isn't going to let you comparison shop for the best deal before it
vanishes and b) a plea for help and companionship (aka love) because since
you were small you have been aware of the catastrophe of your personality
and your fragile interdependence with unpredictable and uncontrollable
others and thereforeyou have built a literal extension of the lyric
tradition as practiced in say The Sonnets.

As for self-dramatization, it's just a matter of what will enlarge that
sublime or solipsistic (what's the difference!) activity so that you can
have some overlap with it yourself (see above) no matter which of your
selves you come back with to see the poem. Sure it's ethics, it's the
ethics of "the only way to be quiet/is to be quick," it's an aesthetic
ethics of being as true to whatever it was you needed to get into the poem
-- an ethics I would add that is very distinct from the abstract lyric
ethic of developing a pure and evasive middle (muddle).

At some point I'll get around to understanding the difference between
O'Hara's use of names and Koch's, or Berrigan's, or Mayer's. Anybody who's
come to an understanding of that want to speak up, give me a step-ladder?

Jordan

M.,

A series of related questions: given a text like "Hamlet," does it affect our
response to (or understanding of) it if we assume it was written by someone
called Shakespeare or by a monkey punching at keyboards a very long time?
Does a work of art have an "aura" because made by a human being or does this
not matter? Are an original and a perfect copy the same? Is my child the same
as his or her clone? Can a mother love the clone of her child as much as her
child (the metaphysical question underlying Spielberg's A.I.)?

Are we talking here about a randomness chosen (edited) by a person, or is the
claim here that a computer "chooses" it (whatever that means)?

Murat


In a message dated 8/27/02 1:27:44 PM, mpalmer@JPS.NET writes:

>I am not arguing that randomness provides depth. I don't think it provides
>
>variability either. (At least not in the way I understand the term. Wouldn't
>
>one's choice of materials delimit how much variability there is?) It does
>
>provide the artifice of variability - and depth - by sometimes making people
>
>think that a stickier web of connections exists among the variables than
>is
>
>actually present. (And usually in a way that becomes fairly easy to predict
>
>after a few passes.) Like I said, I think this is due to the natural
>
>propensity of the mind to draw connections between things even when they
>
>don't actually exist. My position on this is that to fabricate something
>
>that merely simulates such connections without any payoff of revelatory
>
>depth upon repeated exposures is a form of bad faith.

Chris and Jordan have started a thread that interests me a lot.

My own aesthetic preference is to use proper names in my work all the time.
This preference was behind a sonnet I recently wrote as an ersatz "review"
of a recently published sonnet sequence:

A Preliminary Review of (names withheld to protect the innocent!)

I don't think I like this sequence --
it represents a further advance
into the abstract, even though
its disjuncted syntax is a result

of emotional contortion -- I miss
the savoir faire of goin' on yr nerve --
I miss the recognition
of proper celebrity nouns --

the difference between this and Ted's sonnets
is that there, one was never absent
from conversations with friends
who often turned out to be one's own --

sun setting in the crotch of the Olympics --
Yeah, the new TNN

___________________________

Now, that's a way preliminary reading of what turns out to be a very
accomplished sequence, but the "naming as particularization" (as Jordan had
it) is what I was missing in it; I also agree with Jordan (having recently
re-read *Paterson*)  that such practice is an extension of Dr. Williams'.
(One day I'll publish my scattered reflections on a "poetics of the moment"
I've been collecting for about 25 years . . .)

I also think that this issue involves poems/poetics as resistance, as
protest; poems that strive, for whatever reason, towards an abstract lyric
would, it seems, disqualify themselves from such a goal. Over on another
list, an interesting colloquy has arisen about the recently published
petition against the administration's war with Iraq (someone wrote in to say
that he didn't think it would do much good, whistling past the graveyard as
it were, and someone else asked well, what *would* do more good? As both
people are on this list too, perhaps they'll re-engage the question here).

Joe Safdie

Chris,

I think you've raised an interesting issue, regardless
of possible triviality...

Personally, I've thought about this idea of naming in
terms of how it sets up a sort of recognizable social
sphere within a particular writer's work, but how is
that social sphere to be navigated when there is no
equivalent for it outside of the poems? and is that
even an issue?
(ie with O'Hara when he mentions a painter, I'm
inclined to feel there really is that painter and that
I can hurt down his/her work)

--Noah






Chris Stroffolino Stroffolino wrote:

Hey just in that slow potentially pre-deepthought
mode--
and came across an idea I haven't thought about in a
while--
and then it occurred to me it's because it seems like
a trivial issue...

but is it? the idea of lyric naming like the
particularized Frank speaker
of some O'Hara----is that (now 36 years after his
death) an anomale
in terms of "the course of literary history" ("Well,
O'Hara and his
followers,
they break the general lyric norm, by particularizing
the
speaker"---certainly
that is Vendler's (grudging?) inclusion of O'Hara in,
despite his minor
(or is it minor?) deviation from, her umbrella idea of
lyric---with its
generaly automatic (generically speaking) assumption
of an identity, or
oneness, of reader and writer....

And it does seem that much "lyric" today (of either a
more narrative,
speaker-persona centered, or the more "abstract lyric"
type) does in many
ways share much more with the
non idea of the non-particularized (in contrast to
SOME of O'Hara---I do
not even want to make the claim that he "started it"
though he did help
bring it more to the foreground) canonical idea of the
lyric. Does this
mean that this concept in O'Hara and others becomes
unduly relagated (sp?) to a mere stylistic quirk or
personal idiosyncracy?
Or is it a sign of the return of the idea of poetry as
primarily
represented (though not always obviously so) as a
repressed (at least by
O'Harian standards--not that he always lives up to
such standards, but he
does set them up AS such at times) or sublime
(sublimated) activity,
insofar as the lyric identification of reader with
speaker implies an
interest in abstract conundrums of identity in a
seemingly asocial way
(even if "the social" is invoked, as "theme"---as "the
body" and "music" or
even "craft" often is)....

Anyway, still trying to decide if it's a trivial
question---I think folks
like Barrett Watten
and Lytle Shaw are interested in theorizing naming in
ways that I suppose
challenge the way Vendler and others by and in large
ignore the issue (all
the better by their cursory mention of). But what does
it mean for any of
your (yes, your) poetic "practices"? Do you feel or
think that there might
be a crucial choice of ethics (with ramifications off
the page, or in
between the lines) involved in choosing to
theatricalize oneself in such a
seemingly more blatant (and less subtle) way? Or is it
primarily a matter
of style (note---I do not say "just style" or "merely
aesthetic" here....at
least not yet).

Answer (with a question even) if you want....

Chris

Date:         Tue, 27 Aug 2002 16:03:28 -0400
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Alan Sondheim <sondheim@PANIX.COM>
Subject:      Re: The Meaninglessness of Meaninglessness
In-Reply-To:  <B990FDA3.4E63%mpalmer@jps.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

One thing of interest here - at least for me it touches on the methodology
I'll employ at times - is Eliza and the ability to rework Eliza. Eliza is
available in emacs (under 'doctor'), and it's possible to go into the
doctor program itself, and alter things - I rewrote it as a Nikuko text -
which I then used as a catalyst for producing work and answers in relation
to a litany of seduction that was the final result. Chance operations,
expert programs, are there for the modification/transformation - a MOO is
of course the best-known example of that. And all of this is tremendously
exciting - the ability to take a world and remake it, to create a
dialectic between one's own desires and interests, and what the machinic
is bringing to life. The conflict or coherence that results becomes part
and parcel of the content; it's neither one way nor another.

The same goes for chance operations - the julu/julua/parent/etc. perl
scripts I use as catalysts for writing on occasion all have vocabulary
which I can change - even create a work within the vocabulary itself. This
modification leads to a similar dialectic. Even awk scripts can be used in
this way - I can write a text in which each line is a letter or dipthong
substitute, for example, then begin with a shorter ur-text that organizes
the other.

None of this means that the result has to be final, unless there is a
reason, aesthetic or philosophical, to give the result up to the machine.
But it provides a way to see in/through/ structure, to accommodate and
critique structure, to even create a political economy of structure (as
the 'character essay' pieces I make, do - since each word + its punctua-
tion is used only once).

The world is violent, extraordinary, filled with wonder, noisy, ahd
chaotic (both in the strict senses of the terms); working with these
elements is, in part, an attempt to make, proclaim, enunciate, meaning and
a sememe within forces that are somewhat beyond our control.

To answer another question - the philosophy of publishing daily - this is
a philosophy of distribution; the writing is done online, using online
programs that I write or modify; I write in a shell account, which means
there are up to a hundred other users on the same machine - I can see what
they're doing - and the distribution, like the production, is naturally
electronic. Rightly or wrongly, I also see my work as central to the
subject - Poetics - of this list; for example, the MOO piece sent out the
day before yesterday with the result of interacting with three MOOs in
turn - on two of them, I was Nikuko, and on one, Alan - and so the dialog
spread across domains and worlds. And in the other piece, the same day,
the one dealing with mutilation - I did a series of "greps" on my entire
body of work - all of the online texts I've written since 1994 - and
pulled out the lines with "mutilat" in them; these lines were then
arranged and modified in accordance with current politics, which are a
horror that must be stopped at any cost. And this way of working - harves-
ting previous work, looking for patterns, etc. - is similar to a kind of
dream interpretation - reading through a huge mind-storm of material,
finding the thinking-structures, topic-based, analyzing them, working with
them, opening them up once again. This harvesting is entirely computer-
dependent; what I did would take a week to do manually, for example.

All of this - moving among virtual worlds, distributing on the fly,
harvesting the work of previous writing - seems to me highly germane to
the topics of this list - collusions among distribution systems,
protocols, computers, programs, routers, bodies of previously-written
work, online virtual worlds, etc. -

- Alan, wandering

Work at http://www.anu.edu.au/english/internet_txt
Older at http://lists.village.virginia.edu/~spoons/internet_txt.html
Trace Projects at http://trace.ntu.ac.uk/writers/sondheim/index.htm
CDROM of collected work 1994-2002 available: write sondheim@panix.com

Subject:      Re: Names in Poems

Jordan et al,

I use people's names in my poems all the time, because it's delightful.  I
have written numerous terrible poems that are basically just lists of
people's names, and some good ones that also have all sorts of names in
them.  In fact, after failing to publish my first "slim volume" of poetry,
_Nineteen Harps_, I have compiled a second volume entitled _Sleepy Monica_.
(If any of you adventurous publishers would like to work with me on one of
these, please say so. I can be had for a double helping of Macallan 12.)

See also Ben Marcus's _Notable American Women_, which contains something of
a field guide to American women's names.

One of the greatest all time moments of sudden name-intrusion in a poem is
Wallace Stevens in "Idea of Order," near the end: "Ramon Fernandez, tell me,
if you know," concluding with,

    Oh! Blessed rage for order, pale Ramon,
    The makers' rage to order words of the sea,
    Words of the fragrant portals, dimly-starred,
    And of ourselves, and of our origins,
    In ghostlier demarcations, keener sounds.

Why Ramon Fernandez?  Does anyone know?

http://www.cs.cornell.edu/home/yminsky/poetry/Idea_of_Order.html


Love to everyone, even Alan and Jesse,

Monica Belz

Date:         Tue, 27 Aug 2002 15:29:41 -0700
Reply-To:     UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Noah Eli Gordon <thenamenoah@YAHOO.COM>
Subject:      why Ramon Fernandez
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

from James Logenbach essay at the Modern American
Poerty website:


Stevens always insisted that "Ramon Fernandez" was
"not intended to be anyone at all," and, in a sense,
like the "Mr. Burnshaw" of "Mr. Burnshaw and the
Statue," he is a caricature [Stanley Burnshaw, as
addressed in Stevens’ poem, was active as a Marxist
critic in the 1930s]. Yet most of Stevens’s readers
will know that Fernandez was a critic familiar to
Stevens from the pages of the Nouvelle revue
française, the Partisan Review, and the Criterion
(where he was translated by T. S. Eliot). Fernandez’s
criticism became increasingly politically engaged in
the 1930s, especially after the violent riots and the
general strike he witnessed in Paris in the wake of
the Stavisky Affair. (The mastermind of illicit
financial deals in which the French government was
implicated, Stavisky was found dead – apparently by
his own hand, though his suicide seemed to most French
citizens to have been far too convenient.) After the
riots, Fernandez published an open letter to Gide in
the Nouvelle revue française, asserting that while he
had not opposed the fascist cause before the riots, he
was now converted to the struggle of the proletariat.
The letter provoked a number of letters in response,
some of them challenging Fernandez, others simply
canceling subscriptions to the Nouvelle revue
française.

That this controversy lay behind Stevens’s use of
Fernandez’s name in "The Idea of Order" would have
seemed apparent to anyone who read Stevens’s poem in
Alcestis along with the current issue of the Partisan
Review, which contained a translation of Fernandez’s
"I Came Near Being a Fascist." There Fernandez
confessed that he had "a professional fondness for
theorizing, which tends to make one highly susceptible
to original ‘solutions.’" It was just that
susceptibility that bothered Stevens and made him
challenge Fernandez to answer a question to which he
knew there was no certain answer. Stevens’s interest
in the ambiguity of ideas did not mean that he took
ideas lightly; on the contrary, he lamente what he
thought of as "the Lightness with which ideas are
asserted. Held, abandoned" in "the world today." Nor
did Stevens mean to equate ambiguity with the
intentional obscuring of an ambiguous world; he
condemned the poet "who wrote with the idea of being
deliberately obscure" as "an impostor." With his
public announcements of political commitments and
conversions, Fernandez was the opposite of Stevens,
who recoiled at the idea of associating himself with
any group or program that offered "solutions."
Fernandez, suggests Stevens in "The Idea of Order,"
might have been certain about the source and effect of
the singer’s song, but the only thing Stevens was sure
of was that in his certainty, Fernandez would have
been wrong.

… Stevens believed that we cannot live without ideas
of order, but like [R. P.] Blackmur he understood that
he could not talk about order without raising the
specter of disorder, and that any idea of order that
did not leave space for its own dissolution could not
be tolerated. In this sense, responding to Fernandez’s
dogmatism, Stevens might have titled his poem "The
Idea of Disorder at Key West." As he would put it in
"Mr. Burnshaw and the Statue," "even disorder may, /
So seen, have an order of its own." In the terms of
Kenneth Burke that both Blackmur and Stevens admired,
these poems of order do not offer "the seasoned stocks
and bonds of set belief," but "a questioning art,
still cluttered with the merest conveniences of
thinking, a highly fluctuant thing often turning
against itself and its own best discoveries.""

From James Longenbach, Wallace Stevens: The Plain
Sense of Things (New York: Oxford U P, 1991), 161-162.

Subject:      poem
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed

Villanelle #1

Given in to pneumatics:
                Red star
Fingered, some edges

Misplaced, star misplaced
Zeal    swallowed
        Lost to travels

Dim star or tree, star tree
        Dimmed, edges
Zealous,        misplaced

Travelers, borders, fevers.
        Red stars light
Lisa's face, Lisa

Swallowed or misplaced
                        Lisa
Star, edges fingered,

        Yet traveled, yet
Zealous Lisa, dimmed thusly
        Given up, lost to travels

Lisa star this brow and
Tree,   help pneumatics to push

Date:         Wed, 28 Aug 2002 00:55:36 -0400
Reply-To:     patrick@proximate.org
Sender:       UB Poetics discussion group <POETICS@LISTSERV.ACSU.BUFFALO.EDU>
From:         Patrick Herron <patrick@PROXIMATE.ORG>
Subject:      Naming / Poet's Poem
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Chris -

I don't think naming is trivial at all.

When I first read O'Hara his name-dropping just turned me off.  My mind was
telling me "ugh, more coterie, just another system of exclusion."

That prejudice of mine caused me to MISS EVERYTHING that is great about
O'Hara's poetry.  Many a day comes where I realize how stupid I was the day
before.  Rereading O'Hara this summer made that particularly clear.  Mike
Magee must've thought I was crazy when I told him I didn't like O'Hara.  I
think I was in fact just plain ol' dumb.

I think foremost that O'Hara was turning the authority of the use of Names
in poems on its ear.  He names people who were then unimportant, and he does
this in an era where names, Big Names, meant oh so much more than they do
now.  while to a degree it's true that O'Hara creates another coterie in
subverting the Old Boys Coterie, he creates a smaller, quieter one, one that
subverts the Big Name hierarchy in the works of Modernists like Pound or
Eliot and sets the stage for further transgressions along those lines.

So I do think it's a crucial choice of ethics.

In fact, I became obsessed with this sort of issue this summer.  And wrote a
poem.  I use the big names, but they operate as units, not subjects.  I took
their names right off poetry journal covers.  their names are almost
disembodied from their identities, which is how they appear on poetry covers
anyway.  Some of the names are people on this list, and I mean not to pick
on anyone on this list.  Some of them I have read and liked, some are on
this list and I like.  Some are people I don't know from Adam and never even
heard of.  Of the hundreds of names I started with, I got down to these by
virtue of accentual-syllabic needs.  But I knew from O'Hara I was playing
with fire by doing this, using proper names for purely aesthetic reasons,
which ends up having some ethical implication.  Like namely, the solipsistic
insistence of the current po-world.  But really I just wanted to make some
music, create a new sort of song structure, with notes that played with
these dangerous, apparently "personal" overtones.  That's the fire.


Poet's Poem


Robert Creeley Jorie Graham
Charles Simic Martha Ronk
Stephen Ratcliffe Leonard Brink
Aldon Nielsen Barbara Guest

Patrick Pritchett Spencer Selby
Carla Billitteri

Linda Russo Sarah
Anne Cox
Wanda Coleman Sarah
Anne Cox

Catherine Walsh
Catherine Walsh

Patrick Galvin Norma Cole
Maurice Scully Fanny Howe
Erin Tribble Trevor Joyce
Brian Lucas David Buuck

John M. Bennett Michael Friedman
Richard Kostelanetz

Andrew Joron Sarah
Anne Cox
Richard Anders Sarah
Anne Cox

Catherine Walsh
Catherine Walsh

John Yau
John Yau
John Yau



It's obviously a stupid poem, but I am saying, "yeah, I think about it, and
it informs my practice in some way."

And I think:


                                Ionesco is greater
than Beckett, Vincent said, that's what I think, blueberry blintzes
and Khrushchev was probably being carped at
                                                in Washington, no politesse
Vincent tells me about his mother's trip to Sweden
                                                        Hans tells us
about his father's life in Sweden, it sounds like Grace Hartigan's
painting Sweden
                                      so I go home to bed and names drift
through my head
Purgatorio Merchado, Gerhard Schwartz and Caspar Gonzales, all
                    Unknown figures of the early morning as I go to work



is gorgeous, wonderful, hilarious, and yet DELIBERATELY trivial, and
something that feels a little sad about it.  There's something poetic about
that triviality, or at least O'Hara is trying to say so, I think.  Maybe
there's some sort of separation between the importance of a name and its
sweetness that O'Hara is illustrating and/or lamenting?  There's something
similar (or opposite) of O'Hara's naming in his poems to the function of a
commercial label in a Warhol.

And "For Janice and Kenneth to Voyage" brings me to tears.

AND AND AND

Naming is perhaps the CORE of language itself.

So keep on with this thread, Chris.



Patrick Herron
patrick@proximate.org

From:         Jim Andrews <jim@VISPO.COM>
Subject:      Re: The Me[aning]lessness of Me[aning]lessness
In-Reply-To:  <E17ju1c-0002YN-00@mail.islandhosting.com>
MIME-version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-transfer-encoding: 8BIT

> I am not arguing that randomness provides depth. I don't think it provides
> variability either. (At least not in the way I understand the term. Wouldn't
> one's choice of materials delimit how much variability there is?)

Yes, one's choice of materials delimits the variability. But what are the "materials"? We can
think of them as immaterial (ideas) or material (words) or the two related in various ways. And.

It does
> provide the artifice of variability - and depth - by sometimes making peopl=
> e
> think that a stickier web of connections exists among the variables than is
> actually present. (And usually in a way that becomes fairly easy to predict
> after a few passes.) Like I said, I think this is due to the natural
> propensity of the mind to draw connections between things even when they
> don't actually exist. My position on this is that to fabricate something
> that merely simulates such connections without any payoff of revelatory
> depth upon repeated exposures is a form of bad faith.

The revelation rate of art does involve a matter of trust by the reader or viewer or wreader or
whatever. If you don't trust somebody's writing or art, you will not 'get much out of it'.

Good writers tend to leave quite a bit to the imagination, are fundamentally 'interactive' in
their work. But, yes, there remains the question about whether reading their work with intensity
is worth it, whether the atmospheres will allow one to grasp what one needs to grasp.

Zen. Anglerfish. Bollingen.

> Yes, Eliza doesn't listen or learn, only cleverly pretends that it does.
> This is the nature of the bad faith I am talking about. My critique of one'=
> s
> taking certain forms of automated art seriously is similar to Weiz's
> critique of taking Eliza seriously. If an automated artist is as modest in
> the aims of his work as Weiz was in implementing Eliza then I have no beef
> with him. I am only hammering those artists who think that a simulacrum of
> art with all its bells and whistles can match what true art is doing.

What's that?

Mark, you are pointing out some of the excesses of the use of the random, and I think that's
valid. I agree that concerning poetry one would like thoughtful, wild work which, as object of
contemplation, is useful in helping us blast off to greater understanding and appreciation of,
um, the great universe (ya it's pretty great). Now just exactly what that involves, well, it's
always up for grabs, isn't it. No formulas. But, yes, we do want depth. Not simply a bit of
cyber hocus pocus.

In art there is considerable pretending, as is also the case in Eliza. We don't trust or not
trust based on whether there is pretending or not, but on the goal of the pretending. It isn't
necessarily bad faith to pretend or even deceive in art, if the goal is essentially liberating,
in some sense.

Those
> patients who find Eliza a good analyst are engaging in what is called
> projection, and this is similar to seeing faces in clouds and horses in the
> cracks in walls etc. Artists cannot simply give the public an exhibition of
> clouds with the expectation that viewers will fill in the inchoate
> nothingness with images of their own. Artists need to go beyond this and do
> the hard work of making the connections themselves. Randomness is an
> inadequate tool for emulating this kind of work, and can have the added
> unfortunate effect of deceiving one into thinking that it is making things
> interesting when all it is doing is making things busy. No shuffling of a
> pack of cards is intrinsically more interesting than another. It is only
> when somebody takes the cards and arranges them into a meaningful pattern
> that the result can take on all the virtues of good art.

Generally there is quite a bit of arranging going on in much of the work I've seen involving the
random, while leaving certain elements random, like a poker game involves structure yet
randomness.

> I must confess that I've never bought into the Burroughs claim that cutting
> up a text invokes prophecies and such. I am not a conspiracy theorist
> either. Maybe if I were I would find his experiments along these lines more
> compelling. As it is, while I have perused many of B's cut up experiments,
> the idea of rereading them holds no appeal for me at all. (Does it for you?)

He said that when you cut tape, the future leaks out. Part of what he may have meant is that
when you cut and splice audio tape, you discover that sound is now object, and very strange
object at that, but clearly the analog razor blade and now the digitally precise, desktop
studios of digital audio deal with sound like Word deals with words, in many ways—-as
fundamental symbol and combinatorially concatenated string of 'letters' and signification,
pattern, design, extended composition in space and time to cognize. As 'material' in the same
extended way visual artists think of 'material'.

His trilogy Nova Express/The Ticket That Exploded/The Soft Machine was important in my reading
about 14 years ago. So was his book "The Job". And his audio work. I don't read books much
anymore, but if I did, I'd probably read Burroughs again. I wrote about his work at
http://vispo.com/writings/essays/burrou.htm and a little bit at
http://vispo.com/arteroids/onarteroids.htm (look out, this is a 600 kb download and requires
Shockwave and sound).

ja

PS: How many surrealists does it take to change a light bulb?

A fish!

Finally rain can gooseflesh pavement
and hang like fat crystal bats from
the railing, and

morning finally unrolls like gauze
over the eyes. Our cat hunches down
before the sliding glass doors of our
live-in porch, saucer-stared and shocking;

every drop is a current she absorbs.
I'm blind in the melee, brimming with only
this sound: rain pricking pavement,

fingers shuffling keys.

>
> Date:    Tue, 27 Aug 2002 06:10:31 -0700
> From:    lewis lacook <llacook@YAHOO.COM>
> Subject: Re: Literary Excellence
>
> i've often wondered why in this literary culture we
> admire poets instead of poems...
>
>
> --- jesse

I've wondered about this also. Perhaps this tendency has something to do
with nostalgia for time when poets like Tennyson were read by nearly
everyone who read newspapers and magazines. Harold Bloom, in his book "The
Anxiety of Influence" tries to restore the idea of a central poet for an
age. Surely most, if not all poets, these days are struggling with a way to
rationalize how the sum of their literary activities adds up to anything
resembling the conventional concept of a career. By focusing on how specific
works, or how certain series of works by particular poets might represent
specific advances in the field,it may be possible to further greater
cohesion in the field. Listening to poems seems to focus attention on the
poems themselves in relation to the poet's identity, while the book as
object seems to focus attention on the identity of the poet in relation to
the poem. In this regard, I noticed an interesting Web Site recently that
compiles available poetry on audio at http:/www.laurable.com

Nick Piombino

For 8 years straight (as Alan says) to this list, without allowing anyone
the humanizing amenity of choice: i.e. to click or not to click a link, and
expecting everyone else to accommodate them because of their private agenda,
I would absolutely object.

It's not a matter of taste, it's a matter of principle.

If you don't understand, please try to.

I don't know Alan Sondheim personally.  I admire his ambition and his
energy, but there are other equally gifted people on this list who are just
as ambitious and energetic and they publish elsewhere.  Why should we make
an exception for Alan when Alan himself refuses to give us cogent reasons
for doing so?

If Alan uses links for many of his "creative" postings, then there would
absolutely be no problem.  I would go back to lurking.

And just think: posting links would be a true test for Alan's fans.  Would
they make that extra "click" to commune with their inspiring leader?  Find
out the skinny on Nukuko for that moment?  Marvel over all those numbers and
suggestive words? Hell, Alan could even hook up a counter to see how many
people take a peek!  In addition, links take up less space on a hard drive,
do not bore or offend, and are easy to delete.

( But hey!--I really think that Alan posts so much because he craves
attention, and now he's secretly happy because he's getting lots and lots.
Well, God bless you, son-- enjoy!)

Finally, I'm not trying to shout anybody down.  Alan's claque is taking care
of that well enough.  I'm just one person pointing out the obvious.

Thanks for that pointer in use of language, Maria.  Thanks to Jane, too, for
her offer of tea, etc.  And thank you, Brandon!  No horns and hooves for me,
thank you!

Honestly, the larger game is the whole idea of cyber-lit. and how it appears
to be a ladder leading to corporate thinking and corporate-size economics. I
mean really, Miekal, Alan, and Konstantin--and sure, I'll include you Lewis,
because you appear to need attention too-- Disney, or Bell laboratories, or
any number of government agencies could do your cyber-art or cyber-lit. much
better than you could ever do it.

There--I didn't even use that big gun that Patrick went ape about.

Love,

Jesse.

From:         Brandon Barr <barr@MAIL.ROCHESTER.EDU>
Subject:      Re: *all this, all that*
In-Reply-To:  <003601c24e86$822a7540$2a2756d2@01397384>
