> Nick Piombino wrote:
> Surely most, if not all poets, these days are struggling with a way to
> rationalize how the sum of their literary activities adds up to
> anything resembling the conventional concept of a career. By focusing on how
> specific works, or how certain series of works by particular poets might
> represent specific advances in the field, it may be possible to further
> greater cohesion in the field.
>
> These were the key sentences in his post. Some responses miss his point,
> which was to pick up his previous thread about the 'progress of poesie', and
> to rescue the rhetoric of 'excellence' 'quality' etc. from the forces of
> reaction, division,  etc and place it within  field of discussion whose
> terms contribute to a greater sense of cohesion and common purpose. I think
> he proposes a relation between 'career' (the sum of your literary
> activities) not only to the 'field' of poetry, but to its 'progress' that
> can be talked about without falling into talk of careerism, elitism, or
> vanguardism. Science was offered as a 'field'  in which this was possible.
> The two threads, which are somewhat intertwined,Alan's work and his
> 'distribution'; and the meaning of meaninglessness), have helped to produce
> some discriminations regarding, message to noise ratios, and  'cut-up' which
> help define the field (and clarify mis-readings in the process).
>            Wystan



My recent post on the literary excellence thread was in response to the
following post:



 Date:    Tue, 27 Aug 2002 06:10:31 -0700
>> From:    lewis lacook <llacook@YAHOO.COM>
>> Subject: Re: Literary Excellence
>>
>> i've often wondered why in this literary culture we
>> admire poets instead of poems...
>>
>>
>> --- jesse

My thanks to Wystan for so effectively pulling together some ideas and
threads. Although there were some interesting points made contrary to this
idea, I still think that Lewis Lacook's point is well taken. Throughout
poetry history certain specific poems do stand out as particularly powerful.
These are often the favorites repeated in anthologies like Stevens' "idea of
Order at Key West," Shelley's "Ozymandias", Keats' "Ode on a Grecian Urn,"
Coleridge's "Kubla Khan," certain poems by Emily Dickenson, Mathew Arnold's
poem "Dover Beach" ending with the famous line "where ignorant armies clash
by night". Many of these all time hits happen, I notice, to make very
powerful points that combine poetics and politics:  "beauty is truth, truth
beauty," "I am Oxymandias, King of Kings...the lone and level sands stretch
far away," "Where Alph the sacred river ran, down to a sunless sea,""O
blessed rage for order, pale Ramon." To focus on specific poems tends to
focus us on the truths they reveal about life and art. They become landmarks
in the process of poetic development, powerfully memorable efforts by
individual poets that lead to ways of thinking that help peel away the
seductive false smooth lies of self serving totalitarian doctrines and
government and mass media propaganda; all the ways that our overly
organized, obsessive-compulsive civilization wears away the ability to think
and feel for ourselves.

My apologies for any mistakes in references; I am still on vacation and away
from my books.


Nick Piombino

From:         Vernon Frazer <vfrazer@ATTBI.COM>
Subject:      Re: A Question of Scope
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding:  quoted-printable

Hi Sheila

At one point in my life I considered each of my works to be part of one =
long work, e.g. the novels of Celine, Kerouac's Duluoz Legend, Whitman's =
Leaves of Grass. Now I'm not so sure. Over the past 20 years, I've =
expanded into too many areas to see how they all might fit together. My =
poetry started out as Black-Mountain-West Coast Beat but seems to be =
moving into a post langpo with vizpo elements. Most of my fiction is in =
an avant-pop/magical realism mode, but I still tend to write the =
occasional gritty realism piece. I have an unproduced play that's =
definitely gritty realism. And even my fusion of Black-Mountain-West =
Coast Beat poetry with free jazz isn't so simple, since I performed =
sections from my more langpo-oriented IMPROVISATIONS (I--XXIV) with free =
jazz opposite John Sinclair less than a year ago. My fingers have =
branched out in so many directions I'm not sure where my hand is. My =
current attitude about whether my work is all one piece is "I'll know =
when I get there." If I don't find out, I hope someone else will figure =
it out.

Geez, Sheila...do you always have to ask such  difficult questions?      =
 : )

Vernon

From:         Ken Rumble <rumblek@BELLSOUTH.NET>
Subject:      My Great....
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"

"My Great, Great, Great Grandfather, Josiah, Fights the Poney Gang"


"His toughest job was to lead the posse to clean up the Poney Gang, a group
of white trash hoodlums who robbed, raped, and murdered the other white
citizens.  With peace established, Josiah became a successful farmer."
- From an unpublished history of the Josiah Cowan York Sr. family by John
York Rumble

Eye on the blood pooling
Trying not to see the dead man’s dark cavities through his slack mouth
        (like a tunnelmouth where the road dives below rivers, bays, or cities
                (never liked dead faces  photos either
Blood between his forefinger and thumb rubbing it like a coin
        (how?  when?
Bowed floorboards popped up in places, dusty porch sloping towards the
southern exposure, dirt yard, dirt in the shack, dirt in their hair and
fingertips, now blood
        (like in Gone with the Wind
Woman too, and abused, neither armed
        (was the man kneeling?  "execution style" the papers say these days
                (he got them, of course, but how?

He: smoked a pipe
        (probably, a common practice for gentility and he was -- representative of
the law,
         blood of a revolutionary soldier, land/slaveowner
The Gang:  poor, white, couldn’t spell pony right
        (bad combination

I look for him at the reunion, in dark windows
(how?  no pictures, like repels like
I see some of me
but can’t put my fingers on him
        (as if touching makes the fiction real
The fingers of smoke in my lungs grew here,
geography he walked
        (erosion took his footprints -- I walk on turned earth two feet off
                (on account of continental shift
                        ("here" and "there" and "now" interchangeable

He got them, of course
        (posse, guns, oily torches letting loose gusts of flame
                (strange lynching white folk
                        (but how?
This story’s easy
        (with the dreamy edges of sitcom flashbacks
and weird because of the silly name
No Indian blood on the boots, no slave quarters out back
        (he did both:  made sure the Cherokee took the trail,
         raised a whip more than likely, somewhere out there darker cousins
This face there too though



--Ken Rumble

From:         jesse glass <ahadada@GOL.COM>
Subject:      Many Happy Detournements
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

For those who didn't catch it, most of what I've done and said has been in
jest.  Must we always be so earnest in our discussions on this list?  Must
the I always be the true I of the speaker? (If there is a true I.)

There are many ways of opening up topics for discussion.  There are many
ways of manipulating/performing/intervening.  Hasn't anyone ever tried them
out?  I imagine that most of us must be serious here because perhaps they
feel that they have a career at stake.

Yes, I meant some of what I said about Alan's method, but I also
exaggerated, took a point and pushed it, pushed it, pushed it. I also tried
to include some hint that all was not what it seemed.  In a sense, Alan is
this list's shared spectacle.

I want to thank Tom Bell for his quiet dicussions concerning this topic,
which I've been following.  Also his wonderful posting on Glazier's book!
Thanks for that!

Brandon blew my cover, but he went on to deliver some of the most
interesting explanations of what cyber-artists are doing.  Lewis' lecture
was also appreciated.

Why can't I "durst not go" where Alan goes?  Why the heck not?

As for Alan, I've noticed that many of his recent postings reflected
vocabulary from the list situation, so in a sense I've been his Muse.

Love,

Jesse

of Ch'ien-tzu wen, of the waist of language


"He perceives the base of infinite space as the base of infinite space.
Having perceived the base of infinite space as the base of infinite space,
he conceives [himself as] the base of infinite space, he conceives [him-
self] in the base of infinite space, he conceives [himself apart] from the
base of infinite space, he conceives the base of infinite space to be
'mine,' he delights in the base of infinite space. Why is that? Because he
has not fully understood it, I say." (Mulapariyaya Sutta: Sutta 1:15,
trans. Nanamoli, Bodhi)

I  think it is way to easy to slap out a diagnosis or disorder  with some
kind of  disregard to what it  might mean in relationship to have
psychological system that has created convenient categories and then applies
them like tap water.  two in MPD the majority of the time each person or
individual does no know the other... one might want to read some of
Allucquere Stone's "The War of Desire and Technology at the Close of the
Mechanical age" for future insight on MPD.

Call for Papers

Poetry Area, Popular Culture Association Conference 2003
Location: New Orleans, Louisiana.
Call for Papers Deadline: 2002-9-19

For those interested in the Poetry Area of the Popular Culture Association
Conference's annual meeting to be held April 16-19, 2003, at the New
Orleans Marriott:

The Poetry Area of the Popular Culture Association is interested in paper
abstracts on populist American poets or other poets who have influenced
American popular culture and/ or poetry, past or present. Poetry and
Popular Culture offers limitless potential, e.g., small press poetry, zine
poetry, underground poetry, small press publishing, popular conceptions of
the poem, The Beats, bohemian poets, concrete and visual poetry as a =
poetry
residing outside the academy, etc. etc., etc., =85 be creative. Proposals =
for
panels are encouraged.

Letters and one-page abstracts for this form of paper or panel should be
sent to Michael Basinski, The Poetry/Rare Books Collection, 420 Capen =
Hall,
SUNY at Buffalo, Buffalo, NY 14260 or to basinski@acsu.buffalo.edu

For more information on the conference and the organization see:

http://www2.h-net.msu.edu/~pcaaca/

Presentations will consist of reading a paper (20 minutes) and holding a
brief question and answer period. Please send a one page abstract of your
paper along with your letter. Please include in your letter your
accurate/current address, phone number, and e-mail address. This is
extremely important.

The proposal deadline for these panels is September 19, 2002. Notification
by mid-October.

All writers of accepted proposals will be furnished with further
information concerning conference registration, hotel accommodations, and
other pertinent information.

I would be happy to address all questions.

Michael Basinski
The Poetry/Rare Books Collection
420 Capen Hall
SUNY at Buffalo
Buffalo, New York
14260
basinski@acsu.buffalo.edu

Wow! Sorry to have knackered you out, Richard! Yes, well, downloading and installing Shockwave
can be a drag on some machines and connections, I realize.

I've put together a great links page, if you'd like to check out some fine work around the
world. It's at http://vispo.com/misc/links.htm . I've been building this page since 95, deleting
the odd link when I find the site doesn't exist anymore. The order of it is sloppily
chronological, mainly, according to when I came across the work. It's annotated so you get some
sense of where you're going, and whether it's primarily using this or that gizmo, usually, and
what I thought the main attractions were.

I tend to link out a lot in the essays I do at http://vispo.com/writings , also, and sometimes
also link out from within Shockwave or other gizmo work. I think a lot of us doing work for the
Web see part of what we are doing as trying to create a rich and meaningfully linked web of
related work that allows people to find their way around the world to exciting, international
net.work.

ja

From:         Gary Sullivan <gpsullivan@HOTMAIL.COM>
Subject:      Re: Reply to Milli Vanilli
Mime-Version: 1.0

>one might want to read some of Allucquere Stone's "The War of Desire and
>Technology at the Close of the Mechanical age" for future insight on MPD.

My favorite is from one who has lived with MPD (or DID) for many years,
Madison Clell. She does an autobio comic, "Cuckoo." Here's some descriptive
stuff from her website <http://www.cuckoocomic.com>, which also includes
many pages from her comics:

Madison Clell is a Portland-based writer and artist who lives with a
condition known as Dissociative Identity Disorder (more commonly referred to
as Multiple Personality Disorder). She has published ten issues of an
autobiographical comics series titled Cuckoo.

Madison?s goal with Cuckoo is to shed some light on living with multiple
personality disorder. "If all you know about multiple personality disorder
is from Sybil and Three Faces of Eve, you probably don?t have a very human
picture of the condition," said Madison. "That?s why I write Cuckoo, to show
the what, how, where, why, and who of living as a multiple. The comics are
true stories ranging from the serious to the very silly?for example, how
does one deal with an alternate personality who only speaks Italian? How is
it possible to balance a checkbook when multiple bank accounts keep
mysteriously opening and closing? I present the material in an entertaining
fashion so that people want to read it?it?s a Trojan horse."

From author/illustrator Madison Clell:

Cuckoo started out as an elaborate sci-fi/fantasy world, generated inside my
seven-year-old mind and taking form as obsessive games and daydreams. Over
the years this fantasy developed an extensive plot and cast of characters,
some of whom seemed so tangible I believed they were real people. Every year
I vowed to record this world in "The Epic Novel"?having no idea how to begin
such a project, of course! From age seven onwards I made many attempts at
the novel, but always after either one page, or three, or twenty, I quit,
feeling frustrated and correctly assuming that my writing stank! When my
best friend introduced me to comic books, I decided to change "The Epic
Novel" into "The Epic Graphic Novel." I had no idea how to draw comics, but
blindly hoped if I read enough comic books and still slacked off learning
visual skills, this art form would be mastered though osmosis.

Thirteen years later, "The Epic Graphic Novel" by then engraved in the far
reaches of my skull, I entered therapy for hallucinations, flashbacks, lost
time, and speaking in strange voices. After a year of intensive therapy and
the usual denial over the diagnosis of Dissociative Identity Disorder, a
lightning bolt struck. My "Epic Graphic Novel," my "fantasy world," wasn't
make-believe at all! It was a gigantic metaphor for my fragmented,
dissociated mind, complete with alters cast as "fantasy characters" and
worlds where the power to erase the lives and memories of other people was
considered the ultimate weapon. After thirteen years of compulsive
make-believe, the Fantasy turned out to be REAL!

Cuckoo is the real-life "Epic Graphic Novel." Many wonderful people have
stuck their necks out for this project, and I've met and corresponded with
numerous multiples and "singleton" readers around the world. As a result of
years in therapy, and creating these comics, I am now almost integrated.

My tremendous thanks go to all who have helped, all who have reached out and
written me, and everyone who has shown an interest in Cuckoo. Your
participation has been and will continue to be appreciated far more than you
know.

Cuckoo will continue to be published until "The Epic Story" is finished.

From:         Joel Weishaus <weishaus@PDX.EDU>
Subject:      Re: Literary Excellence
MIME-Version: 1.0

Nick:

Indeed poetry can have an effect larger than only on the circle of its
practitioners. Are we lacking in educating the media and the public as to
the relevance poems may have to a democracy? When we get a rare opportunity,
as, for example, Robert Pinsky does on PBS, we fail "to confound the types
of  'rational thinking' that are in reality harmfully manipulative and
constrictive to freedom of experience and thought," as you say.

-Joel


> Yes, Joel, I think there are advances in the field of poetics; these
> advances are most dramatically seen in applications of techniques from
> poetry and poetics to other fields and from other fields to poetry. There
> was a tremendous density of such exchanges during the belle epoque.
Mallarme
> may very well be the inventor of the cut-up technique. His experiments
with
> typography set the stage for the invention of many boundary melting
> applications of discoveries in poetics to other arts and other fields. For
> me, modern poetics really begins with certain works by Poe, Baudelaire,
> Mallarme and Valery. A good place to start is Valery's selection from his
> notebooks in "Analects" (Bollingen). As for "where do we want poetics to
> go?" surely few poets would disagree as to the many advantages of poets
> having greater impact themselves on the attention given to their work. I
> feel that if poets worked more closely together to the advantage of their
> field, the efforts would eventually be seen to dramatically diverge from
the
> approaches used in traditional literary criticism. Electronic poetry
offers
> powerful possibilities for advances in the field of poetics; it has its
own
> fascinating aura inhabited by the ghosts of Edison, Marconi and countless
> others; poets and poetry have so much to contribute to electronic
> communication; I feel that specifically poetry and poetics are central to
> the analysis and prevention of thought control by global corporatism and
the
> rapid rise of Big Brother language manipulations by governments. Poetic
> usage of the cut-up technique helped free other arts from focusing
> necessarily on a unitary image or theme. These techniques, especially in
> their earliest incarnations gave readers (and still do, though possibly to
a
> lesser degree as they become incorporated into mainstream advertising and
> literary products)  additional support in finding ways to defeat the
numbing
> effects of ever more manipulative methods of propaganda utilized in mass
> media and in government supervised educational systems. We are now living
in
> a world as prophesied by Huxley and Orwell. Totalitarianism is on the rise
> in our country and all over the world. Poetry is fun yet it has at least
one
> deadly serious purpose: to try to help save us from types of logic that
kill
> and enslave people. This brings me to Joel Weishaus' final question. What
> makes an event a poem? For me, this has to do with what I feel is one of
the
> central purposes of poetry: just this- to confound the types of "rational
> thinking" that are in reality harmfully manipulative and constrictive to
> freedom of experience and thought. Novalis: "Poetry heals the wounds
> inflicted by reason." And Dylan Thomas: "And death shall have no dominion/
> dead men naked they shall be one/with the man in the wind and the west
> moon/when their bones are picked clean and their clean bones gone/ they
> shall have stars at elbow and foot/though they go mad they shall be sane/
> though they sink through the sea they shall rise again/though lovers be
lost
> love shall not/and death shall have no dominion" (quoted from memory, so
my
> apologies for errors in quotation).
>
> Chris Stroffolino asked me about listening to poetry and the ego effect. I
> do think when listening to poetry we are better able to think more about
the
> music of the poem and to allow our thoughts to combine with the thoughts
of
> the poet. The poet's actual presence, in just voice or in voice and
person,
> in the best instances, allows us to paradoxically let the poet go; in that
> sense, the presence of the poet' voice becomes the transitional object we
> can hold onto while we can allow our thoughts to reach the regions of
> thought and feeling that the poet is working to allow us access to. I
think
> the book can obviously allow for great freedom in appreciating poetry
also;
> but when I look at them I am frequently reminded of biographical aspects
of
> the poetry and I am more tempted to drift towards thinking about critical
> judgment of the poet which often distorts the poet's intention in
presenting
> the poem, I think. I've noticed that when listening to poetry I can allow
my
> thoughts to better join in with those of the poet; I am enabled to think
> less about how the poet has crafted the poem, how it holds together, etc.
I
> memorized the passage above quoted from Dylan Thomas listening to the
famous
> recording of this poem available on Caedmon Records. Peter Middleton and
> others have written about the powerful effects of poetry readings in some
> very useful essays in a book edited by Charles Bernstein: "Close
Listening"
> (Oxford).
>
> Thanks to both of you for responding to my recent post on "Literary
> Excellence" with these interesting questions.
>
>
>
> Nick Piombino

her face the face
Virginia's face
thin, very

Her face
words, and

spitting blood,
There, too,
Now drop
dark as air
but did
but she
face, and
her hand
horizon
most remote
all within
ground, exile
the stairs &
and solitude;
chamber, to
nary modern
order me
robe of sky-
hair. She had
night-dark-
carcasses,
worm-eaten
songs and
refrain
darkness
day and
breadth

Cooler if a giant Sphinx
Sprung to life and ate Sting

Bristling lions of his giant
Windy moo. "Art ash ask asp
Ass asylum ate ... sperm spew Sphinx

Enemy scene beenie prince Sting
..." and catch goldfish
in their beaks. Angeled pigeons

Aiiight schism djhi Sphinx
Filled the room like a
Style-lid. ... [Object of

Knowledge] |View as Text| life-
Like, faithful; true to
Nature, true to life ... saltum [Lat]

"Order is heaven's first law"
"Order from disorder sprung ..."

From:         oranget@GEORGETOWN.EDU
Subject:      Names
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

chris, tenney, others:

in an interview i asked clark coolidge "So how do you see the name
functioning in your work? Typically for the New York School, the name is
a reference to a community of friends and poets; it also sort of fixes
the work in a particular moment in time."

he responded: "Well, somewhat that way, and also maybe even more so in
just an imaginative way, what names of well-known people do to your
brain: movie stars, writers, politicians. And then also made-up names. It
isn't very far from some of the famous names to just altering them a
little bit and changing them to someone that doesn't exist. I suppose
there's an almost fictional desire to sort of invent people....Plus
naming is just so basic, and maybe really basic to what poetry is."

see http://www.jacketmagazine.com/13/coolidge-iv.html

bests,
tom

From:         Wright Laura E <Laura.Wright@COLORADO.EDU>
Subject:      DuCharme, Pritchett read in Boulder Sept. 13
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

The Left Hand Reading Series presents:

poets Patrick Pritchett and Mark DuCharme.

Friday, Sept. 13 at
8:00 p.m.
at the Left Hand Bookstore (1200 Pearl St. #10) in Boulder.


        Patrick Pritchett is the author of Reside (Dead Metaphor Press,
1999).  His book-length poem on Joan of Arc, Burn, will be published by
Chax Press in 2003.  He is a contributing editor for the poetry journal
Facture and has been a visiting faculty member at Naropa Universitys
Summer Writing Program.

Mark DuCharmes first collection of poems, Cosmopolitan Tremble, was
published this year by Pavement Saw Press.  His chapbooks include Near To
(Poetry New York, 1999); Desire Series (Dead Metaphor Press, 1999);
Contracting Scale (Standing Stones Press, 1996); i, a series  (Burning
Press, 1995); and Anon, co-written with Anselm Hollo, Patrick Pritchett
and Laura E. Wright (Potato Clock Editions, 2001).  His work was selected
twice for the Gertrude Stein Awards in Innovative American Poetry from Sun
& Moon Press.  Recent or forthcoming magazine appearances include
Antennae, Canwehaveourballback, Combo, Conundrum, For Immediate Release,
Fulcrum, Morkville, Shiny, Ur-Vox, -VeRT and 88: A Journal of Contemporary
American Poetry.  He has also published several essays on poetics and
reviews of new poetry, in journals such as American Letters & Commentary,
Talisman, Witz and The Poetry Project Newsletter.  He lives and works in
Boulder, where he is a former director of the Left Hand Reading Series, a
founding member of the School of Continuation, and an editor of Potato
Clock Editions.

                There will  be a short Open Reading immediately before the
featured readings.  Sign up for the Open Reading will take place promptly
at 8:00 p.m.
        The Left Hand Reading Series is an independent series presenting
readings of original literary works by emerging and established writers.
Upcoming events in the series include:
        Friday, Oct. 18: Daron Mueller & Laird Hunt
        For more information about the Left Hand Reading Series, call
(303) 443-3685.


--
Laura Wright
Serials Cataloging
Norlin Library, University of Colorado, Boulder

(303) 492-3923

list's membership -- I now follow a practice of not opening any attachment

them.  The virus protection software on my office computer does a pretty
good job of catching these things, but the software on my home computer
needs updating.

Hey Guys --

I just clicked on the button at the EPC for Ed Foster's Talisman, out of
Jersey, but the web site the button took me to was the quite different

Dear Patrick Herron:


It has come to my attention that you like to join lists just so you can talk
to yourself in public.  Maybe you consider your writing more authentic if
you respond to people who see you as irrelevant or worse.

Far be it from you to be discouraged by your absenting from discourse.  Oh
no.  You feel it is your need to make sociopathy appear to be an occasion
for conical birthday hats or prone canines juggling howler monkeys.  You can
defend the overposted, the ignored, and the belligerent all you want.  You
can post poems that operate with rules that are neither quite organic nor
algorithmic.  Those are much less than boring.  You can post political
journalism but you forget you are simply being negative or that 10,000
Francophiles can quote pseudophilosophical crap establishing the utter
hopelessness about change.  Ah, "change," a cute concept for the desperately
naive!  You can insist that proper names are an occasion for becoming
properly pissed.  You can design websites but no one knows what the fuck you
are talking about.  It is painfully clear that you are not talking about
anything relevant.  Pink web pages, pal?  Somebody back me up here!

You can attend readings, performances and publish in journals.  Be rest
assured that no one listens, no one reads.  You can write books, but clearly
they are unfocused, disparate, unworthy of white whale status.  That one
time we bothered to glance at you, you were not there.  Let's be honest.
You will never be.  We see right through you.  Your art stinks.

Writing is no mirror; it is not sufficient for reflection.  Neither are you
sufficient.  Though, of course, I'd like to have sex with you.  But only
when you are dead and your bone is ash.  You are a vapid fraud formed from
vapor.  Ah, to heckle the dead and buried!  It is your most worthy remark. A
mirror is not when dark.

What's worse, you write letters to yourself on this list, wasting bandwidth
and people's time in an apparent attempt to draw even more attention to
yourself, to maybe sucker some people into delivering some pity to you.
Ranting on and on with self-abuse and disregard.  As if pity is a worthy
remedy for a lack of attention.  Forget it.  Push your shopping cart out of
here.  Or stay here.  Cheap tricks.  I do not care.  Even in your
ephemerality you are frightfully pathetic.  Your mirrors consume themselves
into wisps of nothing.


Patrick Herron
patrick@proximate.org


PS: You might help your reality if you attend graduate school.  Especially
if it gives you the opportunity to spend 20-30K a year reading the horrible
doctoral dissertations your professors excused into book form and sloughed
off as serious criticism.  It will make you someone, maybe even a published
poet.

PSS: Don't tell anyone that I wrote you.  Thanks.
=========================================================================

dialog among nothings


how the world was formed with many infinities and paradises

echo "beginning program of branching and ending"
dialog --infobox "entering and approaching the originary / something in
dialog --infobox "restructuring of your position here / bringing a
position into play" 4 60
dialog --infobox "nothing before and nothing later" 4 50
dialog --inputbox "beginning with the origin" 4 60 2> zz
dialog --inputbox "ending with continuous restructuring" 4 60 2>> zz
dialog --inputbox "your identification" 4 60 2>> zz
dialog --inputbox "your anonymity" 4 60 2>> zz

one position, two skittering three and/or four trembling: five all six for
seven nothing, eight plasma nine one ten what two more three about four
the five annotation six necessary seven for eight construction ten what of
more original defining the meaning necessary playfulness construction a
the position, original defining skittering the and/or meaning trembling:
of all the nothing, of plasma

beginning flourish therefore anonymously in in the the midst interstices
of of things, the carrying imaginary things beginning too therefore far,
in towards the edges, of margins, carrying any too possibility the far,
jewels the and edges, flowers, the glorious margins, maidens, of virginal
any handsome things, young jewels men, and which flowers, flourish
glorious anonymously maidens, interstices handsome imaginary which

recuperation nothing i do before play of or restructuring later sorry
nothing forgetting before myself or in later sorry name-naming forgetting
recuperation myself to play of name-naming restructuring your
identification and anonymity the interior interior of the world the
interior the interior the edge

Jesse, I have Paul Knight's translation in which the section you refer to
appears as number 8 of Book 4.  Knight has it as "Every night, swooping with
the vast span of my wings into the death-throes of my memory . . . ," and his
rendition evinces no cut up technique.  Sounds like you have the more
interesting text.  It's surely possible that Knight went about straightening
out the room.  Unfortunate.  It makes sense to me that "Isi" Ducasse deranged
his texts, both the one he lived and the one he wrote (one and the same?)
Best, Bill

WilliamJamesAustin.com
KojaPress.com
Amazon.com
BarnesandNoble.com

Michael,

I assume you don't only mean Greeks or Romans. Armand Schwerner and Sue
Landers have translations of Dante (and great ones at that). john Taggart
translated passages from aeschylus. Richard Sieburth has a very interesting
treatment of Holderlin's "a Map of Mnemosyne," which is holderlin's attempt
to translate the Greek spirit into German. Ben Friedlander has work
(translations) in Holderlin style. Holderlin seems to be the key path for us
both to the Greeks and also to the East (through the Persian sufi poet Hafiz).

Then there are Andrew Schelling's translations of classical indian erotic
poetry and my translations of the 13th century Turkish sufi poet Yunus Emre
and 16th century poet pir Sultan...

i think interest in classical poetry is very strong among some poets today,
but the scope of that classism is much wider.

Best.

Murat

From:         MWP <mpalmer@JPS.NET>

Comments: To: BarbaraThimm@yahoo.co.uk
In-Reply-To:  <20020831173538.95030.qmail@web11901.mail.yahoo.com>

on 8/31/02 10:35 AM, Barbara Thimm at barbarathimm@YAHOO.CO.UK wrote:

> could you perhaps describe more specifically what you
> mean by "experimental poetry"?


Hm. I will get to your question in a moment. But first a bit of the
backstory -


I guess my question arose when I began to think about how somebody like
Clark Coolidge (unquestionably an experimental poet, I think it's fair to
say) would go about translating a classical author like Hesiod or Firdusi
etc. Since I couldn't even imagine how it would come about, I began to
ponder whether the age of poets translating old texts like these was finally
over with the generation(s?) of Zukofsky and Pound, at least among cutting
edge experimental poets of Coolidge's ilk. I may be wrong in my assumption,
but if so, I am interested in hearing why. Why doesn't the challenge of
translation seem to appeal to experimental poets anymore? Has it died and
been handed over to the academics, or is something else amiss?

As to what defines experimental poetry, who knows? I can only cite examples.
I would say that Ashbery on forward is arguably what demarcates the
experimental, more or less. Could anybody see Ashbery translating Ovid?
Ashbery has sometimes translated in his own way modern poets like Craven who
have an aesthetic alliance of sorts with him, but how might he handle
something in an ancient, alienated past? I leave this as an open question.


(How about it AS? Care to try your hand at the Kabbalah?)


m*rk p
=========================================================================

and i'm interested to know what you mean by "translation."
i've been re-reading Rational Geomancy, and the first third or so of the book
investigates translation as a poetic act, so i've got translation on the brain,
and i seem to see it everywhere.
In the sense that nichol & mccaffery use it there-

"the act of organizing space, semiotic balances and the emotional weight
between word-objective-phenomena; .. the modification of pressures in and among
words..."

 i think it might be safe to say that Rob Fitterman translates parts of
Petrarch's Dialogues in Metropolis 16-29.

katherine

> been handed over to the academics, or is something else amiss?
>
> As to what defines experimental poetry, who knows? I can only cite examples.
> I would say that Ashbery on forward is arguably what demarcates the
> experimental, more or less. Could anybody see Ashbery translating Ovid?
> Ashbery has sometimes translated in his own way modern poets like Craven who
> have an aesthetic alliance of sorts with him, but how might he handle
> something in an ancient, alienated past? I leave this as an open question.
>
> (How about it AS? Care to try your hand at the Kabbalah?)
>
> m*rk p

From:         Andrew Rathmann <andyrathmann@EARTHLINK.NET>
Subject:      Re: Experimental Poetry & Classical Voices

Of related interest:

1. Frank Bidart, _Desire_ (FSG, 1997); _Music Like Dirt_ (Sarabande, 2002).  His retelling of Ovid's Myrrha story in _Desire_ is a masterpiece.

2. Christopher Logue's ongoing _War Music_.  The latest installment, a battle scene in the _Iliad_, is in the summer issue of _The Threepenny Review_ (along with an interesting essay on Bidart's classicism by Rosanna Warren).

In the chapbook _Music Like Dirt_, Bidart focuses on the metaphysical and emotional contradictions of poiesis.  He centers, for example, on the fact that artists' avidity for making is always linked to their dissatisfaction with what they have made.  Because art is the static, "finished" imitation of fluid praxis, its triumph--to have embodied life as if for all time--is also a source of pain to the artist, whose urge to go on making does not cease, cannot cease.  This poem, "Hammer," focuses on an impossible wish that works of art might also embody their own destruction.  A poet's poet's poem:

        Hammer

        The stone arm raising a stone hammer
        dreams it can descend upon itself.

        When the quest is indecipherable,--
        ...what is left is a career.

        What once was apprehended in passion
        survives as opinion.

        To be both author of
        this statue, and the statue itself.

I think both Bidart and Logue are among the most interesting contemporary poets to have drawn material from Greek and Roman sources.

Andy Rathmann

Subject:      Re: Experimental Poetry & Classical Voices
In-Reply-To:  <006b01c2515b$ae5d0240$30343544@rthfrd01.tn.comcast.net>

on 8/31/02 7:02 PM, Thomas Bell at trbell@COMCAST.NET wrote:

> this is kind of a weird winnowing process, I think.  I assume, for example,
> that Ed Sanders would be considered either not experimental enough or not
> poetical enough or the Chekov he 'translates' be in spirit and not in
> "verse" so successfully eliminated from consideration?
>
> tom bell

I am not trying to winnow anybody out, but I am particularly interested in
seeing how far out translation can be pushed and still be considered
translation, which is why I stress the experimental side of this.
Traditional translations are not terribly valuable to me in this regard as
they follow the standard rules, although they may be perfectly fine in every
other respect. I want to hear about the weird, crazy possibilities and
actualities, like LZ's Catullus. I am not interested in drawing up a
syllabus on the topic, only in stimulating new ideas and seeing where they
lead.

It seems to me that many experimental poets, and the language poets in
particular, often deal with words as fixed objects for manipulation instead
of seeing them as being something that can get mapped onto something else in
a variety of ways. (Translation being one of those ways.) That is, you often
find poets treating words as harvestable markers in a database, etc. instead
of as dynamic, topologically transformable entities. What I am hoping the
discussion of translation will ultimately lead to is to raise the issue of
what is a word and how does it function, especially within a textual entity
that is the direct translation of another entity that is also made of words.
Are the one-dimensional word qua object-based techniques of today's
experimental poets limiting their options vis a vis the way a text can
intersource with other texts? These are the kinds of questions I am grasping
at. (Maybe still rather badly at this stage.)


m*rk p

I think it's an interesting project as you describe it.

1. How does this fit in with what Ron posted re 'sans verbs'?

2.  I consider myself somewhat of an experimental poet in the sense that I
do like to experiment but see that more as coming from translations I've
done and influencing me experimentation rather than vice versa?  This is not
completely lucid to me at the moment but I feel like I learned to pick out
and manipulate words and concepts in space and order, etc. either from the
way I was trained as a translator or the first work I did which was as a
voice intercept operator listening in to Russian tanks on manoever, etc.
There might be an interesting clue in me and other students realizing we
were dreaming in Russian and it would appear related to the type of
instruction we got which was we basically spent 8 hours a day 'in Russia' or
at least exclusively speaking it.

3.  The translation issue I'm intrigued by at the moment is helping native
speakers of other languages put their English (which tend to be very good
but perhaps'academic' or arcane) into something that makes sense for anglo
academic and/or practitioner audiences (audiences?).   For example, this was
my role with Dmirti Bulatov for his two anthologies and here it was
compounded since many of the articles he either translated first into
Russian (or in many cases had it done) before were 'translated' from Russian
into English.  i do regret that I didn't have the time to do more than what
I would consider a 'passable' job on this.

probably more than you wanted to know but I'm in the mood today.

tom bell

Then there's Kent Johnson - The Miseries of Poetry - see below. I've read

Announcing: The Miseries of Poetry: Versions from the Greek,
translated by Alexandra Papaditsas (1960-2002) and Kent
Johnson. Vestibulum [spora tradere], by Slavoj Zizek;
Preface, by Kent Johnson; Introduction, by Alexandra
Papaditsas. Nineteen translations. 30+ pages. $6. Available fall,
2002. First 25 copies, B through Z, signed by Kent Johnson.
Advance signed copies ordered directly through the publisher:
Skanky Possum Press * 2925 Higgins Street * Austin, TX
78722

*

We have all always desired the eyeless goddess, the handsome
whore-boy,
the Megala Louloudia.  Here they are.  Ever since the cache was
discovered
at Montazah Palace, we=92ve been waiting for translations suitable
for
Greek menus everywhere.  Had the Greeks invented fortune
cookies, they
could not have foretold the strange beauty of these versions.

-Eleni Sikelianos


I'm doubled over by the Miseries of Poetry, folded into a mirror
world of literature and here live on moth-ambrosia, play happily
with
possible ancillas of the Pre-Socratics. --

-Garrett Kalleberg


Like the Jews, if Kent Johnson didn't exist, someone would have
to invent
him. His mind leaks nomads constantly naming world-historic
hinges as if
inscription were always underfoot. You can't pull Catullus out of
the
'incubated / god, writing himself into being' but you can pull the
door
open. Literature is close to fraud, evanescent and trembling in
these times of
incipient terror. Johnson's approach deconstructs and
exacerbates that
fraud; I think of his work as returning to the (re)creation of
language -
political and sexual language, the languages of the last people
speaking
on earth.

-Alan Sondheim


If they ever need a Classics Geek on "Beat the Geeks," Dr.
Kent Johnson is
their man. The Miseries of Poetry is an operatically nerdy
intervention
in the transmission of ancient lyric, a scurrilous, fantastical,
erudite,
shameless, and often very moving addition to the Geek--er,
Greek--Anthology. More faithful in its peregrinate Sapphic
incontinence than most of the
last two centuries of vanilla-flavored translations, this sheaf of
cracked-amphora smut will change the way people misinterpret
Linear B
forever.  Roll over, Richmond Lattimore: this is not your father's
Mimnermus.

-Kasey Silem Mohammad


In the realm of ethics the ends rarely justify the means; in the
realm of art they always do. This complex translation by
Alexandra Papaditsas and Kent Johnson is flamboyant,
provocative, and brilliant. In three or four thousand years, when
English has long sounded more Asian than European, The
Miseries of Poetry will no doubt be inciting tremendous passions
at the KGB Bar.

-David Lehman


=2E.still...moisture on the long
papyrus fragments, vivid
charm and cultural
codes transposed
on a spit the
tang of the Johnson mystagogus,
with live voice on quitch-grass
carnal and refined,
the then swag of buddhistic
pomegranites, the bull-leapers..

-Lissa Wolsak


In The Miseries of Poetry, which court(s) opprobrium as a
slanted form
of cultural capital, violent mannerism is at war with erudite
imagination.
Neither wins. Read it to behold their struggle and moments of
startling
poetry.

-Nada Gordon


A pair of fabled translators politely ambushes us with a rich and
randy
trove of ancient papyri with a dicey provenance. Here the real is
imbedded
in the unreal, the imaginary in the factual. Lacunae appear where
there
were none, and credible texts, adeptly contemporized, where
there were
holes. The holes themselves are deliciously elaborated. Once the
reader is
urged to fall, "Fall, orangely, to the ground" resistance, in a single
adverb, is dispelled.

-C.D. Wright


When Frank, Kenneth, Jimmy and I were young, the
idea of forgery
was a kind of coal to make us go very fast: We
shoveled it,
hungrily, into the bellowing fire, and the speed of our
engine became often
quite fantastic. There were no rules in that magical
land; the backs of
our chairs were turned against the sun, and
sometimes we would
get this overwhelming feeling of exaltation. Now,
suddenly, we are
here at this station, and one wonders, frankly,
what has happened.
"Avant-garde" poetry, whatever it is, like Amtrak
rail travel, so clickety-
clack, so predictable and slow... May I suggest
that Alexandra Papaditsas
be canonized as a saint of translation, and the cast
of her horned head
placed like a warning above the door of The
Academy of American Poets.

-John Ashbery


What a strange debt of gratitude we owe to Kent Johnson and
his
co-translator, the perpetually-betrayed and haplessly goat-
horned
Alexandra Papaditsas (now deceased). In The Miseries of
Poetry they
bring us versions from the Greek that are at once bafflingly
poignant,
shriekingly funny, and far lovelier than they have any right to be,
especially in light of their vexed provenance. These are poems
full of
mystery and buggery, flying in from an unmapped world on thin
gold wings.

-Rachel Loden


Kent Johnson's Miseries probes our own relation with ancient
Greek
musicks, which for most of us are only ever received through
"translation." In so doing, he celebrates and tweaks the
permeability
of that membrane we call "self" or "author-ity." Who is alive and
who
is not, now? Are you alive, reader? The arguments and
skirmishes of a
translator are, perhaps, "the miseries of poetry." And, in this,
though translation might be always a "weird extrinsic
appendage," we
like it, we crave it, for it's also "love's ultimate excrescence into
joy."

-Erin Moure


O to be struck by lightning
And have a horn sprout
>From the middle of your forehead!
Kent Johnson & Alexandra
Papaditsas, may the ancient
Greeks forgive you.  And us.

-John Bradley


>From the halls of Carl Rakosi's objectivism to the shores of Dr.
Kinbote's cretian textual labyrinths come the conquering soldier boys of
Alexandra Papaditsas and Kent Johnson's translations. What too but the pith
and vinegar of Brautigan and Koch, the pint-sized minotaur farting in the
center of these inventions and oh we can't forget the horn, no, on
Alexandra Papaditsas' head: that horn of plenty on which Kent Johnson
impaled himself and rode up and down the alleyways of Thylakis groaning
and drunk. Yes, I think that "objectionable" is the best term for such poem=
s.
In fact, as with all great works of art, this book is utterly tasteless.

-Gabriel Gudding


I spent a careless youth looting ancient sites in West Texas, taking
artifacts and shards to decorate my bookcase and bedroom. Later I
discovered the volumes of LITERARY PAPYRII in the Loeb Series, and stole
the fragmented  images shamelessly. We each translate the world we find
ourselves in-- it is the only way we can understand the void. Nothing
whole remains. Even the universe is incomplete.  If Papaditsas believes it
was Romans who destroyed Alexandria, let it be. Though all the Emperor
Caracalla did in reply to satires was massacre the inhabitants in 215 CE.
It was 'Amir the Arab who is said to have burnt the Library
there in 640
CE, though that too is not exactly correct. Just like these poems,
and the
universe entire. And ourselves, wretched readers. But what
beauty and
astonishment remains!

-Howard McCord
